149268821.review:
The final installment of the Final Fantasy XIII series. 

It's been a long journey, one that I'm happy I took. Every game in the series offered something unique to build off the previous one. FF13 offered a classic Final Fantasy story with one of the best protagonist, 13-2 gave us an expanded universe of time, space, and entourage. And with Lightning returns... it gives us the human, the ones that are the reason we are on this journey in the first place.

The side-quests play a vital role in the story and lore of the series. It humanizes the experience in a way the game hasn't done before. Doing what we're suppose to do versus knowing why we're doing it makes all the difference. 

The game is sluggish to start, truthfully. I did ask myself during the early stages, "Do I really care?" In those moments, I didn't. I allowed prenotions to guide my feelings during that time, but once I continued on it was well worth the time spent. It surprised me, in more ways than one. 

The main story is only half of the game...journeying through the side-quests makes it whole. There were many moments where -everything clicked-. I could see the beauty, the flaw, and raw in each one who asked for my assistance. It was situations you could both sympathize and empathize with. It weaved that emotional attachment to the world-little by little-to understand the 'why'.

Story aside, there are a few unresolved gameplay glitches that can mess your enjoyment and time. The ones I've experienced are sudden simulation freezes after a battle (it will be an empty screen, failing to load). While only happening a few times, this took out quite a bit of progress done prior. I recommend always saving (and multiple save files) after a long-stretch of a main/side mission and at particular points of interest to save time.

The second bug is something I have not seen anyone (over all these years) experience. When you travel to the second location, I recommend not speaking to any of the food vendors until you accept a side-quest mission 'Family Food' (which is very close by). I ran through all the vendors prior of accepting that quest and there was nothing I could do to continue it. It failed to interact the story, making it forever stuck.

This game also has a NewGame+ feature. Do not fret if you somehow can't complete (or fail) every single thing in the game the first time...because you literally can't.

Also, go the the top left of your screen when in-game. If you had to adjust only one setting, let it be 'Color Correction: Advanced'. There is no other setting that makes the game look more modern. That yellow hue is GONE!

If you've made the commitment from 13 and 13-2...this is your journey's end. The story, the atmosphere, the characters... all of it. It's worth it. It brings the final peace needed for the series.

While Lightning Returns isn't perfect it's an interesting end of an unusual trilogy. Of all the Final Fantasy's it's odd that Final Fantasy 13 is the one that got a trilogy of games. While there are places where you can see that the budget was lower than the original 13, Lightning Returns has a lot of interesting ideas, but some of them are quite a bit different than I expected.

The overall premise of having a time limit felt like we were leading up to a Majora's Mask style time loop but that's not really the case. The game is quite generous with time if you utilize the timestop to the point where I slept through the last few days. This is odd, given that the game waits to open up some new mechanics until your second loop, such as leveling up equipment but you can clear it on the first run. The concept of no direct levels but getting your stats from completing quests worked well overall, and getting special drops and upgrade materials from extincting enemy types is a fairly unique system, though it does turn into a bit of a grind. The combat system is entirely different from 13 and 13-2 and I personally found it hard to ideally manage the ATB gauges. I'm not sure if that's a color blind thing or a sheer visual clutter thing but it wasn't the clearest but it's a much more active system than the others.

The story picks up directly from 13-2 and it's fine, there is definitely not enough main plot for the amount of time you have. There was a good 30 hours or so of side quest/monster extinction after finishing the plot before the plot kicked back in.

[h1]The Gameplay: [/h1]
The game-play loop was actually done incredibly well. While the removal of xp from killing monsters is an odd choice, it let me simply just avoid monsters when I wanted, and not feel like I had to passively farm them for some carrot on stick. Movement was actually very good feeling especially since you could sprint and jump/parkour around the map. You also had a time limit, which was pretty generous along with several mechanics that allowed you to feel really in control of what you were doing. Most importantly, the combat felt very nice and I can see that this would eventually become the foundation for FF15's and 7 remake's battle system, which is very nice and they should keep it like that. Everything was swell until the last act where difficulty simply spiked to the high heavens and the final fight became a slog. 

[h1]The Story:[/h1]
In short, the story was utter garbage that had no business being made for this setting. It seemed confused and had no proper focus causing a lot of it to just be random ramblings that get boring to listen to. This is before I touch on the fact that the premise is ridiculous and somehow more detached than the previous game which also did a terrible job with their story. Also putting the number 13 in things did not add to the story, nor did it really fit in any real way. Save for the characters, nothing was connected in any meaningful way. Any world building done by one game was thrown out by the next and by the time we get to the current setting, there is such a disconnect and lack of focus that it feels like another high budget fan-fiction. This is all because it tried to do too many things with it's plot and only succeeded at doing none of them well. It had the makings of a potentially good story as a base idea, but the execution was done terribly and it only executed my desire to learn any more of this story. 

[h1]The Visuals:[/h1]
The game was pleasant to look at, and the movie scenes were interesting to look at. The environments were designed well and I really loved the atmosphere created by the two cities that were in the game. That seems to be the one thing, no matter which game they seem to get incredibly right. The thing that seems to be lacking is the armor/weapon options. Half of Lightning's potential outfits were an ugly mess of belts and zippers that just somehow feel like it didn't fit her at all. Sadly this is the one game where the bonus DLC outfits seemed to fit better than the ones in the game. 

[h1]The Sound:[/h1]
The voice acting was superb as always, and we even get the bonus of almost any interaction you could have being voiced. The sound effects where also appropriate sounding, giving you the right oomph to your hits and swings. The music was also much better than it's predecessor 13-2 which was a mess. My only issue is the Victory Fan-fare happened to be the worst of all 3. I ended up using DLC outfits to avoid that cacophony. 


[h1]The Experience:[/h1]
This was a mixed bag, a true love/hate relationship was born from this game. I hated the story, but enjoyed the majority of the interactions that were generally not touching the overarching plot. I liked most of the music but really hated the fanfare. And I loved the game play until they started to enter end game where it became very tedious and seemed to favor the grind more and more. I enjoyed doing the side-quests (even though a lot of people did not) and ended up finishing it in 6 in game days. Unfortunately that is exactly the amount of time you are considered in the beginning of the game - after that you must grind to level up your skills. Ultimately, the game was not a completely bad experience, but since its major selling point is the story, and in order to get this game you have to play the travesty that is XIII-2, then this is a hard non-recommend. I went from enjoying 13, to understanding why no one ever talked about it, it was just not great after it was all said and done. Also the constant reference to the number 13 in literally anything that could be find was kind of annoying and is almost poetic to how the whole experience was for me. I wish they never did it and just made some other better story instead.

145326070.review:
As the name suggests, Lightning Returns gives back the spotlight to Lightning, the unrelenting, inexorable heroine from FF XIII. In this entry she will be thrusted into a dying world as the servant of an omnipotent deity, and will be tasked with carrying out the god's designs in what seems to be the only chance left for an agonizing humanity. Despite this central role, Lightning remains a humble character. As she answers the pleas of those in need, she will also realize the flaws within herself, turning her quest into a deeply psychological and introspective journey.

The combat is very novel, responsive and interactive. With only one controllable character, your gear and skills will be divided among three attires, each one with an independent configuration. You will be able to switch between these attires freely while fighting, allowing you to adapt to every situation. Timing and resource management is important, as is paying attention to the enemy's movement. This will seem challenging at first but with every battle you'll learn the patterns of your adversaries, thus gaining the insight on how to engage them. Multiple setups are viable, the system is fluid and lets you experiment while rewarding your creativity. 

Although the world is open and encourages exploration, progression is slow but very rewarding. Even with a limited number of days at your disposal, patience is essential. Completing missions will improve your statistics and health pool, and I recommend to do as many of these as possible.  While some might be long and time-consuming, they all earn important rewards and carry a story worth hearing. Money also becomes an important asset so it's advised to avoid rushing and defeat every foe you encounter. The path is hard yet satisfying; it will make you savor every victory and value every little improvement you gain.

Accompanied by outstanding graphics, enthralling narrative and an impeccable musical score, the beautiful XIII saga comes into full circle and gives all characters their well-deserved conclusion. Lightning Returns is a charming and unique game, one I would universally recommend to any gamer of any background, but specially to fans of the genre and those who completed the previous games.

Lightning Returns or FFXIII-3, has probably one of the best endings to a Final Fantasy ever and was the perfect way to finish off the 13 trilogy, the ending is beautiful. Easily one of my all time favourite Final Fantasies out there, housing some of my most beloved FF characters, one of my favourite FF protagonists to date (seriously Lightning is just [i]chefs kiss[/i]), a great OST, combat system and gameplay loop and a really solid story arc as well which of course is a continuation of FFXIII and FFXIII-2.
Plus you get to play dress up simulator with Lightning, so what's not to love?

Despite the above it does have it's pros and cons of course, so here's a few of the things I think it does right and doesn't do so well with, I won't go too hard here because there's a lot I could say that would be very spoilery and because I already know this is going to be a massive wall of text after what I do want to mention is said;

[h1]PROS:[/h1]
[list]
[*]Combat system is extremely diverse and unique, while it is difficult to master and perfect it is one of the most rewarding combat systems ever in a Final Fantasy. You only get to control Lightning and won't have any other permanent party members but you have a ton of different outfits you can dress Light in and all of them have different effects and abilities which while some allow you to mix and match a little bit of everything to make the perfect builds, others have exclusive abilities locked to them which can be pretty fun to play around with and min-max. [*]OST is absolutely phenomenal, there isn't a single bad track in this game and there won't be any you get tired of quickly, everything just hits right.

[*]There is TONS of content! I really do mean that, there is so much to do in this game that it can legitimately take multiple full playthroughs to collect all unique gear and do everything you need for 100%.

[*]The Boss fights for this game are really outstanding and actually difficult to beat if you don't build into fighting them correctly. Good luck!
[/list]

[h1]CONS:[/h1]
[list]
[*]Now I personally don't mind this, but the time mechanic this game has can be daunting for new players during their first playthrough so technically it's not so much a con as it is a pro subjectively. [code]Lightning Returns is the final entry in the flawed XIII trilogy and while there are some interesting ideas on offer, the game just isn’t good enough to warrant a playthrough for anyone but those who played through & enjoyed what came before[/code]

After [i]Final Fantasy XIII-2[/i] already introduced major time-skips (and ended [spoiler]500[/spoiler] years (!) after the events of [i]Final Fantasy XIII[/i]), [i]Lightning Returns[/i] moves the clock ahead even further - 500 years to be exact - which consequentially gives us yet another new setting: The last few days on Nova Chrysalia before the entire world is destroyed. Protagonist & only playable character in this game, Lightning, awakens from her crystal slumber (part of the DLC scenario in [i]Final Fantasy XIII-2[/i]) and encounters Bhunivelze, the God of Light. For the third time (!) in this trilogy, she ends up being tasked by a god, only this time to “save the souls” of the dying world’s denizens.

The most important aspect about the new setting is the aforementioned time limit (6 days before the apocalypse), which is not only a narrative device but also shaping the gameplay: The in-game  clock runs continuously and only stops during dialogues or battles. Certain actions (e.g. taking a train or escaping from fights on higher difficulties) might even lose you entire hours. If you don’t manage to fulfill your tasks in time, it’s game over and you’ll have to try again in New Game+. You can extend your time limit by “saving souls” (= completing main/side missions) up to a certain point but there’s no way to rewind time, if you want to replay certain days for example.

Time-limited missions in videogames are usually far from beloved, so time-limiting an entire game is a bold and interesting choice. Unfortunately, the gamble doesn’t work out in the end. As mentioned, the time limit can only be extended by completing main/side missions. As a matter of fact, there’s even an entire extra day & dungeon locked behind completing a certain amount of side quests (= most of them). Even worse, the only way to increase your stats (health, attack, etc.) apart from better equipment is by completing quests - since fighting random monsters only rewards money as well as Energy Point (EP), which can be used to perform powerful abilities.

Speaking of EP, here’s a tip for those who are wary about the time limit but still want to play the game: One of the EP abilities does include the power to stop the in-game clock for a short while. There’s also a mod to [url=https://www.nexusmods.com/lightningreturnsfinalfantasy13/mods/13?tab=description]make this ability free[/url], which means you can explore Nova Chrysalia for as long as you wish, as long as you keep using the time-stop ability.

To get back on point, completing side quests is the main gameplay focus of [i]Lightning Returns[/i] (apart from the main missions), as they strengthen Lightning’s stats and extend the overall time limit. This shouldn't be a problem, side quests are more interesting than killing monsters over & over again, but the ones featured here are of dull MMO-fetch quality – and work-intensive to locate.

The world of [i]Lightning Returns[/i] offers four different locations with surprisingly few ways to traverse them: Apart from the occasional train or rare teleport, you’ll spend most of the time just running around. And there’s another catch: Only main missions are marked on the map. So if you even just want to start a side quests, you’ll have to manually scout the locations for potential quest givers.

This can take a lot of time, especially since some quest givers only appear during certain hour of the day or have other preliminary conditions that need to be fulfilled. So unless you want to scout all locations multiple times a day, which is a lot of boring footwork, there’s still a big chance you’re going to miss quite a few side quests - unless you came prepared with a [url=https://www.trueachievements.com/game/Lightning-Returns-Final-Fantasy-13/walkthrough]detailed guide[/url].

And that’s only starting the side quests. If you want to do enough to reach the bonus dungeon, you’ll also spend a lot of time running around just doing them. Again, they’re basically MMO-style fetch quests, boring gameplay-wise and surprisingly boring narrative-wise as well, considering the world is about to end. Yet there’s still someone that wants you to kill X or get trivial thing Y for you, as if they didn’t have bigger trouble to take care of. Only a few missions are slightly more memorable, which is just a waste of the unique setting.

The main missions of [i]Lightning Returns[/i] are only slightly more interesting compared to the side missions. They might offer bosses and sometimes even dungeons, but the bosses all follow the “stagger, shock, slash” formula and the dungeons are uninteresting affairs, with very simple puzzles or platforming challenges set in uninspired locations. Surprisingly, time only plays a part during one particular dungeon as well, where doors only open at certain times.

At least the modified ATB battle system is still fun: Instead of utilizing different party members, protagonist and [url=https://press.na.square-enix.com/LIGHTNING-BECOMES-A-FASHION-ICON-IN-LOUIS-VUITTONS-SERIES-4-CAMPAIGN]literal Louis Vuitton model[/url] Lightning can switch between customizable outfits to fulfill different roles in battle. It does take some time to get used to it and even on normal difficulty certain fights can take quite long but if you wrap your head around it, it’s a decent refinement of what came before.

To sum things up, while the battle system is decent enough, the dull main and side missions are boring busywork. It’s also quite annoying that a guide is basically necessary, if you want to make sure you finish all the side quests you might need. But what about the story?

Unsurprisingly, the story of [i]Lightning Returns[/i] is turning the interesting setting into a predictable, messily told journey. Again, this is the third time Lightning became a servant of god and with all the time-travel trouble that came before, it’s not surprising that the story feels weighed down by the mess the predecessors created.

Initially, it seems like the game wants to fix that by focusing on Lightning alone, sidelining returning characters from the previous games. The problem here is that Lightning isn’t a very interesting protagonist, her stoicism and little-to-no character development make for a pretty bland combination. As the story of the game continues, the focus does briefly touch upon Lightning and her relationship to previous characters. But fans especially aren’t going to be delighted to hear that most of the returning characters are also quite different from how they used to be – which isn’t that surprising since 500 years have passed but the game also doesn’t spend enough time on them to really justify that change.

Speaking of time, ironically for a game with a constant time limit, the story pacing is all over the place, with basically no progress until the final day arrives. The explanation for that is quite easy: Every day before the final day is exactly the same, no matter what you did before. Even completing main quests doesn’t have any lasting consequences until the ending arrives. Which means that the story is basically stuck or only moving forward in small steps until the last few hours of the game, where a lot of pathos is used to cover up the uneven build-up. And while the ending won’t disappoint fans, it’s also a predictable affair that’s not going to surprise anyone.

To conclude, [i]Lightning Returns[/i] is a game with interesting ideas (setting, time limit) but held back by some gameplay decisions (dull questing) and its messy story not making most out of the setting. It’s a game that should be just fine for fans of what came before – but unfortunately, it doesn’t manage to elevate/wrap-up the “Lightning saga” in any meaningful way.

139429110.review:
This game is the third and last of its trilogy, and different to the past two games in lots of ways.
In regards of gameplay, a premise is to be made -- You get 13 (or 14) in-game days throughout your playthrough. There are 5 main quests before you reach the end in order to unlock the final day, with its small dungeon, unique enemies and final boss. If you fail to do so, you'll end the playthrough prematurely and enter New Game Plus. The time limit and management gimmick can appear scary to some, but it is definitely not oppressive (especially considering the availability of the Easy Mode), as you can stop time over and over by spending points you get by killing enemies.
Monster species can be extinguished by Lightning, resulting in her facing the "Last One" version of it, granting unique loot.
Speaking of Lightning, she is the only playable character. In combat, you can swap between three Schemata (which are builds, with their respective equipment and skills), all of which have their separated ATB gauge. The building aspect of the game can be very entertaining, as you can influence the capacity and speed of the ATB gauge, upgrade skills (dropped by enemies or looted from chests) by spending other copies of them, and so on and so forth. This results in a much more interesting and entertaining level-up system compared to the Crystogen Points from the two previous games.
Combat is much more deep and entertaining than XIII and XIII-2. It is way more action-oriented, and each skill has unique traits to itself. One particular skill is even buffed and gets a new, better animation if you wield a specific type of weapon.
Throughout said 13 days you get to free roam around 4 medium-big open maps, each of which containing enemies unique to them, and lots of side quests. DLCs are included (some missing from the console version) and come in the form of exclusive and unique gear for Lightning.

Narratively, this game did not do a very good job. The presentation of the ruin of some characters' (caused by the ending of the previous game) is lackluster at best. This game means to make you feel characters were "reset" by the advent of Chaos, and it manages to do so, though it could have done it much better. On the bright side of things, Lumina, a new character, is introduced, and I consider her one of the best presented and written characters of the trilogy alongside Noel, Caius and Yeul. This game does not come with side novels to read as its ending is an ending for good.

As usual, graphics are good, soundtrack great, and the dub is also good.

As a PC port, while still being lackluster and poorly optimised, it is the best of the three, and very much bearable, with no third parties fixes (as there's no need for them). The console version is still obviously much better (especially considering the 60fps on Xbox Series X/S), but this PC port remains ok still, and has lots less graphics fidelity issues compared to XIII and especially XIII-2, thus I do recommend it.

As an entry in the Final Fantasy series, it's pretty obvious that many people, with even a passing interest in JRPGs or the Final Fantasy universe in general, have already bought it and tried it, simply by its name alone.

This leaves the very few "occasional" potential purchasers, that may not be completely informed about this game... and to them it's [i]extremely[/i] hard to recommend a game like this, because there are not two ways about it: the early hours of Lightning Returns are [b]devastatingly miserable[/b].

Upon starting the first run, the player is tasked with the objective of orienting themselves in a pretty peculiar world setting, made of 4 macro-areas that beg to be explored, while juggling a clock timer that forces a strictly objective-oriented gameplay style, all of this while listening to Hope and his machine-gun style of continuous expositions, the aural equivalent of an army of "walls of text".

The combat system, an attempt to re-purpose the paradigm-shift system of the first two chapters, to control the single character of Lightning, clashes with the controls seen in more "traditional" third-person action adventures: after a few tries, it's painfully clear that the system proposed here is far from intuitive, making "twitch" or strictly time-based moves way more difficult than they need to be, and is way better suited to macro-controlling a group of characters. Also, Lightning movement speed during combat is painfully slow, making quick re-positioning basically impossible via the standard controls.

To add insult to injury, having the difficulty settings labelled as easy/normal/hard does not help at all, as many new players will be tempted to select a "normal" difficulty for their first run, which is... uhm... [i]far from ideal[/i], as it introduces many unnecessary penalties to a gameplay experience that is already extremely challenging by default.

So, to sum things up, the quality of your experience with this game will strictly depend on your motivation to soldier through those chaotic first hours, master the peculiar combat system, and maybe even "survive" a few failures to reach the final day on your first attempts.

The prize for enduring those 10-20 hours of Chaos (pun intended) is a solid, albeit quite eccentric, gameplay experience.

As far as the story is concerned, I found the concepts presented here interesting, and competently aligned with the general "Man versus God" theme of the Final Fantasy 13 series.

Visual production values are very high, except for a few instances of bad texturing (oh, hello "desert rocks"), or some polygonal models that elicit ilarity (oh, hi "dog"). 

Also, the game really shines at 60 frames per second and high resolution, something that was not possible on PS3 about 10 years ago: the added fluidity is extremely noticeable during combat, and the high resolution makes justice to the stellar art direction.

The only downside to the graphics are the excessive particle effects during combat that, together with some unsolicited camera movements, make reading the state of the fight more difficult than necessary, especially when precise timing is required.

Music is an effective mix of familiar Final Fantasy 13 themes and new songs, and sound effects are flawlessy produced and extremely well done.

As far as this PC port is concerned, the game crashed on me a few times in a certain area, but saving is always available, so there's a workaround for that.

Also, controller vibration is completely absent.

Another slightly annoying thing is that you are limited in how many potions you can carry. actually, not just potions, but TOTAL CONSUMABLE ITEMS you can carry, period. you start the game with 6 max, and apparently expand it as you complete some missions or events. You also have some resource that you can fill by fighting called EP that you can use for some game mechanics like slowing time or even using them to get a full heal or in combat to extend the time u get to smack an enemy that is staggered and capitalize on the beatdown...........however all in all the things that you get screwed over for, the rush due to the lack of time, as well as the fact that you have to handle mobs all on one single character and be constantly aware of multiple potential enemies throwing ranged atks at you while you're trying to take care of this one mob because combat is STILL targetted at single enemies and you move SLOW AS HELL walking in combat really hurts.

I would've honestly prefered to have a ff mmo that allowed you to customize abilities and evolve them like this system can, except with free movement and aim-to-attack, and potential class changes like ff14 (because to my taste, ff14 combat is slow and a bit of a turn-off for most classes, especially melee ones that have to weave those boring ass slow auto atks

but yeah, the story and concept were interesting but implementation felt like they totally missed the mark. ff15 did a much better job. I may have rolled my eyes a bit at it because most of it was side missions, but at least in ff15 I am pretty free to explore and do as I want in any order I want, and can command my party to use active abilities when I need them to, and roam and look for loot and explore dungeon-like areas, something that none of the ff13 games really had that are staple exciting parts of RPG games.
ATM really looking forward to see how FF16 turns out after watching some of the early development videos and seeing the MC turn into a giant eidolon/ifrit and beating down other eidolons. It's not even about the graphics, it's about exciting development and capitalizing on a big moment to let the player take part in.

If you enjoyed Final Fantasy XIII and XIII-2, then you'll definitely enjoy Lightning Returns. It has a quality story, full of soul and suspense, which its predecessors shared. Even though it picks up from a completely different landscape, it links directly to the end of XIII-2, rather than just ignore it altogether. 

Combat is excellent, probably the best of the 3 games, with the ability to guard and have more control in response to enemy behaviour through schemata, rather than stuck in a list of ATB commands queued. Another improved element is the open-world aspect, which contains loads of locations and quests with a lot more interesting story depth to them. Upgrading your parameters (HP, Magic, Strength) is no longer done in the Crystarium through points earned from battle, instead it is from completing quests - making it more story driven progression rather than repetitive farming of repeating battles to grow. 
 
I enjoyed the linked story line and it's conclusion to the trilogy story, some detailed aspects might fly over your head, but overall it does the trilogy justice in my opinion. The game has a fast start compared to the slower start in XIII-2, and although some may find the constant time pressure of the clock irritating, I thought it gave the game even more urgency and story, regardless of the stress!

The only negative I would say is that the graphics seem to be inferior compared to the other two games, especially XIII. This is more in terms of cut-scenes, with XIII having such advanced visuals way before its time. The beautiful, high-quality music scores and impressionable characters return and are added to, real trademarks of the XIII trilogy. 

A great game to cap a brilliant trilogy, which I think is hugely underrated. They really did capture Lightning in a bottle ;) 
Rating: 10/10

134166331.review:
Much like Final Fantasy XIII-2 before it, Lightning Returns is a product of Square Enix’s early 2010s financial struggles. An effort to bring in as much money as possible by reusing many assets from Final Fantasy XIII whilst Final Fantasy Versus XIII (which eventually became FFXV) continued languishing in development hell & Final Fantasy XIV was gearing up for its big relaunch as A Realm Reborn. 

The interesting thing about Lightning Returns is that, whereas XIII-2 felt like a game built around its accelerated development cycle, Lightning Returns is a game that feels too ambitious for its own good. Whilst XIII-2 reused as much from XIII as possible & used the time-travel premise as an excuse to reskin both old environments from XIII & most of the few new ones multiple times & made minimal changes to the gameplay; Lightning Returns completely overhauls the combat to more closely resemble an Action-RPG, mostly sets itself in new locations & has an ambitious & risky new mechanic that required a lot of balancing work to get right (more on that later). 

Perhaps this is a byproduct of Motomu Toriyama, the director of the Lightning Saga, & his… passion… for Lightning (seriously, this guy’s love of Lightning borders on waifu territory) and a desire to give her story a happy ending & unforgettable sendoff. Maybe the XIII team as a whole wanted to stretch their legs & try some new things after XIII-2 mostly played things safe on the gameplay front so they could apply the lessons learned to future projects. Funnily enough, much of the team at Business Division 1 that made Lightning Returns would go on to develop Final Fantasy VII Remake & having played both games I can definitely say that game is much more of an evolution of this game’s combat than it is of FFXV’s combat. So you could call Lightning Returns’ combat a dry run for VII Remake (if it weren’t for VII Remake initially being planned to mostly be developed by CyberConnect 2 rather than by Business Division 1 themselves).

Regardless of the reasoning, the aforementioned overambition has a noticeable impact on the game’s graphics. The visuals noticeably take a step back from XIII & XIII-2, with the best-looking assets in the game being either reused from the previous two games or costumes for Lightning. The environments, in particular, look pretty bad for a game that was released for the PS3 & 360 in 2013 (The Last of Us & GTA V were released for the PS3 (and 360 in GTA’s case) earlier that SAME YEAR and look a lot better than Lightning Returns on the same hardware). The more wide-open Wildlands & Dead Dunes fair the worst, but even the more closed-off Luxerion & Yusnaan fail to meet the visual highs of XIII & XIII-2. These hits to graphical fidelity were likely a combination of having to create so many new assets in less than a year and a half that fit in the memory pools of the aging hardware the game was made for & Crystal Tools being pushed to its limits to make this open-ended design happen. To think this trilogy started by raising the bar on this front… It’s also worth mentioning that, like XIII-2, there are only three pre-rendered cinematics in the entire game (one at the beginning, one at the end & an unlockable post-credits scene). 

Going back to the combat, it’s probably the best thing about this entire game to be honest! As mentioned before, Lightning Returns utilizes an action-combat system with some turn-based elements like an ATB bar that’s very similar to VII Remake in it’s approach to mixing action-combat & turn-based combat. And for this team’s first attempt, there’s a surprisingly high skill ceiling involving timing, learning enemy attack patterns & maximizing the amount of stagger you dish out to an enemy. It’s a real joy to engage with & I’m glad that the dev team has evolved it into the system many people love in VII Remake. 
But perhaps the most unconventional element of combat is how you increase Lightning’s stats. Rather than doing so by gaining XP in combat, in Lightning Returns the only ways to get more powerful are through quests & the Canvas of Prayers (essentially a “Get X in exchange for power” system). While this is definitely a unique approach & I didn’t hate this (it’s especially great from a ludo-narrative synchronicity standpoint), I’m also glad that this concept hasn’t caught on in other RPGs (and that this didn’t carry over to VII Remake)...

Anyways, I’ve talked around it enough. Let’s talk about this game’s time limit, by far the single biggest & most divisive change made to Lightning Returns compared to the previous two games & the mechanic everything else about this game revolves around. Lightning only has 13 days to save as many souls as she can before the world ends, and the game imposes this deadline upon players as well. Each in-game day corresponds to around an hour of real-time (2-3 hours on Easy mode), meaning you have 13 hours (+ however much time you spend in cutscenes, conversations & combat, which pause the timer) to finish the game (26-39 hours on Easy mode). Oh, and at the start of the game, you only have 7 days and have to unlock the remaining 6 days by completing the main story quest chains.

As for my personal opinion on it, at first, I found the time limit very daunting. But eventually, as I played through the game (on Easy), I started to come around on the idea. Plus it turns out that said time limit is actually pretty generous, so an average player might be able to complete the game in one go once they have their head wrapped around the combat. 

Fortunately, the PC version of Lightning Returns is the best of the Lightning Saga’s PC ports. There is a healthier amount of graphical options than XIII & XIII-2 & the game is much more stable, less crash-prone and generally works just fine right out of the box. No mod manager is needed. There are some performance issues in certain areas, but never quite as bad as XIII-2 is out of the box & it’s clear that Crystal Tools was not designed for the kind of game Lightning Returns aspires to be.

Finally, let’s talk about the story. Going into this game, my expectations were tempered by the mostly negative reception to the story. But this is where Lightning Returns surprised me most. While the story isn’t perfect and the high degree of non-linearity can lead to things feeling disjointed, the overall story is pretty good, even if the identity of the main villain is pretty obvious after a few hours. I’d say the story is at its best when it’s exploring Lightning’s flaws & worst tendencies as a character and at its worst when it devolves into a bunch of fetch quests (looking at you Sazh). As a finale… It’s a good ending to the Lightning Saga, but it’s no Final Fantasy XIV: Endwalker for sure.
Conclusion
Lightning Returns is a very experimental game, an interesting choice for the for the finale of a trilogy (even if the devs marketed this as a “new experience”, the story is very much written like a trilogy capper), but I suppose a highly experimental & ambitious game that tries out a bunch of new ideas is a very Final Fantasy way to cap off a trilogy. Not all of Lightning Returns’ experiments are successes & even some of the ones that do work are things I wouldn’t want to see in every Final Fantasy game going forward, but I applaud the ambition of this team, especially when, given the context of this game’s creation & their company’s financial troubles, they could have easily phoned it in with a safe & iterative finale. But they didn’t and that’s worthy of praise (even if their ambition did ultimately outstrip the time they had to ship this game). 

It’s not a perfect game, at times it’s actually a pretty messy one. But it’s definitely my favourite of the Lightning Saga & I’ll likely do a New Game + run in the not-too-distant future…

Technical score: 6/10 (not bad for the time, but the PC port has some issues out of the box)
Business Practices score: 7/10
Overall score: 8/10

133703356.review:
[h1] Spoilers for FF 13 1 and 13 2 in this review [/h1]

FF 13 3/Lightning returns does a lot to fix what the last 2 games left behind. The first game was very innovative but had a lot of glaring issues, personally I hated the second game and the port was so bad it was a joke.

This game on the other hand is actually kind of good? And the port is more then acceptable? What a shock. I am genuinely surprised. When I saw this game had a time limit I thought I would hate it.

FF 13 3 is a follow up to the ending of FF 13 - 2, for the sake of this review I can't avoid spoiling the last 2 games because of how important the story is to the gameplay here, if you want to avoid spoilers for the first 2 games then just know I recommend playing those first if you even want to play this game. *LAST SPOILER WARNING*


After the horrible events of the last game Lightning has ended up in a crystal stasis. She is woken up by god and has been tasked with gathering souls, the world will end in a bit less then 2 weeks and god wants to recreate everything with the souls that you collect. This concept is incredibly strong and somehow makes the terrible writing from the 2nd game look slightly competent. 

So how do you collect souls? By doing quests, if people don't have any regrets they can open themselves up to you and you gain more power as well as more time for the world. This also means grinding has been changed and the primary way to get stronger is by doing main and side quests. When I mean quests you might think defeating some great evil, but most quests are pretty simple in structure and are things like doing fetch quests or finding treasure chests around the map. 

And this is immediately where this game shows its strength and its weakness. The core concept for the game is really cool and fun, the first like 20 hours of this game are a blast. You are pushing your speedrun skills to the limit to try and fit as much as possible in the time limit. The world is dying and everyone knows it, the places you go to are generally really interesting and super imaginative, a lot of it reminds me Nier automata especially in the music department (even if FF 13-3 came first). You can explore a lot of it compared to the last 2 games and the side quests allows you to get a deep dive into all the characters. The mythos that has been built over the course of the last 2 games finally starts to get pay off and seeing it play out is very interesting. In that sense the content that is here is strong....

But this is a Final Fantasy 13 game and for some reason these games always need to have a catch. I decided to play on Easy because that allows you to get more time and after how frustrated I was with 13 2 I wanted to get this over with as soon as possible when I originally started. I usually hate time limits in RPG's and wanted to explore everything the game has to offer. I was able to finish with like 8 or more days left with NOTHING to do. Even if I played on Normal im very certain I would have had 0 problems beating everything with plenty of time to spare (You can't change difficulty mid game). 

This game is just very lacking in things to do and it feels like they had to cut a lot of corners. Enemy variety is limited. Character customization and progression isn't very exciting and that is even more of a problem because you don't really have party members in this game. Side quests can be pretty hit or miss with some of them being fun and others just feeling like a waste of time. A lot of story elements feel forced in to make sure this is a proper conclusion to the story, this sucks because the story elements that feel natural are really interesting and engaging. The world looks a lot grimier, the set pieces are great but you can't help but notice the grime when the first game looked as good as it did. Lastly the time mechanic can be really annoying, oh you want to finish a side quests? Go wait 30 min or go walk to an INN and back to continue. There are too many time related blocks in the game and that can result in some really annoying moments.

Personally I also dislike the new combat system. This game uses a very similar system to the previous 2 games, but now you don't have a party so everything is a lot more dumbed down. Lightning gets access to a lot of powers and the combat has been made a lot faster. The stagger system also has been made a lot more confusing somehow yet the combat still feels much simpler in every other aspect. It almost feels like they wanted to go for an action game but decided they still needed to be an FF 13 game and they needed to use that combat system.

That doesn't detract from what the game does well. It still sounds fantastic and the world in itself is super interesting and open, the first 20 hours as you explore everything while being pressured by the clock are really magical. I love a lot of the personal scenes that make sense in the context of the overall story. I think it also somehow rounds out the story in a pretty satisfying manner. The combat is fast paced which means it usually isn't too much of a slog (me playing on Easy might have helped here). Lightnings movement is pretty fun and due to the structure of the world it can be really fun to just run around which is great because thats what you will be doing most of the time. There is a ton of voice acting and personality that has been put into even minor side quests, it helps breath life into this dying world.

And one of the biggest things I want to commend is that the port quality is pretty good overall. The biggest problems I had were that you would sometimes get stutters when it loaded in a new part of a city. But past that it runs great most of the time and the settings are decent as well although I would have liked more customization. Overall im glad I didn't have to mod the game a bunch just to get it started properly.

In the end, should you play FF 13/3? This game is great but it relies a lot on what the previous games built on. I highly recommend playing this game if you somehow made it through 13 and 13.2. I would even say its a must play in that case because it really makes both of those games a lot better. If you haven't played the first 2 games then I wouldn't recommend this game on its own merit. Its a fun experience and a great way to round off the FF 13 trilogy but I am really sad to see that so many cool concepts just end up feeling unfinished or rushed. Those flaws are a sad mark on such a beautiful canvas. For now I will say goodbye to this trilogy and maybe someday I will comeback to experience the new game plus experience and the harder difficulties.

- Right-click the executable, then select Properties.
- Switch to the Compatibility tab and click on Change high DPI settings, under "Settings".
- On the new window, under "High DPI scaling override", activate the checkbox: [✓].
- Select Application from the dropdown menu and confirm with OK.
- Click Apply, then OK on the Properties window.
- Launch the game.

To fix button prompts go to Settings > On-Screen Button Explanations > Controller Type. This should enable proper xbox prompts.

The game settings (and exit button) hidden in the corner menu: https://i.imgur.com/mpfCgRe.png
To access it you can either use the mouse mode of a controller or touchscreen (tap top of the screen).

131587503.review:
I came into this game without expectation, and oh boy. I am so so GLAD I played it while trying to figure out if the criticisms are valid. This turned out to be my personal favourite among the FFXIII trilogy. I can understand where some criticisms are coming from. As the FFXIII trilogy, in terms of story and game development, they are messy, and each instalment is so different. The trilogy can upset some FF (Final Fantasy) fans (nobody asks for XIII to be a trilogy) as the narrative is not as strong as previous titles, SE is milking this franchise too much and sets the pace that FF won’t likely return to turn-based combat in the future.

Let’s talk about what is meh about this game. 
The story, I would say just ignore it. At least it is not as confusing and nonsensical as the first FFXIII, when half of the time I didn’t know wtf they are babbling about. But it does bring great satisfaction to Lightning and her gang’s stories. Also, this game redeemed Snow. I never liked him, but he is actually pretty cool in this game. Unfortunately, they did a huge disservice to Sazh, AGAIN!

Resource management, in terms of time, gils and health. I wouldn’t call these a weakness, but it does make the game less enjoyable and pushed players away. Who thinks setting time limit is a good game design?! This game forces you to strategize. I had to read up on the side quests to figure out what time, day and location certain side quest-givers will appear so I can plan my day (game days) ahead and be more efficient. In the beginning, I was stressed about the time tickling, that I couldn’t properly travel around admiring the views, and unable to listen to NPCs and Hope’s dialogues properly. Then I failed the first side quest, “Wither Faith” which pissed me off. (This does motivated me to play New Game+) Then I discovered “Chronostasis”, the best EP (energy point) ability in the game. Once you’re allowed to spam Chronostasis, time won’t be your enemy anymore. If you plan well, you can finish all the main quests by Day 7-10. I do appreciate the limited-time element later as it does give off the apocalypse vibe which gave Lightning more agency not to diddle dawdle.

About the gil, the amount of gils the monsters (except Cactuars in the Dead Dunes) dropped is pathetic so you shouldn’t spend your money on most weapons, shields and adornments. Buy the garbs but if you are in Hard mode, ignore the new garbs (I only bought "The Duelist" for Hard Mode). In your first playthrough (easy/normal), save up your gils so you can buy the Hard mode-only weapons or shields, and upgrade your weapons and shields in New Game+. Unfortunately, upgrading in Hard mode is stupidly costly. Some of the best garbs, weapons and shields are dropped by some monsters, the main quests’ bosses (Chao’s Revenge is my MVP weapon), and the DLCs (Cloud’s upgraded Buster Sword in New Game+ is amazingballshit. Yuna FFX’s whole set, Yuna FFX-2’s shield and the sword, Brotherhood is my favourite sword of the FF series. I just keep Brotherhood for the aesthetic but in terms of power and bonus abilities, other weapons are better.) Also, I don’t recommend selling the misc items that the monsters dropped. You can use them for Canvas of Prayers. If you need extra gils, sell the sparkling items you randomly will collect while roaming around, or the extra abilities.

Now the good parts. 
Combat. I LOVE THE COMBAT. This is the saving grace for LR. It’s brilliant, fast-paced and surprisingly tons of grinding. At first, I was upset Lightning is solo since I am used to having party members and I do use them for moral support when we roam scary locations or fight hard bosses. I was wary about the schemata system since it reminded me of “FFX-2”. I don’t enjoy seeing another game with a “magical girl” feature in which the girl may end up showing a lot of skins or suddenly sings Jpop. Thankfully, most outfits for this game don’t make Lightning dressed up sexy. 

I personally love to grind, but this type of grinding is different from the past FFs. You do not level up by fighting tons of monsters. Also, it’s better strategically not to quickly extinct most of them before Day 6 as they will drop higher level abilities on Day 10 onwards. Thus, defeating more monsters does not automatically make you stronger. If you fight the monsters, it is because you want to study their patterns, test out your new schemata or restore EP. Staggering is the key to beating them faster and increasing drop-rate for rarer items. Magic like ra-spells is great for staggering. This game taught me how important it is to observe opponents ‘ movement, and timing and to guard. I am a button-masher player so when I guard and evade better, it becomes a game-changer. This game also switched my playstyle, which I will inflict some status ailments on all enemies. I rarely use status aliments like Poison, and Slow in other FFs, but debuffs become my staple. Imperil and Deprotect is my go-to debuffs. Debuff-ing and buffing (mostly by stealing the enemy's status enhancement) constantly is a must in Hard mode.

The game also lets you experiment so how it plays out, what schemata, weapons, abilities, and accessories become your favourite is highly dependent on your play style. In the past with the end-game, you tend to use the ultimate weapon. However, I like this game was designed in a way that you can pick your favourite to be the “Ultimate weapon or garb” and it is more evident in New Game+. I love the combat system so much and I want to fight better that I switched from a keyboard to a game controller. I highly recommend playing this game with the controller. 

My only complaint with the bestiary is, there is no Tonberry. :(
At least it gives us Cactair, the afro-haired Cactuar. That battle was hilarious.  

So how to level up? You do the side-quests, the other surprisingly pleasant elements of the games. I thought they are mostly fetch-quests, and then a few actually teared me up LMAO. (The Angel’s Tear, Bhakti) The side quests are split into two categories, the ones bestowed by the NPCs and the Canvas of Prayers. Do attempt most side quests by the NPCs (you need to level up enough for the final boss. “Last One Standing” in Dead Dudes can only be completed in New Game+, but you can use your first playthrough to prepare for it). The Canvas of Prayers is the fetch-quests so only do them if you feel like it.  The NPCs’ game models can look generic and silly, some dressing horribly stupid with hideous adornments. The best NPCs are the low-poly animals like the [url= https://www.gamesradar.com/why-i-love-this-dog-from-lightning-returns-final-fantasy-13/]dog [/url] and the [url= http://coldrungaming.blogspot.com/2019/08/ffxiii-lightning-returns-part-8-gem.html]cat [/url]. I died laughing. Oh, Biggs and Wedge are in this game!

Of course, the OST. People can bash the FFXIII trilogy all they want, but we all agree the OST never fails. I love that the soundtracks will adjust to the timing of the day, and some inserts of previous instalments’ OST are simply brilliant and got me emotional. (Blinded by Light with Snow’s battle, FFXIII-2 New Bodhum, Crazy Chocobo, Invisible Abyss (with one of the superboss! My heart melts) FFXIII’s Dust to Dust (Oerba’s theme))

And do start in Normal mode! Many recommend Easy but Normal mode is the one I feel that really forces you to manage your resources (health, gils, time) and appreciate the combat better since there is no HP regeneration out of battle.

Is the FFXIII trilogy still controversial? Yes, but this doesn’t automatically mean LR: FFXIII is a bad game. It's not the best FF, but this game has brought a lot of joy for me, Lightning remains as my favourite FF protagonist, and I still have hope for the future of FF.

Very fun game. I think this game could appeal to both someone who is a fan of the other XIII games and someone that did not like them. In terms of gameplay, it evolves from XIII-2 in a natural way. If you look at the three games in order, then the gameplay goes something like this. Party of 6 following a linear path -> party of 2 + monsters you recruit where you can explore alternate paths (timelines) if you wish -> Lightning by herself in an open world game. Despite the time limit, there is a sense of freedom and calmness that aren't really present in the other 2.  You are able to tackle the four main zones in any order you like (though there is an optimal order and you will naturally probably follow it). While the combat is fun, there are 2 main problems with this game.

The first is the difficulty. There's easy and normal (well, and hard after you beat the game) and I think most people will think that the game is too easy on normal. The game's difficulty is highly dependent on what order you do the zones even though you're 'encouraged' to take them on however you like. Now because there aren't really any levels, if you do them out of order you will find some of the bosses to be really hard, conversely if you do them in the right order, then the bosses become completely trivialized. They tried to account for this by buffing the bosses after 7 days worth of time (out of 13), but its not nearly enough because most of your power in this game comes from abilities. In terms of content, there is a superboss in the overworld and also a hidden endgame dungeon. Even accounting for this, this game does not have anywhere near the amount of content in the previous 2 games. With all that being said, the final boss is extremely well done and the difficulty is really well thought out. While you are able to get to the final boss without engaging with and understanding the deeper combat systems, I promise you will not be able to beat the final boss unless you understand the combat system.

The second main problem is the time mechanic, well not the time mechanic itself but rather how you interact with it. I think most people found the system to be annoying because you have to go into the settings and then go into your time abilities. You end up interacting with this system constantly because you have a time stop ability, so the added time to get to the menu is just annoying. If there was a quick menu where you can pull up your time abilities in real time, it would be a lot better.

In terms of the story. Its not that great, but its not insultingly bad either. If you want to appreciate the story in any way shape or form, then you really have to go into this game thinking that its not a trilogy and this is a standalone game. The story and world doesn't really make sense canonically speaking so you just take it for what it is. 

SPOILERS:  I think the story and character growth shown in this game really highlights some of the problems with planning this as a trilogy from the get go. Why is Lightning and Lumina's story arc shown in the 3rd game when it is so vital to Lightning's character? No wonder people think she has no personality. Then on the flip side, you have Sazh, Vanille, and Fang all pretty much being the same character from the first game.

With all that being said, the game is still fun and the music is good.

Un juego que comenzó como un rpg mayormente lineal termino convirtiéndose en algo completamente diferente. 
Luego de haber completado la historia casi por completo, si tuviera que poner de un lado lo bueno y del otro lado lo malo, la balanza se inclinaría hacia lo malo. Sin embargo fue un juego muy entretenido con mecánicas nuevas que nunca había probando antes y aunque no este del todo pulido fue una experiencia que valio la pena, y se puede ver en todas las horas que le dedique hasta el momento.

Comenzando por un analisis general: Es una idea MUY buena pero no se le puso el esfuerzo y cariño que debería, pudo ser mucho mucho mejor. 

Jugabilidad de batalla: 
Lo primero a resaltar es que cambia casi toda la jugabilidad con respecto a los otros 2 juegos, esto es algo negativo teniendo en cuenta que todos estábamos acostumbrados al sistema de combate anterior y cuesta acostumbrarse. Los roles desaparecen y solo podemos equipar 4 habilidades, eso no me gusta ya que con acciones tan limitadas hace que las batallas sean poco divertidas. Muchas de las habilidades magicas de daño como la ruina estan muy nerfeadas y no causan casi nada de daño por mas mejoradas que esten. Por otro lado, no tiene sentido que nos castiguen por escapar de una pelea. Y por ultimo, los controles para el teclado son muy malos, al menos pude arreglarlo configurando los botones de habilidades y acciones en el pad numerico para un manejo comodo. 
Hubiera preferido mucho mas que se mantuviera el sistema de combate que se nos mostró en el capitulo extra de Lightning vs Caius al final de XIII-2, ese sistema era Excelente.

Jugabilidad por el mundo: 
Algo muy bueno es que esta mucho mejor optimizado que antes y tenemos mas libertad para movernos por casi cualquier lugar con muy pocas paredes invisibles. El poder subir escaleras, bajar por tubos, saltar desde lugares altos, deslizarse por la arena, toda esa libertad de movimiento es muy agradable.

Ambientación, mapeado y detalles:
El apartado gráfico como siempre es precioso considerando los pocos requisitos que pide. Ademas el nivel de detalles tanto en ambientación como en el comportamiento de la gente es mucho mas vivo, complejo y llamativo que antes. Y banda sonora es hermosa. El único problema es que el mundo se me hizo pequeño, hacia falta una región mas en Nova Chrysalia de preferencia con nieve.

Historia y desarrollo: Es buena y a la vez no
Como dije antes la idea es muy buena pero el desarrollo es muy vació. Empieza bien, pero a medida que avanzamos se torna muy simplona hasta casi llegando al final. Tambien considero que hacia falta un nuevo personaje secundario o mas participación de los que ya conocemos (la cual es muy escasa). Si bien es interesante pudo ser mucho mejor.
Por otra parte la idea de salvar almas es algo que me encantó, pero hubiera sido mejor que las misiones sean mas complejas de completar, la mayoría son muy sencillas. 

Sinceramente no era lo que esperaba, pero a pesar de todos los puntos malos pasando el Dia 3 ya estaba enganchado y decidido a pasármelo.
El primer FFXIII lo destaco por su buena historia y XIII-2 es mi favorito tanto por historia como jugabilidad. Este destaca por su modo desafiante (en todo sentido), ya que el principal enemigo no es ningún villano ni monstruos, es el tiempo. La constante lucha contra el reloj y el objetivo de salvar todas las almas posibles hace que a medida que voy avanzando se vuelve adictivo, entretenido y hasta satisfactorio. Ademas poder personalizar los trajes le da un toque mas personal a la partida. 
Aunque le hizo falta mas desarollo a la historia, pulir el sistema de combate, mas variedad de monstruos, un mundo un poco mas grande y cosas como la toma de decisiones, actividades extra y demás no hay muchos juegos de este estilo y no esta de mas darle la oportunidad para concluir esta saga. 

Puntuación general: 6/10

Alright, I'm giving this game a thumbs up because it is one of the rare Square-Enix PC ports that run ok on PC.
Unlike the previous 2 FF-XIII PC ports, I can play Lightning Returns from start to finish without any random crash-to-desktop.
Although, I recommend using DXVK-Async with this game as well. It can further alleviate some occasional frame stutters.

And I am surprised at how much I enjoyed this game.
Because of awful experience I had with XIII-2, and some of my friends take a dim view of this game, I came in expected to dislike this game too.
As I played, it gradually became my most favourite in FF XIII Trilogy. And it is the only game in trilogy that I bothered to played a new game plus after I finished the game.

Here are what I like about this game:
[list]
 [*] I like that the game run relatively well on PC. Load time is fast.
 [*] Character control and movement, both in-combat and over world, are much better than previous 2 games. And that makes the game feels fluid and fast.
 [*] Character growth is not tied to fighting enemies.
 [*] Enemies spawn much quicker than previous games; less time wasting running around when you need to kill them.
 [*] Enemies are easier to avoid. I can just breeze through from one objective to the next and only fight when necessary.
 [*] This new style of action-based combat is very quick. Attack damage and defense are also based on timing, similar to Fromsoft games where you can do extra damage or perfect block by pressing button at the right time. It works like that in Lightning Returns too. And if you memorised enemies' opening moves and their weaknesses, you can counter those and finish the fight in seconds.
[/list]

Thinking back, I just realised that I played Lightning Returns like how I've played Saga series; run pass enemies to reach items/objectives.

Having said that, I don't think most players would like this game.
Just look at Steam achievement stat, at the time of writing, only ~29% of players managed to killed 100 enemies.
100 enemies are not that many by RPG standard. Normal encounters have, like, 2 - 4 enemies. So, it actually pretty fast and easy to earn that achievement without even trying.
This shows that Lightning Returns cannot hold interest of ~70% of players, and they quit playing at early game.

Lightning Returns gameplay is a far departure from any previous traditional Final Fantasy games.
The main mechanic of this game, time management, can be off-putting. This game has a countdown clock, and you have to complete 5 main quests within that time limit, or it will be game over.
When you play this game blind for the first time, it can be anything but fun, because you would have no clue what you should do or where you should go.
Many events, such as, shops, NPCs, quest availability, item spawn, enemy spawn, they all happen only at specific time based on in-game clock. And in-game clock moves fast; 2.5 minutes real time = 1 hour in-game. It's easy to miss deadlines for events if you are not careful.

Character growth is not based on EXP like in previous games. Killing enemies do not make you stronger. You will only gain stat increase by completing quests. And they are often fetch quests. If you don't like these type of quests, It's very likely that you will not like this game.

The game graphic is closer to FF12 than FF13. With exception of some main characters, most textures are low quality and pixelated.

In my opinion, Lightning Returns feels more like a spin-off than a sequel to a mainline Final Fantasy. So, it's understandable that many players would drop the game, since it might not be what they expected.
Personally, I would put Lightning Returns in the same category as Final Fantasy Type-0.

[h1]Almost 500 hours. I'd say money well spent.[/h1]


Lightning Returns finishes the FF 13 trilogy with a bang in the form of a race against the clock to save as many souls as you can before the chaos that was unleashed in FFXIII-2 destroys the world completely.

But don't worry, it's not nearly as stressful as it sounds. If you can't do it, you get to go back to the beginning and try again, with any items and gear and stats you may have earned previously.

It's a pretty neat mechanic - not my favourite, but that doesn't mean it's not worth your time. You start out with a few days to go before the end of the world, but as you progress through main quests, and even side quests, you can extend the life of the world and give yourself more time. Considering I could get most all quests done in 4 days in my speedrun videos, leaving 9 days free to do whatever you want, it's quite forgiving.

Some quests can be found early on, while others might only open up after a few days, or after main quests are completed. The reward is usually increased stats - a bonus to HP, Strength and/or Magic. There are a decent number of quests, but I do sometimes feel like it needed more minigames, something commonly found in other FF titles. 

It does have a few things to keep us glued to the screen. A unique system of extinction comes into play in this title that is perhaps not seen at all in Final Fantasy titles thusfar, where there are only a finite number of (most) enemies in the game. Ergo, it is possible to exterminate whole species of monsters, almost like a No Encounters reward, but the game makes you work for it. It *would* be a nice reward, but there are some minor exceptions to the rule that cannot be extinctified. No, that is not a word. But you get what I mean.

There are four distinct maps, and some familiar faces to encounter from past FF 13 titles. One strange thing I couldn't get my head around was the fact that they talk about the chaos being released 500 years ago, but in the last game it looked like it covered the world in an instant. Anyway, in this strange limbo existence, people don't age, which is why all your old friends are lounging around getting on the beers. 

Plot holes aside, the graphics are good in some parts, but lacklustre in other areas. Main characters tend to be passable (some even get new clothing!), while NPCs can be a bit on the cloned side. City environs have more detail, but things like the Dunes, or the open grasslands just seem like wasted space to make the game seem big. Even the cinematics are on the mild side, mostly all at the start and end of the game. Past titles, and I mean all the way back to FFVII, VIII and IX, there would be more, signifying significant plot developments.

Griping aside, perhaps one of the better parts of the game is what they did with the Lumina character. The way she keeps popping up to taunt Lightning is cute, and her similarity to Serah may throw the player into confusion, wondering if she is a friend, or foe, or just a psycho escaped from a loony bin (which was my initial reaction, seeing her prance around in a chaos infusion before summoning a Zaltys).

One factor that I've capitalised on is New Game+, which I'm sure I've done at least 20 times. After completing the game, replays are possible, as is changing the difficulty. This is really useful for things like farming more abilities, which can then be used for ability fusions, needed to make them stronger. Looking for missing garbs to buy, new weapons and shields to buy, not to mention upgrading both of those too. With so much customisation, all sorts of new tactics become available, allowing for lots of replayability.

Most garbs can be colour customised as well. And there are lots of pretty adornments too. There. I said it.

I must say though, not all of the outfits suit Lightning. There are a lot of skimpy, underwear-showing things that just don't make any sense given her disposition. Thankfully you don't have to use them. The Soldier garb from FFVII, together with special garbs from other titles are a nice addition and good fan service.


Despite all its little flaws that could have been improved on, I obviously still really enjoyed the game. I've made animated gifs of my waifu Lighty, video guides of some of the tougher monsters, and put in a lot of hours. I'm not a fan of gimmicky combat that requires things like perfect timing, but I got through the whole game, and hard mode, without having to worry too much about it. I think I just enjoyed the concept of turning Lighty into a goddess, getting to the point where she kicked everything's butt. 

Do you want to be a saviour? It's time to save souls and wear slick shades.

Pretty sure I read the game was in part inspired by Skyrim and it shows, it is 4 big areas with their own theme/environment and 1 character to save which are Lightning's friends that have their own issues making you do leg work in order to save their soul so she can take them to a new world god is building for them because reasons and this is the same concept for every side quest done btw. Lastly is the story or whatever this mess is, I can't say I loved the story of the trilogy so far especially after FF XIII-2 but I kept an open-mind and hoped for the best but I was not prepared for that. The quality of the port is good at least for me performance was good and I didn't experience crashes or bugs so at least there is that. Unfortunately my opinion about about how it should have stopped at FF XIII remains unchanged, it is a shame because some ideas are interesting but going through the game with the story and the time limit made it a slog for a considerable portion of my experience. Unless you are that much of a completionist and really need an actual ending and made the mistake of going through XIII-2 or perhaps you have the capabilities of completely turn off your brain when listening to the story I cannot recommend this game, it is not worth the time invested especially if you have not played the previous games in the trilogy. 6/10 average

[b]“It's not a question of can or can't. There are some things in life you just do.”[/b]

Oh Final Fantasy XIII...this trilogy gets way too much hate than it deserves but I digress...

The title of the game says it all. Lightning is back one last time as the main protagonist. In this game, she returns as the savior whose job is to guide souls out from the dying world and into the new one. The more quests you complete the stronger you get and the more souls you save. You're given a max of 14 days to complete all main quests if you cannot within the time limit then it’s GAME OVER. 

There will be a clock ticking at the top right corner of the screen pressuring you. At first, I thought this was a horrible mechanic because I’m the type that likes to explore and I absolutely hate being rushed but surprisingly the time limit gave me little trouble as I was able to complete all main quests with 3 days to spare. I used the remaining days to finish up some side quests. Looking back on it now I realize that the sense of urgency made the game all the more enjoyable and immersive.

People complain about this game being too linear but having a massive open world and a time limit is like giving someone wings and chaining them down at the same time. It just wouldn’t work so I could see why they went for a more linear path. There are a lot of returning characters which is always nice to see. Playing the previous two games is a must otherwise the story would be a confusing mess. Yes, the story is kinda out there and sometimes overdramatic I’ll admit, but I’d rather have that than a boring unambitious story. 

Unlike other Final Fantasy games, you don’t gain experience from defeating enemies. You can get occasional drops from them but you really have to focus on those quests rather than just mindlessly looking for battles in hopes of getting stronger. 

Lightning Returns was a hit or miss for some but I can applaud them for wanting to do something different rather than follow the same mechanic. Is it the best Final Fantasy game I’ve played? No, but it is still an enjoyable game with a satisfying conclusion. A decent entry into the Final Fantasy series. I loved Lighting as a protagonist and I was more than happy to play as her one last time.

First off: this entry is the only one in the trilogy for which the port is NOT full of performance issues and bugs. It's unfortunate that the previous two entries had enough technical problems that this point merited a callout,,.

Story: I was satisfied with how the story was concluded. Along those lines, I enjoyed the foreshadowing and questions raised throughout the side quests. There is a third quest mechanism that acts as a bulletin board of quests with just snippets. These (almost) all felt like fetch quests, and I didn't think added much story or enjoyment wise. In the grand scheme of things the story feels much shorter compared to the previous two entires.

Graphics: It kept the same design quality of the prior games, so I personally thought it looked great throughout.

Soundtrack: Part II's OST is still my favorite of the three, but it was definitely still a strong and fitting soundtrack.

Game Mechanics: All the cons I can think of fall into this category, so I will make a list.
- While the time mechanic was fitting story-wise, I was simply not a fan of it. You get a time freeze ability which is fueled by a resource dropped by monsters, so I was constantly fighting mobs simply to replenish this resource and keep time frozen as much as I could. In hindsight, it clearly feels like the game is designed so you end up doing multiple playthroughs to fully explore and succeed but oh well.
- The combat system from the previous game was was messily molded into an real time battle system instead of a turned based system. I honestly don't know why since I thought the system in the previous entries was unique and worked quite well. I would describe it as acceptable but it definitely felt like an unnecessary change and a downgrade from the system used in prior entries of the trilogy.
- Who thought it was a good idea to have equipment lock abilities to a specific key?! Having abilities tied to equipment isn't unheard of, but in this game it's locked to a specific slot (which in turn is tied to a specific key). This "feature" is incredibly annoying when switching between different setups since ability key mappings will get rearranged. In some cases the same ability on two different pieces of equipment might happen to be locked to different slots/keys... On that note, I thought the overall equipment / ability system didn't encourage too much experimentation. I quickly funneled onto certain builds / abilities early on and didn't have many changes thereafter as the game progressed. The only exception is the superbosses for which I used a more customized setup. 
- There were various other small game mechanic details that I similarly thought felt flawed but I won't go through listing them all.

Overall, I enjoyed the game and how it ended the trilogy, but I felt like I was fighting the game mechanics at times.
