[h1]Too Much of a Good Thing...[/h1]

[u]Spoilers for entire games story[/u]

[i]Honestly the only thing I can say after completing the entire XIII trilogy is why the hell was it a trilogy? It absolutely is a good story I'm not insinuating that it isn't but it was nowhere close to needing three whole games to tell it, I feel like two would have been perfectly capable of the task; The way they did it ended up exhausting me, I just wanted to see the god damn story by the third game's start let alone its end. And that's a TLDR on this review.[/i]

[b]Story[/b]
Like I said above the story is good, at some points even great; I'd say that XIII-3 certainly does a better job in the story department than XIII-2 does but it still has to deal with a lot of crap because of all the "time stuff" that its predecessor got up to. 
I also feel that the way they handled character development and story in the 500 years interim was done well and allows them to subvert player expectations and pull a "protagonists are antagonists" move pretty well without it feeling forced.
The only issues I have with the story would be that it gets pretty damn confusing a lot of the time and to enjoy it you really have to shut your brain off, also like I stated in the TLDR a trilogy wasn't necessary and it leads to the game being somewhat tiresome when played back to back with it's progenitors.

So I liked and hated the ending. It's a good and solid ending to the story of the world of XIII but sucked as an ending for the characters we care about; It was no where CLOSE to as comprehensive as it should have been, In fact I know exactly how it could have perfect and the answer was simple, Include everything they did but steal a page from Gurren Lagann's book and end with [spoiler]Snow and Serah's wedding, showing everyone reunited in the process. (of course without you know what happening)[/spoiler] Instead what we got was just implications that they'll all reunite. and WE DIDN'T GET TO SEE THE FUCKING WEDDING THIS REALLY AGGRAVATED ME!.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
So I'm not very fond of the gameplay this time around, I liked it in XIII and started to love it in XIII-2 but was surprised to see that XIII-3 wasn't using an ATB system but a completely new real time combat system; and not a particularly good one, In there attempt to create a "Final Fantasy" real time combat system I feel they sort of gutted a lot that could have made this great. The end result is slow and at times clunky battles that get really repetitive really quickly, Strategies almost always consist of [Identify elemental weakness] --> [Spam said element 'till stagger] --> [wack with heavy swing 'till stagger ends] rinse and repeat until done, notable exceptions are enemies that need to be hit within a certain time frame but a comatose monkey can do that. Actually the combat loop annoyingly reminds me of how almost every fight in FFX could be beaten with the same strategy, fuck that. They really should have just continued improving on the high quality ATB system they had in XIII and XIII-2 as I feel that would have improved the experience vastly.

The transition to an open world proper was well done and I have no complaints other than the performance while better than the abysmal frame rates of XIII-2 still chugs HARD whenever you move faster than a snails pace inside a city, at worst it puts strain on your eyes because of the inconsistency and at best can be ignored so whatever.

Now a big thing in the game, the Majoras Mask like timer system; This the game absolutely could have done without, It isn't that it prevents you from completing the game as I was able to do everything I could find with four whole days to spare. The problem is that it pushes this artificial sense of urgency that without context of how much time you REALLY have will make you just run through the game and never just take anything in like one tends to do with not just these titles but video games in general. but that's heavily opinionated so I'll just leave it there.

[b]Graphics and Soundtrack[/b]
Like XIII and XIII-2 this game looks absolutely incredible, from the texture work to art style it's all just so god damn beautiful and awe-inspiring. One of my favourite things (though this could have gone in gameplay) is the character customisation, While at times perverted and/or repetitious the vast majority of the available outfits (and there's A LOT) are incredible and allow tons of player choice, I would have really liked the option to wear a cosmetic outfit over your used one though as by the end the outfits with the best stats weren't the ones I liked.

The soundtrack is good... don't really know what I can say here, It isn't as good as XIII-2's soundtrack or XIII's for that matter and its best songs are re-used from the prior two games. I, having just beat the game can't for the life of me think of a single memorable original song from the game. just that I didn't "dislike" any of the tracks per se.

[b]Fin~[/b]
So yeah, I guess I liked the game, I recommend it but you have to really like the story of XIII and XIII-2 to not get bored by this point, try to grab it on sale and expect performance issues on average hardware.

[There's also a small novella that takes place just prior to the ending proper called Final Fantasy XIII: Reminiscence -tracer of memories- that you can read about online but it's not particularly important as all it really does is cement that everyone is in fact okay in the new world.]

This game has me a bit torn. 
Quick Preface: Overall I feel the sequels to FFXIII were unnecessary. FFXIII had its own satisfying and conclusive ending that didn't need to be expanded upon. That's largely why I disliked FFXIII-2 so much. It tinkered with an already good ending and made it more convoluted. And while the combat in FFXIII-2 was faster, I don't think it was better. XIII-2 tended to pigeonhole you into one or two specific combat styles; largely either because the fights were so easy they didn't require strategy, OR, they were so hard they forced you to be very specific about strategy. There was no in between and it didn't encourage expirementation. 

Lightning Returns on the other hand is probably one of the best combat systems in the entire FF franchise, and one of the best combat systems in an RPG period. It allows for a huge variety in playstyles and the combat is quite in depth with tons of different strategies to employ. The use of different schematas allows you to play with builds and assemble a set that all compliment each other. The only instance in which I felt a very specific strategy was required, was for the game's two superbosses, which are entirely optional. 

Story-wise it redeems the less-than-stellar XIII-2 plot and provides another satisfying conclusion to the series. Which again, I felt it didn't need to exist, but if you tasted sour grapes from XIII-2's story, this title fixes it in spades.

Overall, I actually really enjoyed this entry and it earned a place as one of my favorite Final Fantasy games.

BEING A SAVIOUR DURING THE END TIMES IS AWESOME

Just found out that normal mode is actually hard difficulty. I'm not afraid to admit that this is the first time I did not have fun of a game because of the difficulty. I rage quitted on every boss, made multiple saves to undo whatever I did wrong, and overall just not having a good time. And also my lack of knowledge in the game's combat system contributes to me not having a good time. 20 hours in, and I just want to stop. I thought, maybe I will never end this game in the future. But I kept on moving forward. Kept on pushing.

I broke my most sacred rule when playing a video game; searching up a guide on the internet. I usually gave this rule a pass on final bosses only. But I immediately open up a guide on the very first boss encounter (not the tutorial one) Oh how terrible of a sin I have committed. This game really drained the soul out of me. Immediate uninstall after reaching the credits. Feeling glad, I put down my controller. Sigh of relief. I have finally finished the Final Fantasy XIII Trilogy.

Despite being one of the most stressful game I have ever played, weirdly enough, I kinda LIKE this game. And planning on coming back to achieve 100% completion in the future. 

Lightning Returns: FFXIII is one of the most unique game I have ever played. Mechanics like the timer really pairs well with the overall narrative. In this game, you play as Lightning, the protagonist from Final Fantasy XIII, and also basically a saviour and prophet sent down by God to save souls from a dying world. You have thirteen days to save everyones' soul. And also the dying world have their time frozen, making everyone unable to repopulate, grow up, and basically become an immortal. A 5 year old will stay being a five year old no matter how much time, days, years, passed. Unable to grow up. Unable to die,

I love the premise of the game. Going down to the world of Nova Chrysalia every day and doing sidequests to save people is really fun. The aspect of how different people cope with the end times, or how it is being unable to die, is really very well thought out and crafted. All of the sidequests are fun to explore and never felt dull and fetch-questy like in Final Fantasy XV. The sidequests in this game are the core of the narrative and also gameplay. You won't level up and gain stat increase by killing monsters like other JRPGs do. You have to do sidequests, and each of them are very entertaining and memorable. 

The main quests are splitted in each region of the world. You can start whenever parts you want. Maybe start the one in the desert first? Or maybe the woods? (I maybe wrong in this) Basically there is freedom in exploring the main campaign although theres a time limit. (I'm lookin at you, Deadrising). Not linear and on rails like the first game. The downside of the main quests are you have to play the past games in order to get invested in the characters. Some character changes will leave you leaving kinda 'meh' because not knowing them. Well, this is the third installment in a trilogy. Make sense when putted that way.

The combat although I do not enjoy is very customisable and can provide various playstyle. Instead of doing the Paradigm System like the first two games, This game made a whole new combat system where you control Lightning and her three Schematas. Schematas are basically jobs and roles Lightning can turn into in battle. You can have Schemata that focuses on physical damage, one on magic damage, one on debuffing, and more. In this game you have 3 different schemata which you can equip abilities and switch to on the fly. Unfortunately, the game just displays text of the name of the skill and calls it a day. This means that it is very hard to see what you have equipped on the midst of battle. You might be reading this and thinking that it can't be too hard reading a piece of text to determine what skill you have, but let me show you alternative ways they game could have displayed the skills.

The game could have used coloured symbols of the attacks you currently have so that it is easy to glance at your skill list and know what you have equipped. Seeing a symbol is much easier to interpret than reading because you don't have to focus on seeing it perfectly to decipher it's meaning. Just seeing a general outline of a distinct shape and colour would be enough, where as with text, you got to focus on each skill name clearly to discern what you got. Again, this might not have been an issue, if the game wasn't an action game or didn't have you switching between so many different skill sets, yet the game fails to make gauging what is going on more difficult than it needed to be. It's like the game is going out of its way to make things difficult for you.

Some attacks are also too hard to see, like aero which is almost a semi transparent wind orb that is so small you got to be actively looking out for it when the game signals to you the enemies are doing "Aero" and in a battlefield with this much clutter you just end up spamming guard and hoping for the best. Speaking of attack signals, they are too inconsistent. Usually, the game will signal what attack an enemy is doing in classic FF fashion but sometimes that very same attack is not signaled and the enemy does it anyways. Like why have a textbox that announces the attack if it only appears whenever the game feels like it.

The polish isn't great as you can see, and this applies to the enemy design. There was one enemy that only did "rush" as it's only attack making you have to chase it up and down as it proceeds to do its only move, great enemy design. Also some enemies cast magic in such an unconvincing way, that if I hadn't seen the fireball coming out of their hands, I wouldn't have guessed they were casting magic. Enemy polish was not this game's priority. Yet what irks me most about the combat system is how passive enemies can be sometimes, feeling like you are just hacking away till they swing. It's obvious that there's a lot of baggage with creating an action game with the assets from two other games that were meant to be more traditional jrpg's but the hype, albeit small, that this game has conjured up is way overblown. If you can get over the Dead Rising-esque timer system which is very much designed for you to fail to achieve a perfect run on your first playthrough, the way this game handles combat with the engine actually manages to make it somewhat engaging, opting to let you customize what certain buttons do outside of combat per job instead of the previous system that made the autoselect the best combat option. Jobs and weapons are tied to specific costumes the player unlocks by completing certain quests, buying them, and if you're playing on hard mode there's even exclusive (but expensive) garbs. 

While the story is still just as overly convoluted as the previous two games, and I personally didn't find myself getting too invested in it, the pacing of this game offers players a reason to not really care about it as they stay hyper focused on managing their time and saving as many people as they can in the world, and in my case, getting my character as well built for bosses as quickly as possible. 

Probably look for it on a sale, If this game had just been "Final Fantasy: Time Crisis" and involved a different set of narrative characters, it probably would've sold so much better across the world, it really shouldn't be considered as part of the trilogy of XIII games for any reason other than it's narrative.

91154335.review:
Of the three titles in the Final Fantasy XIII Saga, Lightning Returns definitely reigns supreme. While the entire series is not exactly the most polished game series out there, Lightning Returns takes what we know about the XIII series and turns it on its head.

The story is unlike the previous two in that Lightning is solo (for the most part) through her journey. Your job as part time Savior / Demigod, is to help people accept their fate, help them with their issues and give their souls to you for safe passage to the new world. (Spoiler alert: The world is ending in 13 days [max])

The big kicker with LR is that Lightning fights by herself in this game (besides temporary companions). The battle system is no longer preselected Auto-fighting, but instead a very robust Schemata system. Similar to the paradigm system of the previous games, you get to switch between 3 separate garbs all with their own strengths and weaknesses. Each of these Schemata can have up to 4 abilities of your choosing, while some offer unique strengths with their "baked in" abilities. A great example of this is an early game garb you can obtain called the Mi'qote Dress. It provides you with excellent healing capability via removing debuff or ailments you might get hit with.

Each of these 3 Schemata you equip before battle can be swapped to at will in said battles as well. However, their is a caveat to doing so. Each of these separate fighting garbs/paradigms/etc have their own independent ATBs attached to them. So using them wisely in encouraged and mandatory. You'll find yourself switching often as each garb/paradigm that is on cooldown with regenerate ATB over time. While in one of your schemata, using abilities will drain the ATB gauge. Some moves drain more than others as is dictacted by their ATB cost (usually found attached to the ability itself.)

The game is based around a limited time / end of the world style exploration system. You have a finite amount of time to complete the main story line / do side quests, but don't fret. With each major main quest completed you extend and push out the remaining time you have by large portions. So, I wouldn't be too concerned with your time management / minmaxing every little thing you can do at every moment.

Another thing I should mention that is fun is this game offers what I like to refer to as an "extinction system". Because the end of the world is drawing close, there is little time for populations of monster to repopulate. This game actually functions on a dead and gone system. If you continously hunt the same enemy over and over, eventually they will become endangered and finally you will hunt them to extinction. Normally this might sound bad, but there are often huge ebenfits to hunting baddies to extinction. Namely, when you kill all of them, one final enhanced version of that enemy will spawn to desperately fight back. If you manage to kill this one, you will net (usually) an enhanced ability drop that they normally wouldnt have. Materials to upgrade your abilities to make them stronger, as well as a unique item on their grave. This could be anything from an accessory to a weapon. These are often some of the strongest one off items you will find in the game. So experimenting with what enemy to cause extinction on is very fun! (I recommend Behemoths, Skeletons, and Cyclops).

Well to wrap up this review, as I'm sure I'm rambling, the overall story and battle system are decent. There are four major areas you can explore all with their own major story lines, a ton of side quests, an effectively great battle system, and tons of NPC interaction (which the previous games lacked)

While I know people tend to shit on the FFXIII game series as a whole, this is definitely the prize of the bunch. Not to mention their are a couple uber bosses and a final dungeon hidden in the game that requires unlocking a secret day. 

Get it on sale, try it out, if you were on the fence you might find yourself enjoying the battle system to the point where you can make it through the entire game, and strangely enough Lightning actually gains a personality the more the story progresses. (A huge improvement from her previous games)

Good luck hunting those monsters to extinction! Also there is a fantastic Cheat Engine table if you would like a more relax playthrough that can freeze time, give you max stats, etc. (As someone who played the game originally and wanted to 100% this puppy, it was a godsend for certain materials I didn't want to farm!)

89685553.review:
Lightning Returns: Final Fantasy XIII is the conclusion to the 3 game saga, and is a much better port than the previous game, being more stable and less prone to random crashes, but still suffers from a lack of configuration, requiring a keyboard/mouse to exit when using a controller, and having majority of the keyboard controls hard mapped. Well worth a look for RGP fans and those who like the Final Fantasy series.

[b]Story[/b]
If you played this entry without playing the previous game you would be missing vast amounts of backstory (it’s more forced on the events of the second game than the first, however it does try to explain past events). The story continues on 500 years after the end of Final Fantasy XIII-2. Chaos has slowly eaten away at the entire world until 4 bastions remain. Within those area’s humanity is slowly dwindling away, with individuals who remain left burdened with guilt at the last 500 years of failures and regrets. Everyone lives in a depressive half-life, no longer aging, but not being able to start a family and still being able to perish by monster attacks and disease. Lightning is awoken by Bhunivelze, the god of light to free the burdens from those she can and carry forth their souls to the new world he is creating, with the promise of resurrecting Serah if she performs this task. The game heavily focusses on wrapping up events for the main protagonists in the previous games, and acts a redemption game for Lightning, though it is the darkest entry out of the 3 games. I found all of the major plot points were well thought out, and there’s lots of little scenes that have been added to the game as nice touches, like how Hope and Lightning reminisce if you start a new game plus mode.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
Gameplay has been significantly changed again, and there even less in common with this entry to the previous two games. I thought a lot of the changes were great, much like the previous game really transformed how you tackle enemies and quests. You are on a countdown much like Zelda: Majora's Mask with a full day/night cycle. Completing main story missions extends your available day count, while side quests extends the time fractionally and acts as your XP though some can only be progressed at set times. Each quest completion rewards you with additional health, strength and magic, making quests the primary path for upgrading Lightning’s stats. While you do have an option of freezing the countdown it isn’t infinite unless you keep fighting enemies, which only reward you with drops for quests or skills, and eventually run out - you can make majority of the in game enemies go extinct! You are given the freedom to explore any of the world’s 4 areas in any order, and the game itself is very non-linier, allowing you to progress as you see fit, though some areas are harder than others.

As stats are increased by completing side quests you don’t have to worry about how you are going to upgrade Lightning’s skill tree as its been removed (there’s no end game strategy to work towards). Costumes you purchase and find change some of your base stats (health, magic or strength, extend the ATB gauge or add other effects), along with the sword and shield she equips. There are accessories you can apply that add further buffs or immunities, as well one category that is for purely cosmetic changes. Physical and magic skills (offensive and defensive) are assigned to each costume setup, for a total of four attacks for each of the 3 interchangeable costumes you wear into battle. Each setup has its own ATB gauge that fills up when not in use, and each attack drains it by the used skills cost. It’s quite an inventive system, allowing for lots of customisation and experimentation.

The game is now a single player ARPG, with a few very limited team battles. Like the previous game enemies are shown on the screen in real time (there’s no random battles), and you can now easily engage or run away as needed. Battles are similar to how they were previously, however they usually require the correct setup otherwise can be very difficult to beat. The available enemy types have been drastically reduced to sub 50 types, and this fits into making that type of enemy extinct (it’s harder than it sounds to fight an enemy type enough to make this happen without purposely farming them). For maximum effects in combat you still need to stagger enemies to weaken them (which uses a different method now) then hammer home attacks while they are down. Fortunately, you can purchase their data before you encounter most of them making pre fight setup much easier and which advises their stagger conditions.

Crafting and upgrading has been changed again, with you merging skills that are dropped from enemies. This usually increases damage and can be well worth it for performing stronger attacks with the same move cost. Accessories are upgraded by collecting multiples (new game plus mode), and weapons and armour are available to upgrade late game with item pickups.

[b]Graphics[/b]
The graphics are the same as the previous two entries, and each area is its own self-contained biome, with a desert filled with tombs, 2 cities and open field & mountainous area as the games primary setting. Most of the enemies are reused assets from the previous game, though the landscapes do look good. Lightning now boasts increased customisation via the outfit system. If you want her to rock a cool pair of sunnies, party hat, or some other item you can - these follow through into combat and are only missing from the movie sequences. There are plenty of in game cut scenes, especially when finishing guests.

[b]Music[/b]
The voice acting was outstanding, just as it was in the previous games. Many of the NPC’s have quite depressing stories, however their lines are delivered with feeling and a sense of acceptance that nothing is going to change but nothing is over the top. More focus is on the main characters of the previous games, who show a lot more emotion and expression, but remain true to the characters they were in previous entries. The music score is great, featuring more percussion and having lots of the songs being tweaks of Lightning’s previous track or using it as a base.

[b]DLC[/b]
The included DLC features a host of different costumes, weapons and shields that can give you an early game boost. Nothing that’s going to break the game, but it’s nice its included for free.

[b]Achievements[/b] 
The game is easy to get 100% achievements if you know which quests to tackle, otherwise will require a few reruns to mop up.

As far as combat goes, this is not your typical FF game. But, let's face it, if you are on part 3 of FFXIII, you aren't a typical gamer. The combat is actually very similar to the worst parts of Elder Scrolls Online's combat (weapon switching, animation canceling, very limited spell/attack pool). Then, tack on blocking (it's a "spell", ugh), timing, and a bunch of resistances to discover and take advantage of and you have FFXIII-3. Oh, and there is essentially no magic based healing - it's very strange for a FF game.

Way too many particle effects, makes perfect blocking/attacking difficult (magic attacks have a cheese, physical do not). Forced camera angles during attacks exacerbate the issue. Very limited graphics options (most are on/off, no level of control).

The window is a wrapper for the game and the game doesn't have a built-in exit/quit. You must use the mouse to hover to the top of the window, this shows the menu, then you can go to File > Quit. It's a pretty pathetic port - absolute minimum effort on their part. If you are going to release a PC game, maybe play at least one or two - ya know, do some market research so your product isn't obviously below par.

From what I've read and observed, the game is pretty much meant to be played on easy first. The difficulty setting isn't so much about your skill as a player (you must have decent skill to even play), but it is more about your character's level. Although, this game doesn't have character "levels", so "stats and equipment" is probably more accurate. You may not even beat it on your first play through, if you go in blind. That's fine, just start again and keep going - it's a fun game and you will get another chance at understanding the story. You will get stronger and eventually beat it. Then, you can go up to Normal, NG+, etc and try for 100%.

The time of day stuff can be annoying at times, but isn't really a problem, even for a slow player such as myself. It fits into the story very well, does not feel tacked on, and doing side quests does not feel like I am going against the spirit of the main quest (looking at you, Cyberpunk 2077) - in fact, it actually enhances it, imagine that! It's also used to time-gate free drops at the start of each day, higher quality shop items, quests (of which there are 3 types: main, side, and canvas of prayers [which are basically fetch quests]), and such.

When you kill enough of certain enemy types, a "Last One"/Omega version of it will spawn in their place. Once killed, that enemy will never spawn again, anywhere - it has been extincted. I find this intriguing and it works fairly well. Most, but not all, of the enemies can be extincted. If you sell some monster parts, then 3 days later the canvas has a quest...you may not be able to complete it. So, be careful when selling items if you have extincted the enemy that drops it. This is the crown-jewel of the FFXIII trilogy, and probably one of the most overlooked games in the entire franchise. 

From the moment you start a new game, get through the first little tutorial section and are brought to The Ark at the final days of the world, that angelic song echoing in the background, you know you're in for something quite unique for an FF game. Lightning Returns: FFXIII is brimming with an almost-idyllic, yet apocalyptic atmosphere, that I have never seen replicated in any other game, even FFXIII-2, which obviously shares some themes with this one. I have never seen a game embrace this feeling of a looming threat of an apocalypse, mixed in with an eerie, beautiful acceptance of it, permeating throughout it's many hours of gameplay. It's almost like it's biblical, the player taking the role of mankind's savior, tasked with saving as many souls as she can before an inevitable rapture-like end of the world. 

The story of this game is fairly minimalistic, though grand in scope. It's the perfect closure to a pretty epic series, which, although had its' share of ups and downs when it comes to plot (among other things), remains as a very ambitious and emotional story. Better than XIII-2, but due to it's openness, way less focused than XIII. That being said, it's great to see how the old characters have changed in time, though I found the new ones a little lacking.

Gameplay-wise, it's definitely the best of the three - you have lots of freedom to experiment and settle on your preferred brand of combat. Though at certain points the game tends to be extremely hard (pro-tip: avoid fighting the boss of the main-quest of The Wildlands early unless you are REALLY looking for a challenge), and sometimes it funnels you to building your schematas in a way the game wants you to build, overall it's satisfying.

The music is absolutely perfect. Of course, being part of a trilogy, it will re-use some music from the previous games, but knowing the fact that the entire trilogy has an absolutely stellar soundtrack, this one does not disappoint in any capacity. The new songs (like the previously mentioned The Ark theme) are just as amazing. 

The thing I've seen people criticize the most is the time-management part of it, but I've never had much trouble with it, especially once you get Chronostasis and enough monster encounters to refill your EP bar all the time. In fact, going through the Yusnaan quest, I barely finished it with only several minutes of the day remaining, which was heart-pounding. However, in time, it's no longer a problem, and I completed pretty much everything one can complete upon first playthrough and had lots of time remaining to spare on grinding gil, so take that how you will.

Anyway, it's great, definitely worth a try, and don't let the crappy reputation of XIII stop you from trying LR. This game alone has made me appreciate the entire trilogy with new eyes, and I will be replaying it again. Solid stuff.

In my opinion the best one in the trilogy, but I am biased for Lightning. I am going to assume you've played the other 2 games, because if not, you'll get lost in the references and characters of past events.

Here, you play as Lightning and Lightning exclusively, if that's good or bad, that's up to you.

She is on a quest to save as many souls as possible before the world ends. This is done by completing fetch quests for them. Also Light gets stronger the more quests she completes, literally, her stats go up. Unfortunate thing is that these quests are not optional, because 1) you have to complete a certain amount to see the ending, and 2) some of them block you from going to important main story places.

There are actually several main stories, each returning character from previous two games gets their own, and again, you have to complete all of these to get the ending, where they all converge, and through power of friendship help you reach the final boss and end the trilogy. Overall, the story is not bad, but some side quests do have more interesting premise than the main ones...

Combat is a curious mix based on the previous two games' ATB system. Since Lightning is alone for most of the game, she has to fill all party roles by herself. For that reason she has three simultaneously runnnig ATB bars, each with their own moveset, that you are in a complete control of. And since there is no party, all buttons on the controller are assigned to one of Light's attacks, not to a menu. This makes for much more natural and interactive flow of battle. 11/10

The world you get to explore is the best of the three, in my opinion. It pictures the dying fantasy world swallowed by great void perfectly, and while you are limited to few locations, because of the great void, those locations are quite open to exploration. (Exploration is mandatory because of the quests, but who caaaaares.) Also it's set in completely new places.

One massive downside however. The time limit. According to the LORE, you have 1-2 weeks before the world dies. So there is a ticking clock, on your screen, all the time, to tell you what time of the day it is. And it even has affects what quests and locations are available.
If you don't finish the game in the given time, you have to restart. You keep your stats, but otherwise no progress. So all those quests you'll have to do again.

The game is very clearly meant to be replayed this way few times, before getting the ending, but there's nothing new in the new playthrough, it's just a waste of time. This is a misstep, no matter how you look at it. The only redeeming factor is that Easy Mode makes managing the clock significantly easier, so pick that if you need to relieve your anxiety.

If you've played FFXIII-2, you kinda have to play this too or live knowing you never reached the true happy ending. If you've only played the first game, and are somehow reading this, you have a choice. FFXIII is a more or less self-contained thing. It's only in the second game that things go way off track. If you abandon the saga at the end of FFXIII, I would totally understand.

78034671.review:
In my opinion, this was the best from the Final Fantasy XIII trilogy, though if you didn't enjoy the story in the other two, this one will not be any better. The true reason for fully recommending this one is the combat system, which is very different than the other two entries in the trilogy. In this game you play a one woman party the entire game with a few guests throughout. This time around, you have the four buttons of the gamepad that you attach an ability to use in real time combat. You have three different attires that you customize, and switch between them throughout the battle. It still follows the theme of the other games in terms of the class system that existed in the other two, but they are in the form of abilities. As a person who enjoys deep customization, this was a very welcomed change to find in this game. While this game varied from most of the final fantasy series, it was likely one of my favorites of all time in terms of the combat system in the game.

The complaint would be the rushing feel to the game, you are on the clock the entire game and have to be at certain areas at certain times to further quests and side quests, and that can become tedious. I would urge you not to be so concerned, as it offers new game cycles to allow you to explore any quests and areas that you missed in a previous run.

All in all the story, quests and overall rush feel to the game could be frustrating trying to manage your time, but the combat was really fun and made it a very exciting game for me. Even if you didn't like the previous games in the trilogy, this one is very different and very worth a playthrough; moreover, this is coming from someone who didn't enjoy most aspects of the other two titles.

77687844.review:
[h1]The Savior has Arrived [/h1]
Basic premise/Story

From developer studio, Square Enix 1st production department and directed Motomu Toriyama. With composers Naoshi Mizuta, Mitsuto Suzuki, Masashi Hamauzu. Lightning Returns: Final Fantasy XIII is the last game to finish off the Lightning saga. In the final installment, you play as Lightning Farron, who has awakened from her slumber by the mighty god Bhunivelze. Due to the events of Final Fantasy XIII-2. The world has been swept by chaos, and only a small set of islands remain of the last surviving humans. With chaos gone. Humans can now live forever without fear of dying from old age. Bhunivelze has tasked Lightning must save, as many souls as she can to whisk them away to a new world Bhunivelze has created for them. In the context of ‘saving’ as freeing them from whatever burdens they have. Lightning agrees as long as Bhunivelze holds his end of the bargain of reviving Serah’s soul. Her beloved sister. But, hold on. There’s a catch. The world has a time limit. And Lightning must save as many souls as she can within 13 days. What awaits Lightning on her journey to save as many souls as she can?

[h1] Far Beyond a Lightning Dress Simulator [/h1]
Unique Gameplay

You mainly play as Lightning. And while some may consider this to be a weak point. I think it’s also one of the game’s strengths where you have full control in her actions when in battle. The main battle system is the style-change active time battle system. Where you can change schemata on the fly during combat. Schemata are preset load-outs Lightning can change into up to 3 mid-way instantly during combat. 

One moment you may be rocking physical schemata filled out to the deck with heavy physical attacks. Then the next moment, you switch to a different schemata. This time a magic one. Weapons, garbs(the main outfit Lightning wears), accessories, shields, and four different abilities you can customize. The amount of flexibility is quite honestly very refreshing to switch different schemata on the fly. Considering each schemata has its separate ATB bar. A resource from which you can activate any of the four-button prompts for your abilities. 

The time limit the game operates can be quite stressful early on. And was one of the main reasons why I never finished the game after Final Fantasy XIII-2. However, after a couple of hours with the time limit constraints. It wasn't stressful at all. The game operates under 24 hours. You must complete the game by the thirteenth day. However, a nifty feature the game has is “Chronostasis” allowing players to stop time temporarily at the cost of another resource called EP. Or energy points. You can increase your maximum EP capacity by completing main quests. By the end, I had eight total EP I could use. And “Chronostasis” only needed 1 EP to halt the time. You can recover some EP by fighting enemies. Of course, fighting tough enemies rewards more than 1 EP sometimes. The game is pretty balanced in giving the player enough free time to handle the main quests and side quests. By the time, I finished 90% of the main quest and a great majority of the sidequests. And only six days had passed. So I still had seven days remaining. 

[h1] On the Edge of Crystal Freedom  [/h1]
The Graphics

Graphically, I found the graphics to hold up quite well considering it's one of the last generation games before the move to Xbox One and Playstation 4. The game ran very well on PC. And I found it to be very well optimized. The areas you visit and traverse in Lightning Returns are gorgeous. The different islands offering new environments and freedom to explore. You can enjoy the hustle and bustle of city life in the 1st area. Enjoy a more festival city on the 2nd. And embrace the wild open plains of the third with many flora and forests to tread. Or brave through the harsh desert dunes and rocky terrain on the fourth island. Visiting different towns and cities is densely full of people and NPCs to talk to. While not as detailed as Lightning’s model, they do a decent job in filling the world. It’s also worthy of note that certain people only show up at different times of the day. So you don’t see the same amount of individuals you come across 24/7. I love the different garbs you can collect and buy for Lightning as well as the large assortment of adornments you can try out. 

[h1]Different Shades of Lightning [/h1]
The Sound Design

The soundtrack for Lightning Returns is honestly incredible and diverse. You can hear random unique music from NPCs on the streets. A rich collection of instruments tackling different genres in the musical spectrum. Consists of a morning, afternoon, evening, and nighttime tracks for every island. They’re strangely soothing occupying different tones and backgrounds throughout each main island theme depending on the time of day. The soundtrack also has different variations of battle themes according to the islands you enter. The soundtrack has great variance in battle themes. Based on the location of Lightning as well as the time of day. 

[h1]No More Burdens[/h1]
Final thoughts/Ruminations

Overall, I found Lightning Returns: Final Fantasy XIII to be a fitting end for the Lightning Saga. It’s been a long road. Yet, in the end, I am very well content with finishing it. Enough, to even complete 100% achievements on my first playthrough as well. 

The world-building and how it connects to Lightning. I loved the way sidequests are handled here besides doing the obvious fetch quests and killing ‘x’ monsters. The struggles the NPC's face here is pretty reasonably sound, even when the world is about to end. There are different walks of life in the people Lightning meets and everyone has their share of burdens, she needs to tackle to save their souls. In some cases, these sidequests offer insight into Lightning’s thoughts, feelings, and character development while offering some foresight into her character. Even when you reload the game sometimes the in-game summary will change after you complete the main quest segment or a notable side quest that monologues Lightning’s thoughts. Granting the player insight into Lightning’s character. 

NPC's also talk about their daily lives when undergoing a sidequest giving context and how they need help from Lightning. In some cases, the quests may even unlock subsequent quests that are connected. And in other cases, two different side quests that have nothing to do with one another can converge creating a new branch of side quests to complete. Making it a multiple sidequest chain to undergo. I found each of these sidequests to be noteworthy to complete among other miscellaneous quests. Which gave me a good chuckle. While others dealt with harsher topics which I won’t spoil in this review. But, it's interesting with the world about to end in 13 days. The people Lightning meets have different priorities and burdens they need to be lifted. 

[i]
The last game in the Lightning trilogy reaches for the crystal zenith and achieves it. The combat system is one of the series best by far. Addicting, fast, and very enjoyable. The soundtrack is fantastic. It reaches the scope of different classic instruments then hits you in ways you didn’t expect with genres flying by that fit the game setting and atmosphere. The graphics I found to be well-done. Concerning the world design, animations, monster designs and Lightning's garbs. Ali Hillis's voice actor of Lightning deserves similar praise among other returning voice actors. The story by the end made me feel extremely satisfied to conclude the trilogy. Overall, I would wholeheartedly recommend this game only to fans of the genre or to others who have played the previous installments in the trilogy. A worthy finale. 
[/i]

77580252.review: My first review, and probably a pointless one since the game is so old, but I still feel obligated to write it. I loved FFXIII, even though I know a lot of people didn't. I thought the combat was absolutely perfect, and learning and mastering the system felt more rewarding than any other game I'd ever played, except maybe Rocket League. The story and characters were also great. I also really liked FFXIII-2, despite the combat changes, and found myself really caring about Serah by the end of it. Which is why (SPOILER) when she died at the end of the game, I had to play Lightning Returns to find out what happened. I got into it, and found out Lightning made a deal with God to bring Serah back. Great, that's exactly the type of thing I was hoping for. And then I find out the game has a time limit. And it killed it for me. I hate time limits. Especially because this game promotes exploration more than either of the other games in the series. I decided to give it a try, for Serah, but I just couldn't do it. I was way too stressed out all the time because of the limit, second guessing every single thing I did, wanting to reload previous saves if I took too long finding something. So I gave up on the game. I set it down for five years, and it was constantly hanging over me. I wanted to go back and finish it, but I just couldn't do it because of the time limit. Recently I decided to try it again and finally get it over with to find out what happened, and I'm glad I did. The time limit isn't a big problem. If you balance the side quests out with the main quests and manage your time well, you should easily have enough time. I had all of the main quests done by day 7, and did all the side quests I wanted to do by day 10, and just stayed at an inn for the last couple days because I had nothing else I wanted to do. The story was pretty good. There isn't a lot of plot, but what's there is good. Most of it is told through the stories of minor characters during their side quests. Some of them are really interesting and heart warming, and some are pretty pointless. In almost all of them though, there's way too much talking. It gets pretty irritating after about 30 or so. Hope also talks way too much the entire game, and none of what he says is useful. It's always just telling you things you already know over and over and over. If he actually said things that helped me out I wouldn't mind, but he doesn't. And nearly every conversation he has with Lightning is cut off by the start of a battle anyways. The combat system is okay. It's my least favorite of the XIII series, and definitely a big step down from XIII's. The schemata thing is pretty cool though, but confusing to new players. I never really knew what I should use. I didn't like the way you level up your attacks either. You get new attacks as loot, and then you synthesize them with identical attacks to power them up, then you use a stone to level them up. It was also confusing, and I didn't do anything with it until the final boss. It probably made the game harder for me in the long run, but sitting there trying to equip new attacks, looking through a list of like 75 things, with half of them being identical was just a headache. The final boss was also super hard, but I wasn't surprised based on how hard Orphan was in XIII. If you did enough side quests to power up, do the trials before facing it, and customize your schemata based on the fight, you should be able to get through it. As far as the port goes, it was just about perfect. It runs very smoothly, and I encountered no performance issues. Play on a controller though, it clearly was not made for KBM. Overall it was a good game, and a good way to wrap up the series, with a few flaws. 7/10

75613988.review:
LIGHTNING RETURNS...


     with a thunderstorm of controversy. 


This is a game I was convinced to dislike simply for what people have denigrated it for, and I must say, I'm pleasantly surprised. I love this game so much, and dear almighty Bhunivelze, help me give this game some sort of salvation with this review.


The final frontier of this derisive trilogy of games I have an odd affection for. Unlike the first game's insouciance to being explicit with its world-building or the second game's confusing timeline that somewhat falls apart under scrupulous scrutiny, this game's narrative is streamlined and focuses on providing a--in my possibly controversial opinion--rapt conclusion to the trilogy with themes that I've come to appreciate upon revisit.

The world these characters live in has always been an endless cycle of schism, classism, false gods, family, religious cults, sacrifice, changing fates (and way more than I can mention), and each game explored these core ideas in very fascinating ways.


It feels oppressive when the player and characters realize how unpropitious their efforts are. As depressing as that is, part of what I like about the trilogy--especially this game in particular--is no matter how hopeless everything can be, they empower themselves from familial love to heal from their past wounds and sinful scars to quell the Fal'cie who wants to perpetuate a world with worthless slaves by gifting them supernatural powers in exchange of eternal suffering. In the end, they create a new world, free from the binds of these false gods, and this game does an admirable job at coming to that conclusion.

 

The focus of the game isn't entirely on Lightning's desire to reunite with her beloved, deceased sister, Serah; it's the side quests and how it relates to Lightning's wish to reconcile with her sister. 

And this is where my love for this game starts to be apparent.



I love how this game allows me to explore and understand the people of this world who have to survive with the nightmare of being immortal, becoming apathetic, and scrounging for any sense of worth in what is perceived as a meaningless world. Some people, with asinine intentions, risk their lives for a sense of livelihood. They kill, act selfish, erase their memories to ease pain, and commit truly despicable things. Seeing all this through the lens of Lightning, who has lived a very depressing life, as she reflects on all the experiences she had before in tandem with every NPC's own struggles, followed by their saved soul to extend humanity's hope is such a visceral feeling.

The way she monologues to herself about how others cope with grief, loss, despondency, and hope for a better world, and sharing her own life experiences to fill people with hope is the main reason why this game resonates with me so much.

It threads Lightning's own struggles with her own poignant life as a mechanical and narrative progression in such an enrapturing way that I can't describe perfectly. I just have so much fun vibing with this game--none like any other. And it made me really like Lightning as a character, whom I feel is a misunderstood, excellent character.


Most side quests fall under fetch quests, and people can be impertinent about it, but that's not problematic to me. It provides more immersion to this world. People comment on your outfits/garbs, Lightning is hilariously aware of how ridiculous you dress her, and not all people are going to be kindhearted. This world feels very believable to me, and since half of the side quests are optional (unless you don't want to fight Ereshkigal by extending to the 13th day), it enriches the experience so much upon new playthroughs. The game executes these sombre, doleful underlying themes well enough, and it supplements the main characters of the trilogy.


Now Let's address the elephant in the room--the most polarizing, aggravating (or so they say) aspect of the game: Time management. 

In this game, you're against the clock, racing to bring salvation to remaining remnants of humanity and deliver them into the new world through the might of their god. At first, the clock felt pressurizing to complete quests and defeat enemies to increase your vitality, strength, stamina, magic, etc., and often, I found myself running amok clumsily through all of this instead of exploring the world. It... wasn't a good first impression.

But take my word for it; there's no need to panic. I learnt to cave out from my antisocial self and spoke to citizens to understand how the locations I'm in worked, discovering knowledge on how to find requested items. You have more than enough time to complete the game, and side quests are lenient if you make a mistake or miss an opportunity to complete it. On top of that, you can use chronostasis to save yourself time as much as you need to. I don't find the timer to be a detriment. It's all about being perspicacious and efficient. Not everyone can be saved, so you have to be astute with your decisions on the first playthrough. 

I love the sense of urgency the game evokes, but simultaneously, the game feels idyllic. The game never suffers from ludonarrative dissonance since your purpose as saviour is to complete those side quests and save souls. It makes new playthroughs replayable and interesting because you're constantly planning different strategies and schedules to complete this game's non-linear progression. 


The combat in this game is unbelievably satisfying--better than the first two games, even. Exploring a wardrobe of garbs and customizing an ideal set of schematas to stagger, obliterate enemies, and hunting ultimate versions of monsters called "Last Ones" for extremely helpful and powerful items is always an absolute joy. It's so enthralling how seamless it weaves into story progression and side quests because the more you fight, the more Eradia Points (EP) you earn, which helps you extend time as long as possible to complete as many side quests as possible. 

On higher difficulties, it's even more satisfying to preserve your usage of EP because you earn less and have to spend more for powerful attacks, such as, Army For One. There's always a risk and reward system, and it makes battles very tense, as you need to decide carefully on how you use your EP; otherwise, you'll be punished by losing one hour of your time on those higher difficulties. My only problem is how underutilized some of these garbs are. Despite my praise, I will not forgive this game for not allowing me to listen to Bluesy Chocobo (the first track you hear when you ride the Angel of Valhalla during your steed's first stage of recovery) after nursing him. 72234292.review:
(100% achievement run has been done)

[h1] Lightning Returns – What you read is what you get [/h1] 

TL;DR
Lightning Returns is far better than the first part of the trilogy. If you managed to have fun and got invested in the characters: This one is worth your money. Also play this game on easy for the first playthrough.

[h1] Was the trilogy necessary? (rant time) [/h1] 
The first FFXIII game was universally declared the worst Final Fantasy after it’s release (which is somewhat true. Only FF2 is worse to play through). And then we got a sequel that fixed a lot of mistakes which also had a plot that needed another sequel. And that is Lightning Returns.
And well… nobody really cared about this game. Nowadays I would compare the trilogy with the Star Wars sequels that did not manage to find an uniformly tone which disappointed the audience. The Final Fantasy XIII trilogy on the other hand suffered from a very bad first game wthat managed to destroy most of the audience interest.
So the trilogy was necessary from a narrative standpoint, but failed to live up to the expectations of the audience. If you want closure or just a fun game to play: this one is pretty enjoyable.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1] 
You have 3 slots for garbs (=clothing) and each slot can contain up to 4 abilities. You can and have to switch within battle to different garbs as every ability you use consumes points and they are regenerating the fastest when you are using another garb. So you will be constantly rotating through garbs trying to deal damage, block attacks and casting magic so that your enemy gets staggered (=vulnerable) to inflict even more damage.
This gameplay is very satisfying as you are constantly engaged and there are no down times fighting. It can become repetitive if you are fighting the same species of enemies over and over again, but finding out how to optimize your pattern is pretty enjoyable. The garb themselves also have a lot of impact in terms of customization if you really want to use everything the game has to offer. On the other hand: On any difficulty that is not hard you can use pretty much any garb.
The game can get quite challenging at times and managing your time is really important.

[h1] Story [/h1] 
This game is beyond throwing terms at you that make any sense. In short: World is going to end soon, god will wake up and create a new world for you and he promises Serah (Lightning’s sister) for your cooperation. 
Even shorter: You son of your mother, I am in ~ Lightning
(Bhunivelze didn’t like this).
Oh and after the events of XIII-2 500 years have passed and nobody ages, but people still die.
You have some episodic main quests that are somewhat interesting and reunite you with actually beloved characters of this trilogy that needed to adapt with the world around them and lived for 500 years too. There is some sincere heart to this.
But the best part are the side quests:
While often somewhat predictable, they are very wholesome and show how humans can deal with various problems of life. This is when the game really shines and Lightning actually develops something of a personality and relationships to other persons than the main cast. It is always more or less superficial, but Lightning now has bonds to treasure and reasons to be interested in the well being of the world. 
In short: Call me a rat, but I like some of these cheesy aspects.

[h1] Atmosphere and Worldbuilding [/h1] 
Not aging and dying for 500 years changed society and the population started to ask the big question:
What is the sense of living?
Lightning Returns portrays this beautifully. Starting to believe in a god, hunting monsters and adapting to the wild or just pure hedonism. There are many answers to that question and every person that lived for 500 years has developed an own answer which is really interesting to explore.

[h1] Graphics [/h1] 
The game is passable and not ugly, but at times I was disappointed, especially if you compare it to other titles of it’s time like The Last of US. The amount of pre-rendered cutscenes has drastically decreased and there are more in game rendered cutscenes. I actually like the more integrated approach and moving your camera while cutscenes are playing is a nice gimmick.

[h1] Music [/h1] 
At the worst of times the music is a little above average and just quiet in the background. At the best of times it reminded me of Nier:Automata which is a compliment I can not make often. The soundtrack is excessive and around 6 hours long. Every place of importance has it’s own theme and manages to encapsulate feelings and rarely a track overstays it’s welcome. The music and the sidequests are by far the best content of the game and listening to the soundtrack is recommended even if you decide against playing the game.
When you are finally facing the Final Boss… I like his theme even more than One Winged Angel which tells you a lot about the quality of the track. 
Not on the level of Dancing Mad but pretty similar.

[h1] The quality of the port [/h1] 
The port itself is fine, but can occasionally fail you. I had around 2 total failures and some mild annoyances within my playtime of around 60 hours.
LR also is a port from the PS3 era which means:
You will have performance issues despite having a high-end pc. Just bad optimization and trust me:
Square will not fix that.
It is really playable but it could be better.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1] 
If you played through the first two games and enjoyed them, you will probably enjoy this a lot more than FFXIII. I had a good time and while the mistakes and misdesigns are existent, the fighting can become tedious and some storylines could appear on cheese.com, but you are going to find something enjoyable. Even if it is only the dress-up game.
A well made ending for a not so well received trilogy.

Gameplay is super hard if you go in expecting to autobattle everything and win... indeed, there is no more "auto battle".  I'd been playing through the 13 series lately, and having just finished FFXIII-2 and seen the "true ending" in the included DLC, it seems they also gave a preview of the battle system in this game in that last fight, where you control only Lightning, and she has no Cure spells and a limited number of recovery items.

This is less faceroll/outlevel content FF, and more reminiscent of monster hunter/dark souls in terms of the kinds of timing skills one has to employ to kill even basic mobs.  Trash monsters from the previous games come back as real killers in this game for those not prepared to at least look at the Libra information on how to stagger each mob.

I like hard games, and this is definitely hard.  I think I'm about halfway through my first playthrough, and I'm enjoying it.  Definitely recommend *IF* one managed to play through the first two games, and that's problematic because FFXIII-2 is pretty unstable out of the gate, and a lot of people might not have bothered to get it running and be patient through that game's technical issues.

I really enjoyed this game. It was quite a change from the previous two 13's combat style. Having only one character under your control is different and makes for more challenging combat, as no one can bail you out. I wish you could walk around a bit quicker to create gaps as necessary, but you can move with abilities like in previous games, so a minor gripe. The garb system is really interesting. There are also many unique weapons to collect and stronger versions with new models available later.

At first I found the concept of limited time/days stressful. As I learned to manage the game a bit, it was not a huge deal, but it's a mechanic I could do without. I also found the limited time window for certain quest givers frustrating. By 60 hours and 8 in game days, having completed all but a handful of quests, I had my fill of the game and skipped ahead to the end to beat it.

One thing I found really irritating about this game were the timeframes. Hey, do this on FOUR different days, but you can't do it until 4pm. Or, sorry, this zone doesn't open until midnight, why don't you go do some other stuff and come back here. Or, this quest phase is at 10am, next quest phase, midnight.  It just seemed unnecessary. Overall, good game, and I enjoyed all three of the 13s. Definitely check them out.

Having been a fan of Final Fantasy games for a while, the 13 series is different. I was excited when they first came out; it was something new that wasn't on the GameBoy. The thing about these guys is that they have their own gimmicks. They all follow the active time battle archetype the company has created, however, it seems that with each iteration of the series, there is too much tweaking. Lightning Returns, in addition to being named poorly and unlike the rest of the 13s, changed too much. The voice acting is terrible, the emotion is terrible, the stereotypical storyline is predictable, and its exactly what you would expect. 

However, the biggest issue I had with it was the battle system. Maybe it's not for me, but I did not like it. Until about halfway into the game, I didn't feel as though I had an trouble. Then I got to the 3rd boss and had to start googing to get answers. The way they built up different paradigms in the past games have no relevance anymore. The stagger meter is gone and seems like an extra bonus. The perfect timing on attacks and guards was something I could never master and with hardly any feedback, will probably be something that most people won't. But the fact that the difficulty curve in this game goes from nothing to, "you won't win this fight even with max items" and there is really no reason, is disappointing. 

From having to grind the superbosses in 13-1 to needing to resort to 100% damage resistance to get past mini bosses in 13-3 here is incredibly unwelcome. But with that, I felt the game was either too hard or too easy. Not to mention the quests really seemed like gimmes; lackluster writing, basic fetch quests, and no substance. 

I wanted to play this game because I sunk time in the others and understood the story. I felt that this was easily the worst of the trilogy, which as a whole, set a pretty low bar. If you played the others and found them interesting for one aspect or another, then give this a go. It won't be the best, and you probably won't enjoy it too much, but it is an interesting take on the battle system and does its job. Otherwise, don't waste your time.

Judging the artstyle from screenshots this game really got me intrigued. Bought it on a sale and gave up after 4 hours. This may not be a long playtime for a RPG game, but those 4 hours felt like a chore.

First, the good things:
- Music is quite good
- Artstyle is good

Negative aspects:
- The combat is always only 1 on 1 and takes place in real time. You need to attack, cast magic and block  attacks almost like in a fighting game but slightly slower, all while watching different gauges deplete while you perform those attacks. In order for these gauges to fill up again, you need to change costumes with different abilities. With each costume the attacks, magic and the button-layout change. Sounds like there is a good strategic portion to the combat, but it's actually more confusing and boring than anything else. It takes quite some time to kill even regular enemies, too.

- You're constantly recieving directions, orders, background info and reminders from a boy called Hope via remote communications. Since this game has a timelimit, he CONSTANTLY reminds you to hurry up and finish the mission. Literally like every minute! Annoying beyond belief.

- The doomsday premise and time-limit aren't a bad idea actually (I also didn't mind such mechanics in Majoras Mask). The story (at least at the beginning of the game) doesn't give me the feeling I'm doing anything important in that world though! Lightnings orders are to save as many souls as possible. How do you save them? By completing sidequests of course! Like: get some medicine for a girls dying father (you need to get those rare ingredients one by one of course), or investigate a murder-scene. I never had the impression of doing anything meaningful while the world in this game was nearing it's end. Under the premise of a dying in-game world, those quests felt shallow more than ever.

And that's it. I tried to enjoy this game and even though my journey lasted only about 4 hours at review time,  those 4 hours felt like work. You're constantly in a rush. You need to learn the games mechanics, combat, lore, characters etc. as fast as possible. You need to explore and memorize the environments as fast as possible. You need to finish as many sidequests as fast as possible. During all that time, I never had the feeling of doing anything meaningful in this game.

69084238.review:
Long Review, No Spoilers

Final Fantasy XIII - Lightning Returns is the conclusion to the FF13 trilogy. So what's this game about? 
In short, you follow-up on the open end of 13-2, now controlling Lightning again, trying to save part of humanity from the end of the world.

13-1 was criticized for its linear gameplay. While I can relate to that criticism I still found that it was a good game (4 of 5 stars) and it was true to the aspects that I enjoy about the FF series in general (good combat system mechanics, semi-turn-based combat, controlling a party of 1-3 heroes, lots of side quests, weird story, good music, well-balanced leveling of chars).
I didn’t recommend 13-2 (see my review for more details), because the game left me empty and because it fell behind 13-1 in many aspects.


Moving to 13-3, let's just summarize the facts:
- the combat system is reworked again when compared to 13-1 and 13-2
- you play a party of one char for most of the time
- the general gaming mechanics have been reworked again – e.g. there is no leveling up your character with experience points
- there is a time limit imposed on you from the very beginning of the game, if you don’t make it in time, you cannot finish the game properly

While each individual point of the ones above could have been excused, the combination of all these aspects made me uninstall this game very soon (now switching to my subjective view on this):
From the very start, 13-3 feels like nothing fits together. 13-2 already didn’t really integrate its storyline very well with 13-1, but this one is worse: It doesn’t make any sense at all. It felt like three different people were in charge of each of the three parts. In the end, somebody was ordered to put all the pieces together, but totally failed his mission.

The paradigm and leveling system of 13-1 and its experience system was OK for me –it gave me the chance to develop my party in a direction I could influence and switching the paradigms during a fight “felt just about right”. This was worse in 13-2, beginning from the fact that there were no espers, you control only a party of 2 chars and your “pet”. 

In 13-3 even those aspects are taken away, leaving you to fight alone (most of the time) – this choice of the devs, I cannot understand.

Then there is the way the game throws its new mechanics at the unsuspecting user: From the very start you get bombarded with the full extension of the combat mechanics - which are quite complex. Granted, this was always the case (at least to some extend) for the FF series, but the game simply doesn’t give the player the time he or she needs in order to adjust to the third combat / gaming system in a row of the third part of the series: Staggering, (lots of) Garbs, Weapons, Items, Synthesis, Libra Lore, EP, special abilities – it all goes way too fast for my taste.


There is a saying that if something isn’t broken, one should not try to fix it. Why the devs chose to re-invent the combat / leveling system again is beyond my comprehension. 

All that would not have prevented me from playing and finishing the game I daresay. But the time limit does.

Whoever came up with the idea of imposing a time limit on the player in an RPG series where grinding is an essential step and it was never an issue before to rush the player, entirely missed the point.

FF is about story, taking in the details, exploring, looking around, searching for easter eggs / non-obvious content / side-quests and (an acceptable amount of) grinding for better stats / equipment. 

Enforcing a time limit takes all that away and puts the player under constant stress before he even has understood (much less mastered) the complex basics of the gameplay. I know, there are ways (and guides on the internet) telling you how to extend the time limit – theoretically indefinitely if you know how – but honestly: Does this really result in a benefit for the gameplay? 

Apart from that, it isn’t even logical when considering the story – why sleep for an eternity, then wake up and have only 13 days left until the world ends?

I stopped playing after less than 2 hours. Never did that with any FF title before and I really love the series and wanted to have a worthy finale for the trilogy.
That speaks for itself.

It also really makes me wonder if I ever want to buy another FF title, if the devs obviously have such a different understanding of what the series should be like compared to what I expect.
