As a devoted Final Fantasy fan since Day 1 (my pre-teen years) it's very hard for me to give these games a thumbs down, but this one I reluctantly have to. This is the 3rd and last game in the Final Fantasy 13 series, and basically extreme flip-flops the story from the first two: The world's end is near, Serah apparently is gone (again), Snow is now the big bad guy and anti-hero Lightning is the hero again. Oh, and Hope's back to being a kid.
The game makes it obvious from the start that it's the PS3 version copied to PC, but you do get all the DLC (costumes from 7 through X-2)  for free with one exception (you have to make a little progress in the game first). Like the first two games it looks and sounds fantastic, including in HD, with top-notch voice work and soundtrack. Where the game goes wrong for me is gameplay-you only get to play as Lightning (very rarely in FF fo you ever control only one character, which is part of the series' appeal), there is a totally new (and too complex despite its potential) battle system, and the worst part of all-the timer.  Basically game time moves at 8 times real time and you only have so many days-once all the days are used up, you go right to the end of the game. So you'd better enjoy being in a rush all the time. In an RPG I personally do not. Trying to complete all the optional side quests also gets tedious fast and is not fun. And if you just let the timer run out your game will be over in as little as 3-4 hours.
If you can get this on a good sale (preferably $10 or less) and want/need every FF title, think about taking a flyer on this, ditto if you want to see the 13 storyline through to the end. It's not a bad game on it's own, but as the final chapter in the 13 story arc, with each game radically different than the prior entry, this one tries too hard to be unique and it doesn't work. At least there don't seem to be any of the game-breaking glitches that plagued 13-2. In the end, I just can't recommend it except to devoted FF faithful.

68113933.review:
I'd say that Lightning Returns is probably the best of the FFXIII games.  That's not to say it's good, it still has issues, it's just not as bad as the other two.

As usual with the XIII games on PC, starting the game is a  fight against the idiocy of the port itself. The game defaulted to Japanese for voice.  Switching to English (which is labelled default while clearly not being the default) required a restart.

Do not turn off the Playstation(R)3 system while the save icon is being displayed.

I'm using a controller, so I set the prompts to display controller buttons before I start a game.  Prompts are shown in KB+M anyway.  Press backspace to attack. Press M to guard.  Press full-stop for Thunder. Presumably the entire KB+M button configuration was chosen by throwing a dart at a picture of a keyboard, since there is no logic to it.

Change the settings again.  Attack by pressing the 'blank placeholder icon we forgot to replace' button.  That's RB by the way.

The game begins.

The premise is that the world is ending, and it has been for 500 years, ever since the end of XIII-2.  Lightning has been chosen by God to save the souls of the doomed world so that they can be reborn in the new one that God has just put in the oven at gas mark 5 for 13 days.

You save souls by completing quests for people, only people who you complete quests for have their souls saved, so the new worlds population will be 66.  Good luck with the inbreeding on the new world.

You have 13 days to do your job, and the clock is always ticking.  At the end of each day, you give the souls to the tree of life, and you extend the end of the world by a bit.  The ticking clock puts pressure on you to do things quickly, and wasn't something I enjoyed about the game.  You can temporarily pause time by using an ability called "Chronostasis".  This ability costs 1EP to use. You have a cap of EP that can be extended by completing main quests, and you get EP as a reward for beating monsters.  

Small monsters will get you ~ 0.05 EP, a medium monster 0.2 to 0.5 EP and a big monster 2 EP.  Monsters can be driven to extinction, each has a cap of encounters, and once you kill them off you'll spawn a stronger "omega" version, glowing bright pink. Kill that one and they're gone for good.  This comes into play mid-game, where you're strong enough to kill the large monsters to farm EP and keep time paused with chronostasis, but don't want to kill so many of them that you can't do that anymore. You can't make everything extinct, a few of the mid size enemies will always spawn at certain times or places to keep the world populated with things to hit with your sword.

By managing use (spamming) chronostasis, the time limit never really encroaches on your game.  I had all of the main quests finished by day 5 or 6.  And by day 9 I had finished everything else I could do with the game, including killing the two superbosses and killing all the omega enemies.

Outside of main quests with returning heroes Noel, Snow, Sazh and Fang, you can do side quests for NPCs, and complete bulletin board fetch quests on the Canvas of Prayers.  Completing quests is the only way Lightning gets stronger.  Each completed quest will give you strength, magic and HP increases, or an extra healing item slot, or an extra EP. There's no XP, there's no crystarium this time, just incremental stat gifts as rewards.

You're on your own with combat in this game, Lightning gets no companions and has forgotten how to cast cure without using EP. So to mitigate damage you have a guard ability (and mediguard is the only free healing in the game).  Press it at the right time and you'll take less damage and maybe stagger your opponent.  The timing is tight, and the battle camera being total garbage hinders this to no end.  It's quite difficult to block attacks you can't see through effects and hidden behind Lightning's character model. You can press R3 to zoom out, and I'd recommend you change the camera settings to have this as the default view.

You can have 3 outfits (schemata) in combat, and each scheme can have 4 abilities.  All of them have Lightning wearing her battle panties. This is a drawback for me (the abilities, not the panties).  Having only 12 abilities at one time limits your options. One outfit will be your debuff one, one magic, one physical damage.  Late on I got fed up with blocking and specced my debuff gear with enough damage reduction that I was immune to physical or magic damage depending on which accessories I equipped on it. This kind of cheese is mandatory for some stronger enemies.  At least you aren't just mindlessly pressing auto attack all the time though, and you can do bonus damage by casting at the right moment to dissuade you from just holding a button to attack.

Several abilities I never tried because I just didn't have the space on my outfits for them. Most outfits even lock some slots to specific abilities (which you may have stronger versions of but cannot use). You can make abilities stronger, but in your first play through this is limited somewhat by the availability of the upgrade materials.

Staggering is a bit different compared to the other games. The gauge is now a wavy line that goes from blue to red to stagger, and the amplitude of the wave says how close to the next bit you are. It's much less intuitive. I do not like it.  Instead of I am at 60% stagger I am now at mid sized blue line stagger. Here's how to win in the game. Cast de-shell and de-protect.  Spam -ra spells.  That's it. -aga spells cost too much ATB to use enough, tier 1 spells are too weak. Once staggered, use strongest physical attacks.

So there it is, it's the best of a trilogy of totally mediocre/bad games.  It's inhabits the not available "meh" recommendation zone. In that case I've went for no rather than yes simply because I was pleased to have finally finished it so I could move on, and I never intend to play it again on new game +.

65175579.review:
[b][h1]A Disappointing end to the Final Fantasy XIII trilogy[/h1][/b]

[h1]What's it about?[/h1]
Lightning, the heroine of FF XIII and the goddess Etro's hand-picked chosen warrior of FF XIII-2 faces a crisis. She's failed to protect her sister, Serah twice and Etro has died, causing the world to fall into chaos. However, she is given one final chance to carry out a mission by the God Bhunivelze; In seven days, the world will end and she must save as many souls as she can. If she can do enough, she can meet her Serah. With the aid of Hope Estheim, Lightning sets off with renewed determination. 

[h1]The Review[/h1] 
And so, we come to the end of SquareEnix's attempt at a Final Fantasy trilogy (having done a duology with Final Fantasy X and X-2) and It ends not with a bang but with a “sigh.”

And its call because of the damn time limit imposed on you. You see you only (initially) have seven days to complete your mission. You have 24 hours to do as much as you can in each day. Sounds fine right? Well a) the time goes pretty fast to the point it can be a shock to the system b) Some quests force you to grind for items c) you will struggle if you don't get use to time management quickly. 

The time limit pressures you to be as fast as you can, not being able to go at your own pace, miss out on the sites and dialogue of the world and make you feel you're not part of the world but speedrunning a game and the trial and error compound the issue. Yes you can skip almost all cutscenes, but having to see the same locations again and again because you have to restart the game is maddening. 

The battle system feels less fun and more of an exercise on brain training and muscle memory and until you become one with the game, most battles feel tedious, especially boss battles afterthought. Many of the Outfits (via the Schemata system) will be unused due to a few being more than enough to get to end-game (which is a shame, because many have great designs. It would have been excellent if you could choose who the Schemata looks based on what you've collected.) 

The story of the game is okay. There are some nice moments but it tends to be very eye-rolling, with a ton of quests ending in the same tired-way, Aesops aplenty to the point it can feel like a lecture from a spiritual guru and it's quite hammy. Still the familiar faces are nice to see and hear and Lumina is a very strong character. 

Same goes for music, with a few catchy tunes but many of it falling flat or being unmemorable. 
Despite the huge criticisms though, there are some neat ideas in Lightning Returns and credit have to be given to SquareEnix to try something ambitious and different. Lightning Returns does run smoothly and there are lots of variation in terms of NPC design (compared to Final Fantasy XV, a graphically superior game) and  replayability is heavily promoted, with one achievement not available until you've done so. 

But it doesn't pay off. Again the replayability is a bit forced, some features aren't even available until you've completed the game (Want to upgrade your weapons and armour? Better finish the game!) and the tedium increases. 

Is this the worst Final Fantasy game? Well that's always debatable but there is a strong argument. But it's not the worst JRPG. It's a huge let down but there is fun to be had, and for those who love to be challenged and pressured into finding the best way to finish a JRPG, this maybe for you. But for those who just like to do so at their own pace with gameplay that isn't mediocre, you're better off looking elsewhere. 

[b][h1]Rating: 5/10[/h1][/b]

Note: Dear Steam. You REALLY need a "Maybe/Not Sure" choice.

Final Fantasy 13-3 es el final de una trilogía descabezada, su primera parte iba sobre el destino y el albedrío, su segunda respecto de las decisiones que tomamos y como afectan a los demás, y esta última sobre como el pasado nos liga y, a veces, nos encadena a nosotros mismos, haciéndonos difícil seguir adelante. Así descritos, sumado al prestigio de la saga, pareciera que como conjunto son una obra de calidad, sin embargo, esto es algo muy alejado de la realidad, elementos en común que unen a las tres obras son una dirección deficiente, una banda sonora solemne pero mal usada, una narración simplona de tratamiento malamente adolescente y mecánicas jugables muy sólidas.
Justificaré mis afirmaciones respecto de esta obra: se nos presenta una nueva historia pero con los mismos personajes, que viene a contarnos lo que de verdad movía los hilos en los dos juegos anteriores y por qué los movían de esa forma y no de otra, no obstante, pese a todo los personajes no han cambiado, siguen siendo ellos mismos en un nuevo mundo, con cambios mínimos y sus mismas motivaciones, lo que genera agotamiento y rechazo, pues sus motivaciones no son interesantes o comprensibles (a excepción de un caso pero no deja de ser cansino). 
La banda sonora es una remezcla de los dos videojuegos anteriores, nada mal la verdad, y ha sido usada de mejor manera según las necesidades del juego.
El nuevo sistema de combate es divertido, es una nueva visión del visto en FF X-2; el sistema de gestión del tiempo es fresco y motiva a explorar el mundo que se presenta; ambos elementos funcionan.

Ahora bien, no recomendaré este videojuego por fallos graves que tiene: los dos primeros mapas (de un total de cuatro) están incompletos, es más que evidente la falta de pulido y glitches que arruinan la inmersión. Sumado a un montón de misiones de recadero más o menos obligatorias que son aburridísimas. Al igual que FF 13, este producto se empieza a poner bueno cuando llegas al mundo abierto y la historia empieza su arco final, sin embargo, a nadie se le dice que pruebe un juego bajo el argumento de «ten paciencia las ocho primeras horas, luego te gustará», siendo que hay otros (dentro de esta misma franquicia inclusive) que enganchan desde los primeros minutos.

62479625.review:
Warning bells should start when you look at the title of the game. Not FF13-Lightning Returns as you'd expect and the reason why I think this was done is that this is not a Final Fantasy game. 

At their core there are very common themes and style which thread all of the FF games together. Strategic team combat, complex character driven narratives, varied enemy types, frequent boss battles, world exploration and plenty of choices to make ranging from what quest to take on first and what characters to have in my team, to where should I go next and what kind build I want for my characters so they work well together. Now I'd expect some of these things to survive even the most poorly designed FF game, but somehow they lost ALL of these things and I suspect they knew this due to the FF13 moniker being a sub-title.

This can be a plus for some players who don't like the FF formula and it would have been a smart move had Square actually made a genuine effort to come up with something fresh for the studio. But LR-FF13 falls flat on it's face in many, many areas. The time limitation itself isn't a major problem, but it isn't an appealing feature at all and doesn't add anything to the game. It also becomes a hindrance as you're motivated to skip through dialogue and cut-scenes due to time constraints. This is the start of the anti-FF formula features as any narrative becomes secondary to just getting the quest done. It also discourages exploration of your environment but since the game consists of only medium sized 4 regions you're not missing out on much. You'll spend more than 6 hours in one city running fetch quests and facing a very small selection of the same enemies over and over again. The grind is very real.

The team building is completely absent since you control only Lightning herself who has somehow gained the ability to instantly swap between 3 costumes. You put these builds together yourself using a mixture of garb, sword, shield and 2 accessories along with 4 abilities but that is it. The limitation to 4 abilities per costume feels more like Pokemon than it does FF.  The game makes you feel like you're struggling to deal with Lightning's limitations rather than playing the 'saviour' of reality. Choice in progression is also gone entirely as quests decide what stats are boosted rather than you choosing this yourself.

The story and the visuals arent much better. LR-FF13 dangles only 1 carrot to act as motivation to continue - the identity of the girl who looks like Lightning's dead sister. This is not a spoiler as this character appears in the opening moments of the game. This is your singular motivation to keep pushing forwards and frankly it isn't appealing. Square has slipped back into the uninspired and tedious storytelling of the original FF13.

Visuals are a dire patchwork of amazing and horrendous. Stand Lightning next to any NPC and you'll see a dramatic difference in the quality of the character detail. With the exception of the main characters all of the enemies and NPCs look like they were recycled from whatever Square had in their archives from the PS2 days. The world itself has blurry textures on one surface and then detailed on something nearby giving the world an unfinished look that is distracting enough to ruin the experience of playing the game. 

Square cut corners or were on such a tight budget that they had to settle for 'good enough' so many times that it resulted in one of the worst games they have produced. Avoid playing this at all costs!

Amazing game and a nice step from the traditional battle systems for previous Final Fantasy game. The world is actually really great. 4 main areas for the story-line and the game doesn't take too long to play.

CONS -
  -  Many complain about the protagonist and the general story-line. 
  -  New players may struggle understanding the time constraint concept on the first playthrough. Especially when trying to get objectives completed.   -  Some might hate the new battle system of this game
  -  Some hints of repetition on later points (primarily for 100% playthrough's)
  -  Due to being a direct port of the PS3 version of the game, the game can run horribly on some systems. Even one's that should be able to handle Lightning Returns 3 times at a single moment. But bad ports is something Square is sort of known for *coughs* FF13-2 *coughs*.

PROS - 
  -  World/maps are very large, helps waste some of the time you have in the game going from place to place.
  -  I feel that the battle system is really in-depth despite seeming simple.
  -  I personally feel the story-line is good, however a few of the main characters in the game could've used some improvement.
  -  The Steam version comes included with ALL of the DLC that the Xbox 360 and PS3 versions had minus the Aerith DLC. For some reason that was removed. The DLC equipment can be helpful for new players to get a foot in the world.

¿Quién me iba a decir a mí que una experiencia de fin del mundo encarnando a Lightning iba a ser tan buena? Soy el primer sorprendido, y es que esta última aventura de la trilogía de Final Fantasy XIII la protagoniza de nuevo la hermana mayor. Vemos como va evolucionando a medida que completa secundarias y avanza por la historia principal, sintiéndose muy satisfactorio la forma de finalizar los hilos argumentales que había ido dejando la saga. Puede que no sea a gusto de todos, pero a mí me ha parecido una excelente forma de acabar lo que desarrollaron en XIII-2. Creo que consiguen con acierto hacerte sentir que estás viviendo el fin de su mundo, mediante la evolución, los diálogos y el temporizador, lo cual es muy positivo. Eso sí, tampoco tiene que alarmarse nadie, hay tiempo de sobra para completar el juego y hay opción de new game+ para acabarlo al 100% para quien quiera hacerlo superando los mayores retos que ofrece.

En lo jugable, es sorprendentemente divertido el añadido adicional de acción al sistema de combate de FFXIII. Pese a manejar solo a Lightning, no se siente escaso pues podemos personalizarla muchísimo. Tiene infinidad de "trajes" de los cuales hay que seleccionar tres  que llevar activos con diferentes bonos y la posibilidad de cambiar entre ellos en combate. Puedes asignar cuatro habilidades a cada uno, lo que otorga gran variedad de estrategias para todo momento. 
Este título tiene enfrentamientos muy desafiantes, y la única forma de prepararnos para ellos es equiparnos de manera inteligente y formular una estrategia adecuada para los combates según las debilidades de los enemigos. Aquí no se puede "farmear" para subir nivel, y para desarrollar las estadísticas de Lightning es obligatorio completar misiones, cuya recompensa son dichos aumentos. Hay muchísimas tareas secundarias, algunas con mejores historias y otras más simples, pero la mayoría son interesantes de vivir y la protagonista suele sacar conclusiones sobre cada experiencia relacionadas con su propia actitud y conflicto. En lo personal, este juego me ha entretenido tanto que en ningún momento me ha parecido tedioso realizar sus tareas secundarias, todo lo contrario.

Obviamente imprescindible para concluir el argumento de la trilogia del XIII, unas entregas de Final Fantasy mucho mejores de lo que se suele decir. Concluyendo: recomendadísimo.

61645564.review:
This is a brilliant conclusion to the Final Fantasy XIII trilogy.

While the trilogy itself is among the less popular Final Fantasy titles, this one is probably the most challenging and interesting of the three. Just, do yourself a favour and get a strategic guide because it is an absolute nightmare with always-impending failure without it!

Pros:
- Final Fantasy!
- still looks gorgeous
- innovative
- an interesting story that wraps up all the events of FFXIII and XIII-2
- more varied battle system: you still have only three battle stances available at the same time that you can rotate between, but they are way less rigid and constricting than in its predecessors. You don't rotate between classes but simply "dresses"; each has some specific abilities, but you can personalise each dress with abilities, armour, weapons and items, allowing you a great deal of flexbility and potentially hundreds of personalised combinations

Cons:
- impossible to complete without a strategic guide: if you run out of time, it's game over
- only one main (i.e. playable) character, which is abnormal for a FF and greatly limits characters' dynamics, which have always been one of FF's strongest suits
- occasionally confusing (especially if you have not played its prequels, but that is to be expected)

I would say that the pros outweight the cons, so I would recommend everyone to give it a try!

60041871.review:
Ultima entrega de la trilogía del FF XIII por fin da punto y final a su historia y lore, después del enorme final abierto que te deja la anterior entrega. 

El juego abandona el sistema de formaciones por un action rpg interesante y sencillo de aprender, donde puedes moverte a tu antojo (lento, hay que decirlo) donde puedes bloquear a voluntad, moverte para esquivar ataques y atacar al monstruo por donde quieras. Se le añade el sistema de Arquetipos, que es muy parecido a las vestiferas del FFX-2 o muy por encima a los oficios de los juegos antiguos, donde cada uno tiene sus fortalezas, debilidades y habilidades exclusivas, también hay una gran variedad de armas y equipamiento donde se nota mucho la diferencia con su uso. Algo que no me convenció es que no mejoramos mientras combatimos sino completando misiones. 

Los mapas ahora son mas mundo abierto, con tiendas y asentamientos, aunque siguen sin ser muy grandes sigue siendo infinitamente mejor que los pasillos de la primera entrega. Solo hay 4 zonas y dos de ellas son ciudades y las dos aceptablemente grandes donde tienes que ir usando viaje rápido o el choboco para poder explorarlo sin que se te acabe el tiempo. 

Respecto al tema del tiempo contrarreloj, aunque en principio puede echar para atrás, no es ningún problema, cada dia dura aproximadamente una hora de juego, pero usando la Cronoestasis puedes alargarlo sin problemas, empiezas con 6 dias que son ampliables hasta 14, pero yo he completado casi todo el juego al dia 7 llevando mas de 30 horas. 
Gráficamente es el peor de la trilogia, las escenas CGI están geniales, pero el modelado de personajes se ven muy anticuados, los entornos las texturas se ven feas si te fijas bien e incluso algunos detalles de los arquetipos cuando hay escenas. Y el ángulo de cámara durante las conversaciones es un desastre, la mitad de las veces ni enfocan la cara del personaje ni de Lightning. 

El lore sigue siendo interesante, aporta bastante y se conoce al dios creador de todo, pero no meten ningún personaje nuevo, algunas misiones principales son algo sosas. Y algunas misiones tienen horario especifico, algo que a mas de uno no le va a agradar. 

Respecto a lo técnico, el port está bastante bien, mucho mejor que el XIII-2, va a 60 fps estables en casi todas las zonas, no hay tirones y se ha eliminado el launcher. 

En mi opinión un gran juego, continúa con la fantástica historia que tiene el XIII pese a tener la lacra de la jugabilidad de la primera entrega. Aunque que te guste el final de la saga es ya cuestión de cada uno….

56206183.review:
I realized that in my old review I didn't talk about the game. Like at all. So here's a spoiler-filled review of the game.

Pros:

_Basically everyone has their character arcs reset back to the beginning of 13. Most often I hear this as a complaint, but in this case I think it works. Sazh is still trying to save Dajh but this time he lost his heart when his dad got depressed. Snow wants to rescue Serah and is a dumbass while doing it. Fang wants to save Vanille. Vanille still wants to save everyone. Lightning is still Cloud Strife, but with a vagina. Serah is still the driving force behind Lightning's motivations. And Hope is a robot puppet chosen as the Avatar of God himself. The plot is messy you basically rehash every story beat of the first two games, but this time as Lightning and you see the events through a different set of eyes. It takes my biggest complaint of the first two (that the viewpoint wasn't from the main character it was a 3rd party observing them) and makes the story about Lightning's reactions to the situations. It's like that time you found your old GameBoy and played Pokemon Yellow all over again with the knowledge of how to crush your enemies. You enjoy solving the old problems from a different perspective.

_I'm like one of 6 people who really liked the dressphere system in FFX-2 so I really enjoyed that they streamlined it and brought it back. Kinda disappointed that the two female led FF games entire battle system revolved around clothes, but that's another discussion for another day. Each of the equipment parts give you stat bonuses. You have three different parts: your clothes, your weapon, and your shield. I really enjoyed that the sets were varied enough to allow me to go with the raw power of a set bonus or mix and match for a general boost to all stats. In this game there is an ultima weapon (as per usual) and it pairs with your starter armor, which up until that point was the weakest and worst armor and it's the sword you break in the opening scene. Once repaired it gives you a cheaty +2000 stat bonus to all your stats. It makes the final boss (God) go from impossible to manageable.

_I thought the timer was interesting. It made me flashback to the days of Majora's mask and frantically run around collecting everything and doing things for people to save as many of them as possible. In the mode I played I was able to finish everything in the story, and collect 100 souls to get the secret ending, in like 7 days on my first try. It took me doing several quests at once for 2 in-game days to get them all done. Unlike other games I've played with day/night cycles, the clock always ticks. 

_Getting to know people in this game felt really good. I liked the NPCs in this game. Most of the time I just fast forward through fetch quest dialogue boxes and go do what the mission summary says, but in this game the NPCs had this charm. Maybe it's the fact that you have to save everyone and those who you don't save just disappear from the universe forever. So you kind of feel a responsibility to these people.

_Small plus here. Everyone still has their old Paradigm system and uses it in battles against you, but Lightning has a whole different system. If you look close enough you'll see above their heads the old modes like Ravager, Commando, Synergist, etc.

Cons:

_As I said earlier in the story section. The plot is a mess. Sometimes actions don't make sense. Like Noel for some reason decides to team up with the bad guys despite secretly being a good guy, tricks everyone into thinking he's hunting her, just so he could later go on to lure Lightning into their hiding place, and not help her destroy the bad guys. Snow tries to hold the Chaos inside him to prevent it escaping into the city, despite learning that relying on others is a good thing in both of the previous games. Vanille is tricked into being the mouthpiece of a group that wants to destroy all of the Chaos, which is dead souls unable to pass. Her character was never really setup to be the gullible one. In context the game breaks so many prior established rules and just kinda handwaves it away with the lukewarm explanation that it's because they've been suffering for the last 500 years. Like cool story bro, but I've never had that experience so I'm not sure if that's a believable reaction to that much life.

_The entire desert area was just so mind numbingly boring that I don't really remember much except that it was stupid that Fang wanted Lightning's help to get Vanille away from the group mentioned in the last section. So what does Fang do? Immediately send you on a series of fetch quests that end in you meeting her face to face. What's her explanation? She had to prove that it was really Lightning when all it took was them meeting face to face. I Just wanted to mention this in its own section because I found it to be the worst example of this game's plot.

_There was a lot of fan service from the other two games in the form of characters. Even Chocolina made a comeback, but I like her story so I kind of give that a pass despite her sudden appearance in the second game.

Conclusion:
This game has a lot of flaws, but it's fun. That's about all I had to say about it. So if you have read this far, you're an awesome person. Keep being awesome.

And that's it!

Lightning Returns. The final entry of the most bestest Final Fantasy trilogy, took way too long to reach PC, around a year-ish after XIII-2, in fact.
 
That turned out to be a relatively good thing, as the last part of the trilogy finally got a competent port. Not great, but it actually runs smoothly at the advertised 60fps, and not the weird framerate carousel that the last 2 entries had. Options are relatively sparse, and the ones that do exist are brought up in a row menu on the top of the game window, which is a bit weird, and rather unwieldy if you're rolling with a controller.
 
Storywise, it's pretty much XIII, so you better have retained the lore knowledge, because there's more of it, with certain things mentioned in passing on previous entries becoming important or even pivotal to the story. The writing in general ranges from ok to utterly stupid , with special mentions for the sidequest with the girl and her missing father, and the ending. Actually, I'll just say this about the ending: [spoiler]I hated it, and it's [b]France's[/b] fault![/spoiler] ... and [spoiler]Kitase's[/spoiler].

Gameplay wise, you play as the one true goddess who must never be forgotten, Lightning, and as no one else. The world is, again, free-roam, mostly similar to XIII-2, but without the time travel shenanigans. The real shtick this time though is that you can configure sets of costumes that work as a sort of classes, which you can switch 3 of freely during battle. Most of the rest of the battle mechanics are pretty much taken from the rest of the series.
 
Lastly, sound & graphics: BGM is, once again, pretty good, with a decent number of mainstay tracks. No Heavy Metal Chocobo, though.
GFX though....I already talked about the options, but the graphical design in this game is just so ugly. A VERY noticeable downgrade from XIII and XIII-2, with the game having the gall to put models of dogs and cats that used to be background props (and look like they were doused in Vaseline) front & center in a decent number of sidequests.

So, the TL;DR: Port is good, music is good, GFX is terrible, story is.....heh. I recommend this one on the basis that you've already played the other two and want to finish the trilogy. And that you don't mind [spoiler]having France ruined for you after finishing the game.[/spoiler]

53597773.review:
The finale for the FF XIII trilogy. Story wise, it attempts to make sense of everything that happened up to this point and wraps up the cliffhanger that was FF XIII-2. It also has a nice feel-good ending that left me satisfied although a little sad that it was coming to an end. However, for people that didn't care for the story in either FF XIII or XIII-2, the story here will not impress you.

As for the gameplay, I believe this is the best version of the Schemata system yet. It's much faster paced and plays more like an action game than it does a RPG. It's how the system should've been from the beginning! Unfortunately, besides the open areas where you can run around and accept quests, that's all the gameplay you'll get. There's no mini-games and little variety in the quest types. It basically boils down to "go here, talk to this person, fight this, go back and talk to this person, fight again, etc." I don't want to downplay the effort that went into making these quests though as mostly all of them are voice-acted and come with their own stories.

As for loot, every armor and weapon has its own unique model which does make it fun to play dress up with lightning sometimes. Each armor comes with it's own abilities and aren't interchangeable so some armor will be practically useless from the get-go and some others are pretty ugly. It would've been nice to be able to put the stats of one armor onto another but alas, it is not possible. I will also mention that certain armor pieces are vastly superior to the rest in terms of potential defense and offense. I won't spoil which ones are, but if decide to play keep an eye out in armor shops and play around with the various outfits, abilities, and accessories and you'll find some pretty OP stuff.

Lastly, I'd like to address the time mechanic in the game that puts most people off from the game and is understandable. In this day and age where a lot of us struggle with managing our own time in reality, having to time-manage in game is stressful. But I can assure you that the game gives you more than ample amount of time to beat every quest. If you use the Chronostasis ability in game which pauses time for a short while, you can beat all main quests and a majority of all side quests within 4 in-game days. Depending on how many quests you bother to do, that will leave you 9-10 extra days to do whatever. Unfortunately, like I mentioned earlier, there's no mini-games so you'll be spending those extra days doing a whole lotta nothing except fight monsters to extinction, literally. So take your time through the game and don't stress about the time. As long as you aren't standing around doing nothing letting time burn, you'll easily beat the game.

TL;DR: Decent ending to the FFXIII trilogy. If you beat the first two, you'll enjoy this one and you owe it to yourself to finish and wrap up the story.

50596774.review:
A truly great RPG left in obscurity from its relationship with the other two Final Fantasy 13 games. Lightning Returns serves as the final chapter of Lightning's story and possesses some of the most experimental gameplay of the franchise. While adding a time-limit within the game has been a controversial aspect, it's done extremely well and while many call for it to be removed. Doing so would completely ruin the type of experience offered. 

Every aspect of Lightning Returns is built around its 13-day system. From side-quests only appearing at certain times to all enemies in the game having finite numbers and slowly getting stronger the longer they stay alive. What could have been a creative mess has been fleshed out in such a way that I didn't think Square would be capable of. Making it easily the most open and well made in the trilogy. Players are given so much agency to complete tasks in the order they would like that everyone's play-through will be slightly different.

Combat is much tougher than the previous entries; but due to the customisation options each attack and spell is far more useful. This is true for side-quests and optional tasks as well, as each completed task improves Lightning's capabilities. Which becomes important for beating the more difficult main quest missions. While time management may seem daunting at first, there is more than enough time to complete every quest if you're careful. 

The soundtrack and art-style are sublime as always. While the world of Lightning Returns is a broken one, the atmosphere is just as captivating. NPC's going about their daily schedules such as: Going to shops at various times, heading back to their homes during the night, etc. Makes each moment just that bit more engaging. 

But the plot at times is just awful.

Story beats are confusing and given little explanation. Many cut-scenes are littered with nonsensical dialogue and a barrage of bewildering twists. By the end of this game you will know what has happened, but barely have a reason why. Even some previously established rules set in the other games are arbitrarily ruined in this sequel. While certainly not everything, it must be noted how far the narrative has declined since the first game. 

But, overall. If you have kept up with the 13 saga up till this point, this game is absolutely worth your time. Even if it can be a little stressful and difficult at first. The port is actually pretty good as well.

Lightning Returns is a third game in Final Fantasy XIII trilogy. And i must say it's probably the best one but still far away from older Final Fantasies.

So as you already understood from the title, Lightning returns to save the world. It has a pretty good story but sometimes it feels too serious. You meet characters from the past games, one of them (Hope) being your helper who gives you guidance from another dimension. Lighning this time travels in time to prevent the end of the world.

Gameplay and the world is where this game differs from other two.
First, this is probably the first FF game where you don't have any party. Lightning is alone through most the game. Although you can have a non-human companion. Can't say i liked it, but to my surprise it was better than i expected. I still would've liked having a full party consisting of other human characters.
Combat is much more action oriented and is almost hack'n'slash type of combat. You need some reaction to block enemy attacks and attacks and other actions are very fast. It makes the combat more intense but sacrifices some tactical elements like using magic, potions and skills. They're still there but combat is nowhere as deep as it was in FFIX for example.
You'r companion is a Chocobo you meet later in the game. He joins you when you take care of him and become friends with him. This whole quest was really great. speaking about quests. There are lots of them, i think no previous FF game had so many side quests. There are not only hunts, but traditional rpg quests (yes fetch quests too) where some person asks you to do something. It was a nice addition and most of those quests where pretty good and fun to do. You'll need to explore every inch of cities and villages to complete them.
What i liked more about this game compared to FFXIII is its openness. It's a semi-open world game and there are cities and villages finally. There's a lot of explore and uncover, you'll probably spend most of the time doing side quests.
The world is pretty big and locations are beautifully crafted. From a big alive city full of people living their lives to plains to a desert. It has everything. I really liked the world, it's so much better than previous two game, a huge improvement.
There's also weapon crafting. You get materials from doing quests and can craft/enhance new weapons to fight stronger enemies to get better materials etc.

Now what i didn't like. Time limit! Why? For what reason? It's Final Fantasy for fuck's sake. I hated that and i turned it off. Without the time limit game became so much better. I get it, Lightning has limited time to save world but i rather prefer that time would advance after you finish the chapter and you could take as much time doing quests in a chapter as you like.

Graphically the game is a real beauty (considered it's a PS3 game released in 2014). Locations look stunning, cities are big and full of little details and npc's. Be it forest, desert, ravine, dungeon, everything looks great and there's no feeling of reused assets again and again. I hate that. In some other games wherever you go you see same textures, same color palette, same assets, you can't even tell one dungeon from another and if not the different layouts you couldn't tell. Fortunately this is not the case in Lightning Returns.
Performance for me personally was good although it could've had more graphical options. But considering the price, that it's a PS3 port and it's made by SE i was very satisfied.

Music is good as always in Final Fantasy games. Can't it was something exceptional but music never got old and some songs were really great.

Overall a very solid jRPG (although it's very westernized so is suitable for any rpg lover). It's still not a full-fledged Final Fantasy game but it's a huge improvement over past two games. If you love rpg's, beautiful worlds, nice stories, strong characters you should definitely buy it. Kosmo recommends.

[b]Pros[/b]
[list]
[*]Has improved a lot
[*]Lots of side quests
[*]Beautiful world
[*]Strong characters
[*]Good music
[*]Looks great
[*]Action-like combat is pretty fun
[/list]
[b]Cons[/b]
[list]
[*]Time limit
[*]No companions
[/list]

Best game in the series.  It built upon the last two fantastically and started off with an interesting premise that everyone's been alive for 500 years unable to age or die from natural causes.  That theme fit well into the main quests and even most of the side quests that tend to explore stories within that theme which made them interesting.

Pros/Cons
+ They keep track of who you spoke to unlike the second game.

+ Lumina carries any scene she's in and her voice actress was amazing.

+ The map was actually useful for once, which things such as location labels and the ability to place markers.  Only downside is that it doesn't show untraveled areas unlike the 2nd game.

+ The atmosphere of the cities and locations (aside from the boring desert) is well done with the locals talking about the latest events or interesting thoughts as you run past.

+ As mentioned before most of the side-quests themes and objectives are interesting due to them revolving around being alive for 500 years unable to age or die.  There's still your usual notice board fetch quests, but the interactive ones are best.  It's also interesting you only gain stats from completing quests instead of defeating enemies. It was fun planning out the 'day' in order to maximize my time.

+ Time mechanic (where you only have at most 13 in-game days to get everything done) was interesting but overall shouldn't turn you off from the game.  It's manageable.  I fast-forwarded through the last 5 days because I was done early.

+The story is far better than the second game's.

Cons
- While the story is good, the dialogue to deliver it can be cringe-inducing at times. 
- There's also the usual characters gaining abilities/powers out of nowhere, but that's JRPGs for you.

Overall really enjoyed this game.  It was worth suffering through the second game to play it.

49253818.review:
Final Fantasy thirteen, part 3. Alternate titles: Stagger Fantasy 3, Lightning Returns. Referred to as P3 for the purpose of this review.


Opening comments:

P1 had things about it which made it unique among FF games, so much that I didn't feel like it was a true FF game. P3 has even more about it which is unique among FF games, so much so that I dare to call the entire FFXIII trilogy the Stagger Fantasy trilogy. 

In P3, we play a hybrid combination of an action RPG, and Rogue-like game. The result is something very alien to playstation FF players, but it's still a good game. It's challenging and I hope this game inspires greater games in the future.


Basics:

Only one character is controlled in P3, which can lightning-fast alternate between 3 different combat patterns(like switching classes in FFX-2), each equipping a mandatory weapon and shield, invisible headwear and armwear, and inconsequential cosmetic. The base form of a combat pattern is a garb, and the garbs' colors may be edited with a palette of up to 12 user-defined colors and 12 preset colors. Editing the palette doesn't ruin saved garbs. Each garb can only use up to 4 commands(sometimes replacement commands appear during combat).

Although there are some commands that emulate those from P1 and P2, there are no class bonuses in P3, so bonuses mostly come from enemies getting staggered which are then afflicted by special ailments(sometimes stacking with regular ailments) such as 'stagger-deprotect' and 'stagger-deshell' which gives incentive to stagger often. Getting the enemy to stagger in the first place was reworked significantly to better fit the style of an action RPG.

There are 3 types of quests: Main Quests(necessary to complete the story), Side Quests(necessary to expand the story), and Canvas of Prayers Quests(have no effect on the story but add morsels of stats and data). All MQ have no way to time out unless you game over. SQ are the tricky ones. Innkeepers and hotel staff are your best friends when it comes to finishing them. CoPQ are just loot turn-ins and they increase in number both as the number of days increases and as quests are finished.

There are 3 kinds of enemies in P3: regular monsters which have an Omega form[to find out more about that, visit the Lighthouse in Dead Dunes], unique opponents which might transform as they level up, and the traditional RPG monsters. All kinds of enemies can level up by both difficulty level and day number. Loot tables change depending on the level of the enemies.

Enemies are encountered in much the same way as in P2, but the ability to ignore enemies is more like the ability to ignore them in P1. Elemental weaknesses give incentive to take advantage of manual sorting of both garbs and commands for quicker changes to combat patterns.


Concluding thoughts:

I'm glad that the game offers the choice of Easy and Normal at the start. Worth mentioning that there is a Hard mode also. I chose Normal at first and I was exhilerated when I first arrived at Dead Dunes as I was doing quite a lot of exploring there and almost had to skip to curfew(the kind of thing that would feel like a game over but wouldn't be unless ran out of days), but I made it back to the recovery items seller eventually and continued with my expedition. 

I was confused for why getting the Carbuncle Doll was a 1 star difficulty SQ because I was under the impression it was loot earned from slaying a dangerous enemy, when actually it  was just sitting on some boxes in plain sight but only at a certain time of night. Don't believe everything a non-player character tells you.

Luxerion's quests were very annoying because they had too many hidden time-based conditions to complete them. The Ghosts quest in particular felt like it should have been easier and a mandatory quest because it tells so much of the story. I'm pretty sure they rushed through this zone's quest code to finish the game. There's even a series of dialogues that implies I could access a certain area outside of the regular rules by means of some sort of quest which isn't offered.

Lumina was great. I liked her part in the story, and am pleased with how they brought her into the game. They could have done more with her character however, such as making NG+ grant different/additional Lumina treasure quests. Lumina was the best part about the game's story.

I liked the extra dialogue in the Wildlands, that was my favorite of the 4 main zones. It had more SQ than I thought it did. Apparently it's not easy to get them all on a first play through unless looking at a guide.

Bringing back Fang was great, and she was the most predictable character IMO.

As great as the story is, one character in particular made it a bit uncool throughout because of one not so little decision made before the game even started. And for some unknown reason, the mistake if we want to call it that isn't even fixed by the end of the game.

48432312.review:
Here we go. Lightning Returns is one of my favorite games of all time, and I'll try to explain why it is. Everything is a matter of opinion so I'll try to explain the strong points (for me) and my preferences, so perhaps it's easier to see if it can fit your preferences or not.

First of all, I'm 99% about gameplay. That’s my preference. I'm not saying that Lightning Returns has terrible story, but it probably falls flat compared with other FF's. But honestly, it depends on how you approach it. If what you care about is an amazingly deep plot that's all connected and all that, maybe this isn't for you. BUT, if you enjoy a 'moment-to-moment' experience in which little side quests, moments, surprises, etc, can be more important or just as fun as the 'whole package', I believe this game delivers even on story. Some of the side quests are simply amazing, some very bitter to varying levels and others quite light and with a happy ending. This game does an amazing job at displaying what humanity would do at the 'end of the world', even if some side quests might feel like the characters don't feel the weight of the hundreds of years of suffering, others do this REALLY well.

So let’s talk gameplay: Combat is like an action rpg, with a twist: The schemata. You have 3 “classes” that you can switch to anytime during battle at the press of a button. Each have their own ATB bar (works like a Stamina bar really) that dictates how much you can use your abilities. Abilities that YOU pick. Each Schemata has a garb (armor), weapon, shield and 2 extra equips, one affecting just that Schema, and another that affects all 3. Other than that you can pick your 4 abilities that you get from quests, monsters, chests, etc. Each ability has it’s cost, power, element, and garbs can have their own locked abilities, and equipment can have passive skills (even abilities/active skills can have passive skills) that can change how you play. Spend ATB of one Schema to boost ATB of another, switch out at the last second to gain buffs, all sorts of fun stuff you can imagine. Experiment and make your OWN setup, it’s fun and nearly any enemy can be taken down different ways, and yet every enemy has it’s own “stagger” mechanics returning from other FF 13 games. It’s not that complicated once you experiment with it a bit.

Now these are some recommendations on how to 'approach' this game, or at least more or less how I did so.

[b] Play the game without a guide, at your own pace. [/b] The game is full of moments in which you're going to do something and then something amazing happens that you didn't know. Stuff like me going to hunt some monsters for abilities then suddenly I hear this phone ringing and then someone says they are being kidnapped, and I actually have an unknown time limit to save that person. I go after them and suddenly some OTHER person showed up in the way with a new quest, and I also happen to find something I was looking for before from another quest. This can only happen if you don't look up quests online. [u] If you're confused about the game's mechanics, look up how ability synthesis works, but NOT what abilities you can find/make [/u], it's the most confusing mechanic and if you're playing on your own, on Normal instead of Easy, and enjoying the journey, that can help and it won't spoil much/anything. Don't look up boss strats or quest lists. [b] EXPERIMENT with the game. It's one of it's strongest qualities. [/b]

[b] Play on Normal at first. [/b] This game can be hard at times, but Easy takes off most of the urgency, fun and challenge. Think of every day at this world as a bit of a challenge. You gotta define what you'll do, at what moments you're willing to stop and go explore, and how much time you can waste. I love this. There's are many things that help you MANAGE this, and it's fun: EP abilities that can cure, stop time, teleport, and healing items that can also buff you in key moments. I specially enjoy that some of the best items are first avaliable only at the Ark, and later at 'hard to get' places. So your ITEMS MATTER. Are you going to waste that Phoenix Wing (powerful Phoenix Down) in this battle that you just messed up at the start of the day but finally finish off that powerful enemy, or redo everything? Or avoid that enemy entirely? On NORMAL and HARD, those situations DO happen and matter, but they kind of don't on Easy.

[b] Read the in-game bestiary and datalog, and don't worry about messing up or being efficient all the time. [/b] If you game over (out of time) you can try again with all the stats progress you had before from completing quests. Or if you just can't have the patience to do it all over again, trust me: It's better to have like 40 hours of FUN and playing as you see fit, than trying to look up online how to be efficient. This game mechanics and customization allow you to tackle things your own way. No "spam quick hit on the arms and hit the body while using very specific equipment as well as Rikku, Wakka and Tidus THE BOSS" in here. Seriously. Even the superbosses can be defeated in multiple ways in a mix of skill and strategy.

[b] Don't expect a "FINAL FANTASY EXPERIENCE" here. [/b] I'm no FF mega expert, (I beat 10, played lots of 12, and a bit of 8, 4, 10-2, and 13. I saw lots of playthroughts and videos on the other ones like 6, 7, 9...) but I think I know enough to confirm: This game is not very "Final Fantasy-y". I mean, the "pretty much action-rpg gameplay that we call ATB regardless" should be your big hint. My friends, this game has positioning, timed blocks, evades, and combo-ing. EVEN AERIAL combos, sorta. And let me tell you, the combat and customization makes 15 look like a baby's edition of this game's combat for all I know. BUT I haven't played 15 yet, so I won't judge, just simply repeating what I heard others say, at least the ones that enjoyed this or both games.

Now a bit of the bad. Beware of minor gameplay spoilers

[b] The BAD: [/b] Nothing's perfect and I'll try to be devil's advocate here and stab this game (that I love) where it might hurt a bit. But I'll probably do a bad job, bias.

[u] Some Textures [/u]: Some textures are blurry and terrible, specially on the terrain. Characters, weapons, etc still look good, and some places are indeed beautiful. Just don’t look too hard into it.

[u] Guard, then Smash buttons to win fake impression [/u]: This one here requires a few 'unlucky set of events' to happen and give this fake impression. Certain enemies ARE fodder. Some abilities ARE powerful. A few setups are borderline OP. So if you somehow stumble upon all of this at once repeated times, you'll be given the impression you just need to mash buttons and Guard and you win. But trust me, things get really hard later on. The moment you run into your first "Omega" enemy, you'll understand that this game doesn't mess around when it get serious. Hard mode is insane too. The superbossess will not let you PASS if you don't have a powerful setup. And trust me, this game will make you fear Chocobo Eaters like no other Final Fantasy did. Yet, all enemies have their weak points and exploitable mechanics that are really fun. Maybe that enemy you hate buffed himself at a specific moment, and maybe you can prepare for it. Or even STEAL the buffs. Maybe negate them? EXPERIMENT. It's the heart of this game.

[u]Performance[/u]: This game likes to choke on itself, SPECIALLY on big cities with loads of NPCs. Apparently this PC port is 'alright', nothing magical. It gets stable 60fps during combat, which is impressive (console versions of this were 30 fps or less all the time I believe) and sometimes it stays at 60 on the overworld. But on crowded areas it will lag hard without warning. I have a i5-4440 and a GTX 1060, and even though my CPU isn't anything special, I'm not sure a better CPU will solve the stutter issues. It's playable tho.

Would write more, but ran out of space. But this should give you all an idea. Enjoy!

3º y último capítulo de la Saga Fabula Nova Christalis.
-HISTORIA
La historia se sitúa 500 años después de XIII-2 y nos trae de vuelta a Lighting, la cual debe salvar las almas del mundo para poder llevarlas al nuevo, que está siendo creado por el Dios supremo.
Si venias del XIII-2 con los viajes en el tiempo, ahora resulta que todo va de dioses arriba y abajo, complacer al Dios supremo y rogar porque todo vaya bien.
Las conversaciones son TEDIOSAS, te explican lo mismo 50 veces, primero se entera Lighting, luego lo comenta con X, luego con Y, se le cruza un conocido y le cuenta lo mismo, este lo reflexiona y la otra lo corrobora, no sin antes asegurarse de que lo has entendido. En serio, no exagero, es cargante explicando lo que pasa una y otra y otra vez.
Dicho esto, NO hay más historia, el juego es un 90% misiones secundarias con las cuales podremos alargar los días de juego y a su vez, cada mision superada nos subirá las estadísticas de VIT, Ataque Fisico, Mágico... . En otras palabras, no se sube niveles por experiencia vs bichos, si no superando misiones.
Nos encontraremos con los protagonistas de los otros juegos, pero básicamente se basa en completar su misión para salvar su alma y poco más, con el objetivo de llegar al BOSS final que no explicaré aquí.
En cuanto al resto, las hay más y menos entretenidas, pero hacedme caso que en algunas vais a estar paseando más que jugando, parece un walking simulator.
-MECANICAS
La jugabilidad está basada en Action RPG, de modo que nos encontraremos enemigos por el escenario que podremos decidir si pegar o no, y una vez iniciada la batalla dispondremos de 3 vestidos al mas puro estilo X-2 que puedes configurar como te plazca, cada uno con 4 habilidades a personalizar. Las batallas son entretenidas pero hay mejores JARPGs.
Ahora bien, está el tema del TIEMPO. El juego empieza con 6 días para el final, tras esos 6 días el juego se acaba y volverias a empezar de 0 pero con los stats que hubieras ganado. En dificultad NORMAL el juego ya es bien JODIDO, el reloj no se para en ningún momento, y no va precisamente despacio, de modo que si es la primera vez que juegas preparate para estresarte o bien mentalizate de que vas a tener que empezar el juego 2 o 3 veces, porque no vas a llegar al ultimo día (13) ni de coña.Tendrás que ir a las tiendas o a las posadas para recuperar salud, con lo que perderás tiempo. En las luchas el reloj no para, y si te matan, cosa bastante probable, el reloj avanza un trecho. El sistema es complejo ya que tienes que tener presente que las misiones te pueden aparecer de DíA, TARDE o NOCHE, y que no las puedes canjear si se te ha pasado la hora, y cuando empiezas a tener X misiones activas a la vez te recomiendo apuntarte en que momento del día aceptaste a una misión, porque es es probable que no lo recuerdes y cuando vuelvas el tío que te la dio ya no esté allí.
EL MODO NORMAL NO ESTÁ PENSANDO PARA PASARTE EL JUEGO LA PRIMERA VEZ.
Si lo que quieres es pasartelo sin mas, entonces juegalo en FACIL, la vida se te recupera tras las batallas, el reloj se para en el inventario, no usaras posadas ni restaurantes, las magias para parar el tiempo las tendrás MUY amenudo, los enemigos son maás sencillos y no hay pensalización por morir y en definitiva, se puede llegar comodamente al último día y sin utilizar guías, de hecho, debería sobrarte mucho tiempo.
Por si tienes ganas de más tras pasartelo en el nuevo juego + puedes empezar en modo dificil, que no me quiero imaginar el festival que debe ser eso.
-Apartado visual
El juego está muy detallado y con bastantes guiós a otros Final Fantasy, sin embargo tengo que destacar que no tiene CGIs más que en la introducción y en el final del juego, viniendo de jugar del XIII y XIII-2 esto resulta chocante.
Los gráficos no son malos pero tampoco es READ DEAD REDEMPTION2, pasables para hoy en día.
-Valoración
Lighting Returns no es mal juego, pero tampoco es bueno. Entretenido en lo jugable pero sin enganchar, con una historia degenerada al máximo y estresante si entras de nuevo en el modo Normal. Si has jugado a los dos previos y quieres terminar la saga, no lo dudes y juégalo, pero no te esperes gran cosa, a mí me ha decepcionado.
Además se siente hoy día como una demo de FFXV, en el sentido de que te dejan libre por varios entornos MUY amplios que hacen las veces de mapas independientes, habiendo jugado a este último es a todas luces, más divertido jugablemente hablando, y no con peor historia.

The last gamne of the XIII saga was a aquite good surprise despise its flaws

  Combat wise it is an improvement compared to the paradigm system, you now control lightning action more directly in the new schematics system, here you can assign 4 skills to an outfit(and you have to use 3 in combat), it's important to know what are the outfit bonuses to make the right combination of skills accesories and weapons, the stagger system works similar to the past games(some skills have a high stagger hit others make the stagger last longer), overall itsmore action oriented compared to the previous 2 games.

  Story wise didnt liked that much, the conclusion to the trilogy is really something else  but I found it poor executed(story overall is not bad but its just not told very well), I don't recommend newcomers to start here but go back to the original XIII, whoever already played the past 2 games can just play this on easy if they are here just for the cocnlusion of the story.

  Soundtrack is pretty good but i liked the previous games OST more, theres a lot of reused ost from the previous games here but the originals are good as well.

 Grpahics still holds pretty nice and the game runs smoothly without FPS or others issues.

 The bad part is that the games suffers from some glitches and bugs, a minor graphics glitch makes Lightning and some others NPC hairs "Rainbow Colored" it's not a serious game issues just an annoyance you can finish the game fine with it, what i heard is that this is a problem related with ATI GPUs(using RX460 now) I didnt had this issues 2 years ago when I was using an GTX650. There is as well some really annoying bugs like sometimes some quests  dialogues glitches and you end up stuck in a dialogue loop without being possible to finish or start the quest forcing you tor estart the game to retry a second attempt, game also suffers from radom crashes they don't have a reason or a certain area to happen(for me they happens more frequently in the Wildlands) so I recommend you to save the game constantly to avoid losing progress.
  Another issue is related to game content, Hard mode and some of the games content like upgrading equipment and max leveling the skills are locked inNG+ mode so you need to at least finish the game one on Medium or Easy and do a NG+ run to unlock it, some archievments need you to upgrade equipments so if you pretend to get all of them you gonna need to do a NG+ run.

Game doesnt have a leveling system instead you increase your status by finishing quests, I highly recommend you to finish at least some side quests so you wont strugle later on the game as the mosnters get stronger with each passing day, the 5 main quests give a huge boosts and some unique improvements like more slots on consumables itens, more EP points, more ATB bar boost.

 And yes the most unique caracteristic that you gonna find in this game(and the most annoying) is the time limit system, you have a total of max 13~14 days(assuming you gonna do a lot of side quests otherwise you gonna end up of even less time)  a new day starts at 6 a.m so you have till next day 6a.m to get everything done before getting pulled back to the Ark, but don't worry a lot of quests are easy to get done by, some of them can be quite annoying and time consuming but depending how efficiently you manage your time you can get by just fine, I myself, finished the 5 main quests by day 7 and around day 12 had almost all side quests done( yes some quest were annoying and I had to use some help to pass by them), it all falls down to abusing the chronostasis skill, as long you can manage your EP to keep it up you will be able to save a lot of time and get all you need done before the final day.

 Overall Lightning Returns is quite nice I recommend anyone interested to get it on sale if you have played both previous game, in case you didnt get them before them buy Lightning returns in case you liked them, otherwise, don't bother with it.

45035373.review:
[b]Note for Steam Version[/b]: Thanks to the fact that all the DLC content is included free in this version, you start out with a ton more than you would've otherwise. Not only does that give you the chance to try out some awesome garbs and equipment, but the stuff you're not interested in or no longer have any use for can be sold off. So, for much of the game, if you don't want to harvest gil, you don't have to. (Which has turned out to be a huge plus in my view.)

[h1]A Rough Start[/h1]
I put this game off for [b]years[/b] because I was ticked off about how they ended FFXIII-2. They left it on about as blatant a cliffhanger as I could imagine, and I absolutely detest being strung along. 

So, this game was blemished from the start in my eyes. Nevertheless, I am something of a completionist and so here I am. 

[h1]An Excellent Sequel[/h1]
Lightning Returns with dozens of hours of fresh content well-worth the now reduced price of entry. It's framed as taking place over "13 Days," but dont' let that fool you. I'm 85 hours in and I have yet to finish my first play through. 

So long as you have a supply of EP, you can stretch a "day" out to ridiculous lengths. Provided you want to. And between the combat system, side-questing, stat-boosting and monster hunting, I definitely wanted to.

[h1]Tons of Customization[/h1]
Lightning is your one and only controllable party member. But through a garb-swapping system, it always feels like you've got a party of three. And you can store an additional six or so loadouts on the side. 

Each of these loadouts can be assigned their own equipment, accessories and (upgradeable) movesets. And a lot of these come with unique special effects, which you can mix-and-match to come up with some truly creative combinations, which can, in turn, be mixed and matched with the effects on your other loadouts for even crazier effects. 

For the right type of person, it make for some serious nerdy fun, trying to find your favorite permutations.

And that's all before factoring in that you can customize your garbs' colors and pick out adornments to go for whatever type of look you'd like "your Lightning" to have... And, yes, among the many looks available, some are "less clothed" than others.

[h1]Overall[/h1]
This is a worthy entry in this little trilogy, even moreso than its predecessor. 
If you've played the previous games, I'd say you've earned your reward here.

44988492.review:
NOTE: his review covers the whole trilogy, as it is basically one single story spanning over 3 games, with slightly different mechanics from chapter to chapter.

TL;DR version: Game is bad. Don’t buy it, don’t rent it and wait for a very deep sale (75%+), but only if you’re a completionist of Final Fantasy games. Also the PC port quality is horrendous for 13 and 13-2. Less so for Lightning Returns.

Let’s make it quick and dirty, shall we? I’m a big fan of JRPGs and of the FF series in general, and I have to say that this game is BAD. It pains me to admit it, but after playing the first 2 games and ½ of the third I had to force myself and rush to the ending of Lightning Returns, just for the sake of ticking the damn box and getting over with it. I definitely could not bother with New Game+.

The most egregious fault by Square Enix was to try and shoehorn an abomination of hybrid action combat system in place of the traditional ATB-based (or turn-based) system of the previous 12 chapters. With the aggravating factor that you mostly control only 1 character at any time, while the other 2 in the party are controlled by the AI and just follow generic patterns (if they are ever present at all, see below), with frustrating results.
The second and absolutely horrendous decision was to dramatically reduce the number of spells and actions that each character could theoretically execute in battle (because console controllers have only four buttons to mash, amirite guyses? Did anyone ever mention these weird things called “scrolling menus”????). Forget the classic ATTACK - MAGIC - ITEM - SUMMON - SKILL - WHATEVER list, you now have either a variation of “Mash A to Auto select skills” or “Press A for Slash, B for Fire, X for Cure, Y for Potion”. That’s it. And trust me, it is even worse in the first two games since you only choose the classes/jobs you characters are, and then the fight basically plays by itself on auto.

But hey, at least FF games have epic stories with strong characters, many plot twists and memorable villains? Right? RIGHT? 

WRONG

Here is a summary of the shitshow that is this trilogy (SPOILER SAFE):

[b]FF XIII[/b]
The first chapter of the trilogy is definitely the worst, considering also the overly-long development time. It is a glorified tutorial at best, and the player is forced through long linear corridor map sections with absolutely no clue of what is going on, without being given even a small hint to understand the plot of the game. For hours and hours. Sometimes the player controls 1 character, sometimes a different couple, sometimes 3 completely different guys, with the only task to move from one mob group to the other, from one cutscene to the next. Oh, and there is no character advancement system whatsoever, up to at least mid-game. Because who needs it in an RPG? That's preposterous!
The most insulting thing of them all? Once the corridors end and the first true “open area” is reached, when you are finally given the option to rearrange your party and properly equip it, the final mission starts and THE EFFIN’ GAME ENDS. I had to read a walkthrough guide to be sure that I did not skip most of the game by accident by entering the final dungeon prematurely (à la Chrono Trigger). Sadly, I did not make any mistake: the game was really over at that point.

[b]FF XIII-2[/b]
Take the convoluted and obscure plot of the 1st chapter, throw time travel paradoxes in, remove all the characters you barely knew from FF13, add the most annoying protagonist teen couple ever in the mix and reduce the max number of party members down to 2. And you still get a better game than FF XIII-2! Seriously, they could have done worse only if Square was so lazy to recycle most of the assets again and again from the 1st game on every map… oh wait… they actually did it! FF XIII-2 is basically just an asset flip of XIII...
But hey, you can collect Pokémon in this game! Isn’t it cool?
Also, the character advancement system in 13-2 (yes, Square remembered to add one since the beginning this time!) is the worst thing I have experienced in any RPG, ever. You need several external guides just to get a grasp of it, since it is THAT badly documented in-game. It would have been better if Square simply did like in the 1st chapter or forget to implement it at all.

[b]Lightning Returns: FF XIII[/b]
I must admit this is the most solid game of the trilogy. Or at least the most solid turd of the 3. On the positive side, this time the plot is explained to the player, somehow. The efforts put in to fix the dumpster fires that were 13 and 13-2 are pretty evident the more you progress (although several core game mechanics are still undocumented and oblivious af, which frustrates the player) but Square Enix in his almighty wisdom decided that it was a brilliant idea after the backlash of 13-2 to reduce the max number of party members even further. That’s right! In this game you can control only 1 playable character during the whole story! But you can dress her up and play Barbie Fashion Wheel! Isn’t it wonderful?
And if that wasn’t enough, the whole game is on a death timer: once the 13th in-game day ends, unless you have completed the 5 main plot quests this results in an immediate GAME OVER. Even though you’ll soon learn that the time limit is absurdly lenient (I completed each quest in the game, including optional and secrets, in 7-8 days of in-game time) it is still a very bad design choice, because it puts undue urge on the player and pushes you to skip everything just to get to the objective and save time. Yes, this game basically punishes the player for exploring its own hand-crafted open world!
Final note of shame for Square: in the English translation the localisation team completely butchered and removed lots of subtexts and romanticism in the dialogue between the main characters. Because why not? WOULD SOMEBODY PLEASE THINK OF THE CHILDREN!?
