44829662.review:
[h1]Best gameplay out of the series, but everything else is poorly done[/h1]

Lightning Returns: Final Fantasy XIII, (shortened to LR) is the last game in the beleaguered Final Fantasy XIII trilogy. The first game was an utter mess of hallways and handholdy tutorials. The sequel was a massive upgrade from the first game that took fan feedback to heart but had a nonsensical time travelling plot that goes nowhere. LR in the meanwhile is a completely different beast, sporting a new battle system, a time mechanic and only one playable character. Fans hoping for a great final act to the trilogy will be severely disappointed. LR delivers a story so out of left field that it even experiencing the ending left me scratching my head on what exactly happened. Fortunately if you can completely ignore the story and dull characters, you can enjoy some of the finest gameplay yet in the entire Final Fantasy franchise.

The best part of LR is the gameplay. The auto-battle system in the previous games is completely scrapped in favor of an action game. In LR, you only play and control the protagonist Lightning. Each face button represents a command which drains the stamina or active time bar (ATB). Once out of stamina, Lightning can change wardrobes or garbs which have their own separate commands and ATBs. While Lightning is wearing the active garb, the other two inactive garbs recover ATB. The key to combat is to use commands while cycling from garb to garb to setup some insane hit combos. The combat is snappy, precise and has a high skill ceiling. Part of the combat is knowing which garb commands to use to stagger the enemy and which garbs to use when defending. Players who perfectly time guard and attack commands can block all damage or deal bonus damage respectfully. Defeating the strongest bosses in the game requires an intense focus and mastery of combat almost equivalent to playing a Souls game.

The garb system is interesting but ultimately not worthwhile. Each garb the Lightning collects can have special commands and attributes thus enticing the player to collect every garb possible. While it sounds great on paper, Lightning can only equip 3 garbs at a time and some of the best garbs are automatically earned by playing through the main storyline or purchased in stores. Most of the garbs in the optional quests and DLC are worse than the garbs you get normally so there is never a chance to wear them unless you want to see Lightning fight in those outfits.

Some of the garbs that Lightning wears are skimpy and revealing. They make zero sense as combat attire and are purely fan service. One specific garb makes Lightning do a sexy pose in the victory screen: Lightning bends down revealing her cleavage and smiles at the player. Also players can choose to add adornments for Lightning such as having her wear a hat, don a mustache or brand a tattoo. This isn’t the first time Square Enix let players “doll up” a female protagonist, they did the same thing for Yuna with the dress spheres in FFX-2. I’m not against these sexy garbs, but I feel like it’s a sleazy way of getting people to play the game.

The time system in LR is controversial because the game ends in 7 in-game days. Each gameday lasts exactly 1 real-time hour. After the 7 days have passed, Lightning must face the final boss or can choose to rewind back to the beginning and keeping most of the garbs and stats gained in her journey similar to a rogue-like. However I don’t think LR is meant to be a rogue-like. Completing main story quests extends the game by a day, up to a maximum of 13 days. Time freezes while in menus or in battles. There is also an ability that Lightning can use to freeze time temporarily. With proper time management, I believe most players can complete every single main and side quest and have days to spare. But this is coming from someone who loves optimization and speed running, so your mileage may vary.

The production value of LR is arguably worse than the other two games. With the exception of Lightning, her garments and some main characters, LR recycles assets from the other two games. Character designs are the same. There is no new memorable music tracks. FMVs recycle scenes from the prior games. There are no new monster designs. Lip syncing is poorly done (which was a similar issue in FFXIII-2). Two of the main areas the Wild Lands and the Dead Dunes are boring open sandboxes. The only bright spot is that the PC port is great, with zero bugs/crashes and offers multiple graphical/display options.

I’ve been avoiding it for most of this review, but it is finally time to talk about the story.

Remember the L’Cie and Fal’Cie from FFXIII? How about all the time paradoxes in FFXIII-2? Well forget about all that because now the FFXIII world is about to end in 7 days because of the Chaos. God has tasked Lightning to save the souls of the remaining humans and bring them into a new world that God will create. Square Enix has gone straight biblical and created their most ridiculous story yet. The story seems wave away everything nonsensical with either the Chaos or God. Why is Hope back and in his younger self? Why is this character back when they were killed/sacrificed in the previous games? Why does Lightning have to take the train to travel from area to area when Hope can warp her out from anywhere?

It also doesn’t help that Lightning and Hope are the least likeable characters in the trilogy. Lightning never really displayed any emotion in either of the past two games, but now it becomes exaggerated because she is the only character you play. Hope in the meantime serves as the oracle to Lightning and constantly comments on things that you should pay attention to. This isn’t Bastion-level of narration however, Hope’s comments will drive you crazy and you will eventually be relieved when he finally shuts up. Lumina the antagonist, is the only likeable character in LR. Her appearances add energy to the scenes and actually makes the plot somewhat palatable. She is basically the Joker to Lightning’s Batman. But even Lumina could not buoy this sinking ship of a story.

The gameplay is the only reason to play LR. Square Enix made the right step with FFXIII-2 only to bungle most of its’ gains with LR. Instead of refining on what made FFXIII-2 great, Square Enix decided to make an action game and completely abandon most of the plot in the previous games. While the action of this game is probably the best in the Final Fantasy series as a whole, everything else about LR feels hastily put together. The story is nonsensical. The characters are not likeable. The dialog is half-baked. Ultimately if you are onboard with the gameplay, I recommend seeing LR to the end, otherwise avoid this game at all costs and just look up the ending if you’re curious about the conclusion to this trilogy.

42336486.review:
NOTE: This review covers a retrospective of the entire trilogy, the parts concerning this specific game are near the end of the paragraphs or in the TL;DR at the end

Lightning Returns: Final Fantasy XIII is the final game of the FFXIII trilogy. The FFXIII trilogy is probably the most polarizing game in all of FF; a lot of people hate it and call it the worse than WW2 and that it's a sin to humanity and has contributed to the de-evolution of mankind and never should have been brought into existance, while other people defend it and say that it's not that bad. I went into the trilogy fully aware of the prejudice that faced it and walked away from it pleasently surprised. The second game however was a mess(not to mention the constant crashes and game freezes on PC) that I struggled to keep up with, and the cliffhanger ending only made me more worried for the final game in this 100+ hour trilogy. After numerous failures and successes, can FFXIII finally redeem itself and prove it as a worthwhile investment?

Yes. 
Oh my god yes.
I love this game to death and dare I say it's one of the best games I've played in a long time. The combat has recieved a complete overhaul, whereas before the only method of strategy was shifting paradigms and then mashing A until you need to heal or buff, the combat mechanics in LR feel so natural and satisfying. I was thrown off by it at first and it took a good 5-10 hours to get used to, but it feels so intuitive once you understand it. I was uncertain whether I liked only having control of one character, as opposed to in previous games where you could control up to five characters at once. However as I went through the game, Lightning's interesting variety in the moves and techniques she can pull of made her encompassing enough and any more controllable characters would've resulted in a mess.
A small side note to many but also a relieving factor to others, the soundtrack is absolutely gorgeous. Skip this paragraph if soundtrack isn't a make or break desicion for you. The first game had a very orchestrated and what I like to refer to as a "light vocal" OST, not really focusing much on melodies and rather just trying to accomplish a certain mood. 90% of the songs from the first soundtrack are just either remixes of "Blinded by Light" and "The Promise," which gets very old after a while. The themes that departed from these main two were very catchy and it only made me dissapointed that it played it safe with the melodies they regarded as "catchy." FFXIII-2 on the other hand is a lot more experimental with it's soundtrack, adding a lot of lyrics, synths, and elements from metal, "Limit Break" in particular just being straight up screamo-type material. Despite the description, I actually like this soundtrack way more than the first game. It's a lot more unique and unorthidox and it gives the game a very distinguished feel. While yes, a good chunk of the tracks are remixes of the main theme, "A Wish," that's just to be expected from FF. That being said, this soundtrack still struggles a lot with identity, and being experimental by nature some of the tracks are just going to sound noticably lower quality. A lot of songs from the first game are also reused in this one, and whenever your fighting a giant robot from the future with techno music blaring in the background and then it cuts to an orchestrated field theme, the shift is very noticable and awkward. FINALLY after getting that out of the way I can talk about LR's soundtrack. This game has finally found a proper tone for it's soundtrack. It's the best out of the three(obviously my opinion). It mixes the two previous styles together in a way that feels natural; heavy violin pieces are complemented with a prominent, almost-metalic sounding percussion. There are still pieces that are fully orchestrated, like "Divine Love," but they still feel like they fit because the rest of the soundtrack doesn't ostracize them. Even ones that I didn't like when first listening too, like "High Voltage," grew on me quickly after I sat down and noticed all the piano elements in this otherwise fully synth song. In summary: it's good.
Now the part that the FFXIII series is known in infamy for: plot and linearity. The first game had an absolutely confusing first few chapters which bombared the player with unknown terms and lore without really explaining what any of them all, after that though, I felt the game was fairly standard, the only issue being the writing and dialogue was god awful. None of the characters can convey the seriousness of the situation, and plot points that are vital to the story aren't translated with proper intensity. While I defend the first game's story, I can't really say the same for XIII-2. The story is an absolute mess and all it does is unnecessarily further complicate the first game's story. They could've just made a game about life on Pulse and having to live with the fal'Cie there, but nooooo they just had to add their OCs Noel and Caius into the game and make a completely different story which has basically nothing to do with the first game outside of characters. Finally we arrive at Lightning Returns once again, and thank god it's a breath of fresh air after the second game. The story- get this- actually makes sense this time. I didn't need to constantly read some stupid datalog to understand what was happening in the game, and the progression feels natural which is especially noteworthy because of the game's nonlinear gameplay(more on that later). The writing feels forceful and there's enough gameplay between major plotpoints to actually make it feel like this is *your* story, not you witnessing someone elses.
Finally the last point, and probably the most imfamous. I'm sure you've heard the memes about FFXIII's "hallway simulator," and the devs took note of those complaints and made XIII-2 less linear, but it still felt like you were stuck on a certain path with very little variation through playthroughs. Lighting Returns abandons all sense of linearity by dropping you into a world and giving you complete control of where you want to go. It's amazing. There are four main continents and you can go to any of them right off the bat. Each one has it's own main story quest which again, you can choose which ones you want to do first, and then one final story quest which takes place in all 4 continents, followed by the scripted ending sequence and final boss. The game no longer feels like a half-assed adventure game with limited movement options and uninteresting environments. The four main continents of LR are super detailed and filled with things to do and your movement feels very natural and actually fits the gameplay. There's so much freedom it's almost overwhelming at the beginning of the game, and it's up to you to ease yourself in and learn how things work. Lightning Returns also features an in-game real time clock of limited time, similar to that of Majora's Mask, meaning that you have a certain amount of time to complete all the story quests or else it's back to the beginning for you. While this may sound like a negative aspect, a raincloud always looking over your head, after a while you realize how semi-easy it is to gain more time and control the little you have left and make the most of it. That's probably what I love the most about this game: no two playthroughs are ever the same. There are over 100 sidequests to do as well as the many different paths you can take to complete each story mission. It makes the player feel involved as a character in this world, exploring it at their own pace and deciding the path they want to go down.
TL;DR
I'm assuming most of you jumped here so I'll keep it short like I promised
+In-depth and diverse combat system(easy to learn, hard to master)
+Nonlinear story and exploration
+Amazing and atmospheric soundtrack
-Still a FFXIII game(semi-confusing plot and characters that can feel dry at times)
buy this game with money

Overview:

Final Fantasy 13 was a good game, not great but not bad by any means, then 13-2 came out and while it improved in some areas it threw a halfbaked paradox plot at us...still everything besides the storyline was enjoyable for the most part...

Then came this game...

I don't know what the devs were thinking with this one, its like some idiot in the dev office said: 

"Hey, lets throw EVERYTHING GOOD about the last two games out the window and keep all the BAD THINGS!"

And for some strange reason everyone agreed.

Now for a more detailed review:

The combat system:

Before I begin, let me just say that while I prefer the old school ATB combat system hands down, it DOES NOT mean I am  aginst a real time combat system...IF IT'S DONE RIGHT!

The combat system in Lightning Returns was NOT done right...

They tried to implement a detailed menu that was built for the ATB combat system into a real time combat system which resulted in you dodging around until you found the command you were looking for, while switching paragrams on the fly to break your foes and then deal massive dmg to them, all the while button mashing the hell out of all your commands for a single paragram so you could get the booster for switcing to the next one.

It was a juggling act of a mess and while memorizing commands and different paragram setups helped make this less taxing, it was still a juggling act of a mess, espeally aginst bosses who took forever to break. The fact that the combat system completely relied on the idea of breaking your foe before you did any significant damage to them was also a major hinderance and made even the most minor of battles a chore to complete.


The story:

At the very least, 13-2 connected itself to the previous game, albit with a VERY LOOSE plot device. 

Lightning Returns caused me to feel lost from the very beginning. I had no idea why Lightning was suddenly the god of this game's errand girl outside of the fact that it apprently claimed that if Lightning did what it asked that it would give her sister's soul back to her. Beyond that, there was absolutely no connection to the previous games.

What little story there was both made me go "What the actul fuck is going on here?!" While simaltaniously ticking me off by throwing out any and all character development the characters had from the past two games.


The Gameplay:

I could dub this game "Final Fantasy 13-Sidequest Edition" and anyone who played this game would immedately get the joke but I'll be more detailed.

You start out of the gate with a time limit, okay not a great start but not horrid but then you find out that the way to "save" people is by accepting their quest and completing mundane after mundane quest. Occasionaly you'd have to fight your way to collect a Key Item for a quest but for the most part it was running from NPC A to NPC B or go to this location here for item.

However this is only the tip of the iceberg...

Remember that time limit I meationed? Yeah, you have a very limited time to complete these mundane sidequests and there is no quick travel system for the most part so time gets drained fast doing even one of these quests. You would need a FAQ with detailed information if you want to make the most effective use of your daily time limit and get the best ending.

Oh the the kicker? You start off with only 6 days until the game litterally ends and if you don't collect enough etro(currancy for more time in this game basically) and do the 4 core storylines, you get the bad ending by default. You can eventually extend this time limit up to 13 days but without a detailed FAQ, you're definately not gonna accomplish this.

Overall, the gameplay in Lightning Returns is boring if not frustrating to deal with at times.

Graphics:

How do I put this?

It felt like they were downgraded? Like, the only true detail is in the multiple garments you can collect and everything else looks like it was fresh out a of PS2 era game.


Final Thoughts:

Lightning Returns plays, looks, and feels like the developers gave up on making this game half-way through and tossed it to their B-Team to finish while they went off to make Final Fantasy XV. If you enjoy this style of gameplay and combat then you probaly won't hate this game that much but if you're like me:

You'll feel disappointed if not appalled that a game like this is tied to the "Final Fantasy" name.

Lightning Returns is a curiosity that will appeal to fans of the franchise and appal everyone else.

------

Lightning Returns is the third and final game from the XIII trilogy. It does some things very well, and some things really poorly. Let's take a looksie!

[h1]The Good[/h1]

The combat is fantastic. It's fluid, engaging, challenging and skillful but retains many of the tropes that come with the series - like the elemental magic attacks with silly names. It's totally different from anything they've done in the past and the game is [i][b]totally carried by it.[/b][/i]

You can also play dress up with Lightning in a manner that recalls the old Job system from FF:Tactics, minus the extended grind. Good times.

[h1]The Bad[/h1]

The story is ludicrous, melodramatic and at times downright nonsensical, and the world they've created is kind of bland and dull. It's a testiment to the power of cinema that the cutscenes combined with the fantastic soundtrack can still draw a tear to the eye over such complete and utter garbage.

And the English voice acting, as has been standard for the XIII trilogy, is distractingly bad. (JP audio is available)

[h1]The Unusual[/h1]

Lightning Returns should have been titled Lightning Returns: Majora's Mask. Your entire playthrough is on a clock (which there are ways to temporarily stop), the time for which can be extended by completing quests.

The entire game is totally non-linear. Certain things will only occur after a certain day has passed, but you can go anywhere and do anything from the get-go.

[h1]What do I think?[/h1]

You should play XIII - the first one - and ignore the rest of the trilogy. XIII-2 is a complete waste of time and Lightning Returns is only really notable for having better gameplay. These games take upwards of 40 hours to complete and for most people are simply a waste of time.

The nostalgia is real, but FF6 through to 10 are all much better, much more charming games, and the series has gone downhill since (not including XV which I haven't played yet).

If, on the other hand, you're a hardcore Final Fantasy Fanatic or are dying of curiosity and jonesing for some hot chocobo action, then go for it!

39965738.review:
Lightning is back!

Story (*spoilers for FFXIII-2*):
Centuries after the events of Final Fantasy XIII-2 Lightning is awakened from her slumber by Bhunivelze, the God of Light. [spoiler]Serah is dead[/spoiler], and chaos is rampant. Everyone, including old friends and enemies, have stopped aging, however they are still able to die, but not reproduce. Not only has this lead to the population decreasing drastically, the chaos running rampant has also lead to the end of the world, which will take place in only a matter of days. Bhunivelze is planning to create a new world, and it is your job as his servant to save as many souls as possible before time runs out, so that they can pass over safely  into the new world. If Lightning succeeds, Bhunivelze has promised that as a reward [spoiler] Serah will be brought back to life[/spoiler]. However, when the mysterious character Lumina (who bears a striking resemblance to Serah) appears, Lightning starts to realize that (as usual) things aren't quite as simple as they seem.


 Gameplay:
The old paradgim (party) system has been thrown out the window, and has been replaced with a fighting system where you only control Lightning. You are able to have three active schemas (equipment setups) at a time, that you can switch between freely during combat. In addition to weapons and equipment you can also assign up to four abilities to each schema. For example you might have one schema with equipment and abilities focused mainly on dealing damage, another one that focuses on tanking, and a third one focusing on buffing/debuffing. The medic class (and its abilities) has been completely removed, and in this time healing is mainly done by using items.

The fighting this time around is much more action oriented, since you have to switch between schemas and use the correct abilities in real-time whenever your action (energy) bars has full. You also have the ability to move around on the battlefield, however there was only one boss fight where I actually had to move (away from the boss), so you can pretty much just ignore this feature.

The only way to level up is to complete quests, so unlike the previous two games there is no penalty for avoiding fights. Monsters often drop abilities (which can be leveled up if you find duplicates), so there is [i]something[/i] to gain from fighting them, but if you don't want to fight random mobs then you don't have to.

As the world is about to end you are on a timer, and if you don't finish all the main quests (and a decent amount of side quests if you are going for the best ending) within the time limit, you will get a game over. Losing a fight will deduct an hour from your remaining time (unless you're playing on easy), however there are ways to extend the time limit, and also a way to freeze time (temporarily), so the timer was never really an issue for me. However, some NPCs that you have to talk to during a quest only appear during specific times of the day, which eventually got [b]very[/b] annoying, as you would have to return to the same place at different times of the day just so you could hand in quests to all the time-specific NPCs.

Graphics:
It might just be because the port is not very good, or because the world in Lightning Returns is very open with many NPCs walking around, but the game looked way worse than the previous two games. However the CG cut-scenes look as beautiful as ever.

Length:
Another complaint I have is regarding the length of the game. I'm sort of glad that I didn't have to grind as much this time around, but even after extending the time limited to the max the game still felt a bit short, especially compared to the first game of the trilogy. Apparently you're suppose to do multiple playthroughs, but there really is no reason to play through the game more than once (other than upgrading your equipment)...

Conclusion:
All in all, while Lightning Returns is in my opinion the weakest FFXIII game, I still enjoyed it, and if you have already finished the first two then you should also finish the third one, just to see how Lightning's story ends.

This is easily the worst mainline Final Fantasy game I've ever played - and I've played all of them except for IV: The After Years and XV.

In theory, it should be a great game. LIGHTNING RETURNS set out to fix the main issues people had with XIII and XIII-2, namely the linearity. And what it attained came at a great cost. You see, XIII was a beautiful game with an interesting cast of characters, decent to good customization and an incomprehensible storyline plagued by linearity. XIII-2 was a beautiful, less linear game with an interesting cast of characters, decent to good customization, pretty good gameplay features (the time-travel thing was quite cool) and a still incomprehensible storyline that barely worked to keep the game together.

LIGHTNING RETURNS throws most of this off the window from the get-go by being the ugliest Final Fantasy game in existence. While the main character models (reused from previous games) are beautiful, there's not a single location that could be considered pleasing to the eye, something I believe comes from a severely limited graphical engine that wasn't made for open environments. And they did create open environments in a failed attempt to get rid of linearity: The game is lousy with sidequests and huge, open areas that are full of nothing. Every single task in the game consists of traversing one huge place or another, all of them full of monsters and none of them visually pleasing or interesting at all. To rub salt on the wound, the sidequest system is pretty bad, since sidequests are tied directly to character advancement (thus making them basically mandatory), most make little sense, and their design is lacking - you get either fetch quests that involve running from an end to the world to the other to somewhere else while the clock ticks against you (there's a time limit on this game, yay!), kill quests that are pretty much "kill ten rats," and annoying, time-sensitive quests that require you to be at a certain place at a certain time, sometimes three days in a row. In some cases, the side-quest are a mixture of all three for added fun.

On top of the botched sidequest system, there's the fact that there's no character progression system at all besides it, and the sidequests offer no customization whatsoever - so your stats are basically set, except for what you equip. And while equipment does make a huge impact on your stats (most of your stats will come from equipment,) there's something hollow to changing jobs so quickly and easily and not having a chance whatsoever to build your own character as you see fit on an RPG. Sure, Final Fantasy has often had this - FFVII got by on materia alone, for example - but all the other system felt more impactful than this. LIGHTNING RETURNS's customization consists basically of hunting the clothes you want, the weapons you want, and praying that you get enough drops of a magic item to be able to upgrade it. It feels shallow, severely limited, and it's not at all satisfying. And then, of course, monsters become stronger as you do so even if you complete every single task you'll still face annoying enemies with far too much health to be fun by the end of the game.

And then, after the horrible graphics, horrible sidequests, no customization and the lack of a likable protagonist (Lightning is as dull a character as they come, and easily the worst main character in FFXIII), there's the storyline. The writers of FFXIII, who you likely remember were on crack all through the process of writing FFXIII and FFXIII-2, come back for thirds, this time doing krokodil! The storyline is, as we've come to expect from such a talented group of storytellers, absolutely impossible to understand (although I'll give them kudos in that it's a bit easier to grasp than the previous two,) completely uninteresting, and told mostly in a series of endless expository conversations that would have any writer worth their salt shaking in disgust. In the end you're given no reason to care about anything of what's going on, turning the game into a series of uninteresting missions in an ugly, uninteresting world.

I played through this whole game because I didn't want to abandon it as I generally love Final Fantasy. But you? You don't have to even begin it. Stay away from this - I know the ending of FFXIII-2 was a cliffhanger but, trust me, you're better off making up your own resolution to the story than spending dozens of hours going through this. There's nothing redeemable here.

Oh, wait, there IS one redeeming quality: Of the trilogy, this one has the best PC port. Shame it's the worst game of the lot.

>Great Combat system(like White Knight Chronicles and FFCrysisCore had a baby). Stagger rework is abit annoying but it's nice melee and magic can stand on their own without stagger. The fights don't focus on stagger.
>So far I have seen only one waste of a skill slot, however I'm not post game so what do I know. Tons of skills and outfits to shuffle through. The DLC outfits are nice too though imo Summoner and Cloud is broken early game(until you meet element obsorbing enemies atleast).
>New game+ exists(this is a pro for the fact that the game has a time limit).
>Controls feel nice and very responsive
>Story is fairly light on details and doesn't require as much digging(for those who complained about 13-1).

Cons:

>Mouse support is a meme at this point isn't it?

To be quite frank, I’ll only really recommend those who actually like the FFXIII series which are the minority in my opinion. Having replayed FFXIII (even though in the past, I absolutely loved it) I can see why FFXIII series is flawed. Very flawed. But if you’ve never played any FFXIII game, I suggest this out of the whole series. The only bad part is story-wise you’d be confused, but I’m still lost myself as I played the first 2 anyway. (This review will contain some spoilers but I’ll put a warning.)

You can do a mini-riposte once you guard at the right time and stagger the enemy, a key element to the FFXIII combat. Also, it seems a lot more fluid and a lot more strategic. Of course, it’s not perfect, but the battle system for a turn-based combat is probably one of the best. 

Also one of the cooler things in this game is that there’s so much customization. It’s nifty and cute. I love a lot of Lightning’s accessories and outfits. Makes the game even more interesting to play. 

~Spoiler-ish warning~

I haven’t finished the game yet but I’ve been having a lot of fun with the story. Mostly the side-quest mission stories. Customization

Lighting Returns is by far the best RPG I've experienced. Your first playthrough will be difficult and slightly frustrating. The game doesn't hold your hand. It throws you into the world giving you five days to complete the five main quests and tells you to Have Fun!

Lighting Return is fully customizable. Complete quests in any order you like. Customize Lighting's attack & defense skill as you like. 36615024.review:
The FF13 series as a whole (FF13, 13-2 and LR) seems to be one of the most heavily disliked FFs, and though I can understand why in some aspects, I would still definitely recommend this game. 

PROS
+ Combat is immersive (it deviates from the traditional pick a move then it executes, instead putting you in more of a real time situation) and feels more like an action RPG than a traditional RPG.
+ Customization; you get a wide variety of outfits to equip Lightning with, which affects important stats such as health, ATB (for those unfamiliar to the FF13 series this is similar to a mana or energy bar that recharges when not used). At any time you are able to equip three outfits for Lightning, which substitute as your party members in traditional RPG games (and from FF13 and 13-2). With the wide variety of outfits available, it's very likely that no two players will have the exact same three outfit setup which really allows you to tailor to your playstyle(s).
+ Story is at times dark but overall provides a satisfactory ending to the FF13 series (at least in my opinion); this can be highly subjective but personally I found the game explored many themes (especially philosophically) quite well (life and death being a prominent one, it also plays with the notion of pseudo-immortality and the effect that would have on humanity). Perhaps the game was never meant to invoke these kinds of thoughts of themes, but it did for me and I can say I enjoyed the story very much. 
+ Cutscenes were well done and generally a treat but too few far and in between for me personally.
+ Open world element was great for the first 20 hours but gradually became repetitive (a small nitpick).
+ The time limit; an aspect of the game that many dread (at times I also did, I'll touch on that in the cons section), but it provides a sense of urgency as it should in this game's environment. 
+ You get to equip Lightning in whatever outfit you please (some to me are over-the-top but it also serves as fanservice).
+ Good optimization and controller support (running on a 960m was no problem at a steady 60fps).

CONS
- Fighting enemies eventually feels dragged out and repetitive; there will be times when you look to avoid engaging enemies altogether. While the combat system is fresh, enemies appear quite often and the sequence is always the same (look for weak points, hit them with combos to stagger, finish them off). This becomes more of a problem on side quests when you're tasked with retrieving items or delivering a message from one place to another, which for a large chunk don't require combat at all.
- Completing side quests and main quests is the only way to "level up" Lightning; there is no experience point system in LR and fighting monsters only nets you gil (gold) and items/abilities. As mentioned already above, this will at times lead one to wish to avoid combat altogether. Side quests include some interesting stories and are varied enough, but for the most part you'll be doing the same things (fighting monsters to collect x items, finding items, delivering messages).
- Character development is on the weak side (Snow, Fang, Vanille and Sazh all have their own sub-stories but these could have been much further developed).
- Hope constantly being in your ear can be quite annoying, to the point where his dialogue constantly gets cut off as you enter into combat or talk to people.
- The time limit, while effective at times, can simply be abused by using an ability to freeze time; while abilities cost an alternate point system called EP, this can be recharged insanely fast by fighting monsters (though it charges slower with weaker monsters). 

OTHER COMMENTS
- Characters, their development and impact may not be as strong as in some previous FF games (FFX comes to mind) but is satisfactory and enjoyable overall.
- Moderate replayability as there are a few features that are only unlocked after starting a New Game+.

TL;DR - Overall, the story seems to be hit-or-miss with people (it was a hit for me), but due to that and a fresh combat system, I would definitely recommend this game. I would rate this at least an 8/10.

36483125.review:
The basic rundown : You play as Lightning, who has been tasked to save souls from the dying world, and has been given a few godly powers to help. You start the game with 7 days to go until the end of the world, and have to extend the world's remaining lifetime by saving souls. You save souls by completing quests, which convieniently also rewards you with money, stats, and cosmetic items.

The world is divided up into four major areas, and there are 5 main questlines you need to complete in order to buy the world the time it needs. There are also around 60 sidequests and 80 "MMO-type quests" (basically bringing items back to a billboard) to help you get stronger. It is worth noting that the only way to get stronger is through completing quests. You do not level up, and do not earn experience or stats from fighting enemies.

Let's address the elephant in the room now : [b]The doomsday timer[/b].

All throughout the game, a timer ticks down, to remind you that the end of the world is near. Each in-game day lasts 24 real-time minutes. The timer stops during battle, cutscenes and menus, and you start the game with 7 days, and can earn up to 14 by completing quests. You only need to earn 13 days to complete the game. Yet my first playthough took me about 40 hours.
If you're wondering why the math doesn't check out, it's because of a nifty ability called Chronostasis. This ability allows you to stop the doomsday timer for around 90 seconds at the cost of 1 EP, which is a resource you earn by fighting monsters. The cost of chronostasis is so low that you can abuse it to no end. I had completed pretty much every quest in the game, except for a few super-boss related ones by day 5 thanks to Chronostasis, to give you an idea on how generous the game is with it's time limit.
 
The global timer is a poorly implemented mechanic, simply because the only way Square found to make it tolerable was to add another mechanic which entirely circumvents it.

Now let's talk about the other thing that sets Lightning Returns apart from the ordinary JRPG : The battle system.
You have three "schematas" at your disposition, each schemata being a loadout of 1 armor(called "garbs" by the game,  some garbs are more on the swimsuit than armor side), 2 accessories, 1 weapon, 1 shield and 4 abilities. Abilities are dropped by monsters, or found in chests, and can be upgraded by fusing abilities of the same type together. You can freely switch between your three schematas during battle, and each schemata has it's own ATB bar, independant from the other two's. This gives you an apparent lot of strategic freedom, unfortunately the majority of abilities, garbs and even weapons are garbage, which limits your options. This system also allows you to play dress-up, if that's your thing.

For the actual battle side of things, the combat is extremely action-focused. You control Lightning's every move, have no party members (except at one point in the game, and for a very short time) and must parry enemy attacks with precise timing to avoid being beaten into the ground. Overall I found this system quite enjoyable, although it is a bit of a trudge before you unlock certain abilities, and sometimes an overuse of visual effects and animations by the game makes it hard to tell what's going on, and in turn, hard to parry/time your attacks correctly.


The first game of the trilogy was heavily criticized for it's lack of player freedom and overwhelming linearity. This is not the case in Lightning Returns. You can do any main quest you want first, although some are easier than others, go to any area whenever you want, and generally do things in the order you please. The only task the game asks of you, is to complete the 5 main quests and enough sidequests before your time is up.


This game also features an extinction mechanic for the monsters. For nearly all monsters, after enough of them have been killed, a Last One, basically a way more powerful version of that monster will spawn. After defeating it, that monster type will no longer appear for this playthrough. This can be a bit of a problem since enemy drops get better after day 7 and day 10. If you exterminated a monster which dropped an ability you  wanted the more powerful version of  before day 7 or 10, you're out of luck for this playthrough. Likewise, the amount of gil the the game has a soft limit because of this extinction system (the vas majority of your income will come from monsters, specifically from Cactuars), and buying a weapon on day 9 when the store begins selling a straight upgrade by day 10 for just a bit more gil is a huge slap in the face.


The plot is a mess. There is no other way to put it. You need to have played the first two games in the series to even have a remote chance at understanding what's going on, and even if you have, the plot is very confused and full of inconcistencies. It's not really interesting either, and this is coming from someone who had no trouble understanding the plot of the first two games and found them serviceable. Still, Lightning gets some funny lines here and there, so it's not all bad.

The music is alright. It reuses a lot of tracks from the previous two games, and the new tracks aren't remarkable, except for one or two.

Graphically, the game looks great in some areas, and pretty mediocre in others. It's nothing eye-scorching, but it is a downgrade from the first game, and feels like a downgrade from the second game, tough I'm not certain about that.


Overall, I'd rate this game a 6/10. If you liked the previous two games, and can get past the doomsday timer (which isn't that big of a deal) and monster extinction stuff, you could be in for a fun time, but don't expect anything amazing. The 16€ pricetag isn't too redihibitory either, which works in the game's favor.

35181643.review:
Rating: 6.5/10
Genre: Third Person, real-time RPG

The Good:
+ Graphics and presentation. 

+ The combat system has been overhauled from previous entries. Combat now plays out in real-time. You can equip up to 3 outfits. Within each outfit you can equip a weapon, shield, accessories and abilities. Within combat you can freely switch between outfits. Like previous entries, how you setup before battle is more important than the actual battle. 

+ This is a very non-linear game as you can tackle any main/side quests in any order you prefer.  

+ Among the F13 trilogy this is the best optimized game, it does have some problems but compared to the nightmare that was FF13-2 this is a massive improvement. 


The Average:

+/- The game features a time limit in which you must accomplish as many main/side quests as possible before the day ends. You are originally given 6 days to complete everything however you can extend this by completing as many quests as you can. You are also given the ability to freeze time for a few short minutes, however you are only given a limited number of uses and must kill enemies to restore how often you can use the ability. Given that the story is about the world ending, it makes sense from a gameplay perspective but the mechanic becomes a bit tiresome after a while. 

+/-The story, to no surprise is a convoluted mess. You must play FF13-2 and to a lesser degree FF13 to have any understanding of what is happening. I got the impression the developers had no idea where to take the story after FF13 so they started making things up on the go. The story is held together by strong presentation and voice acting.

+/- You are presented with two difficulty options, easy and normal. Normal is too difficult especially for a first playthrough and easy is very easy outside of optional bosses.    

+/- Killing enemies doesn’t reward you with anything other than recharging your meter so that you can use certain abilities and granting you skills to customize your character. Once you have the skills you want there is little incentive to kill enemies.

The Bad:
- You must complete side quests to level up stats. To complete side quests, you must be at the right place at the right time and sometimes meet other conditions. This becomes very problematic because its so easy to miss quests often resulting in using a guide to help you.  Almost every side quest is some variation of a fetch quest and the game gives very little or no helpful advice in how to complete any of them. Given the importance of side quests, a better system really needs to be in place. 

Conclusion:
Square finally made a competent final fantasy port and to their credit, are not afraid to try new ideas rather than rehashing the same old things, sadly not every idea is a winner. This game is completely different from the previous games and given the new mechanics this is one of those games where you either love it or hate it.

35014283.review:
I don't really have words for how wonky and utterly bizarre a game Lightning Returns is in the landscape of Final Fantasy titles. Utterly incomprehensible in its monolothic culmination of three titles of nonsensical stories, Lightning Return continues Final Fantasy 13's grand legacy, yet fails to match the same gameplay and graphical excellence of previous titles. 

The Sidequests are so utterly removed from logic that the stories are frequentably laughable and nigh impossible to even take seriously, but it's difficult to match when watching the idiotic movement patterns of NPCs and the constant clipping of gear. There's often fuel for hilarity during the very cutscenes that contain the sidequests and story when wearing costumes made of Moogles, with mustache, tophats, and countless other ridiculous accenting items and costumes, watching as NPCs are jostled and knocked about by the milling patterns of surrounding NPCS, 

There's a distinct sense that the game didn't have enough time to be developed and that shines through every facet of the design. The very doomsday counter that looms over the player's head is easily ignored when stopping time through a single skill implemented from the start, grinding big  monsters for EP to spend on its usage after abusing gear provided from DLC. This grind continues into the rest of the game, whether it be doing fetch quests, or extincting entire species after felling countless creatures as you traverse an open world. 

This is all despite having a detailed customization system of costumes and large number of skills ranging from debuffing, blocking, physical attacks, and spells, with room for gear and accessories to add stat bonuses and buffs to the gameplay. Each costume and often has its own buffs and debuffs and a specialized use towards what skills would be best to use with them, some even transforming based on the costume or weapon used. The level of detail can, at times, be staggering and overwhelming. 

But even with this and a hybrid real time, command-based battle system involving staggering foes, ultimately one doesn't even need to change strategy and consequently battles don't really amount to much, which is likely why the extinction system even exists. The very rare opportunity to need to change costumes and customization settings only comes from the occasional boss and large-scale monsters, leaving the player with a wealth of time otherwise spent grinding and questing as opposed to having challenging gameplay. 

So, why am I leaving a positive review? In spite of, or perhaps because of these reasons, this game is enthralling. Maybe it's because the game's wonkiness is endearing, whether it be for comedy or for the strangely emotional motivations for the characters. Maybe it's because each costume referencing previous titles, there's always a fun easter egg or two to enjoy while running around and slaying monsters. Maybe it's because playing Final Fantasy 13's game have weakened me. Or maybe it's because it's an absolute joy to play in a Final Fantasy game, customizing, exploring, and operating as I choose in an open world, off the rails that most every Final Fantasy game has kept us on to some extent. In spite of many flaws, I've been enjoying what may easily be the strangest, most unhinged title in the series. So approach with caution and buy on sale.

TLDR: Weird, hilarious, grindy, but unpredictable, with open world, easter eggs, high customization, and player choice for how to utilize their time. Buy on sale and approach with caution, mileage may vary, but can be enjoyable dependant on the person and their taste.

Different

The world ends soon and since God only can create things not souls you need to save as many as you can by doing stuff for people. If you break it down to the core you basically do a lot of miniquests under time constraints.

The time limit is prolly one of the major reasons this got shit on so much. Normally im not a fan either but it works for this game. Theres no intricate schedules for everything like in Majoras Mask, but things change and it creates a sense of urgency and impeding doom the game really wouldnt have otherwise if you could just fart around at leisure. Its quite generous anyway (having some practice from having played this on PS3 i ended up having several days with nothing to do anymore) and in the worst case you get to start over and keep your stuff and stats.

The combat system is different from the usual FF stuff too in that theres no party, you instead can switch anytime between 3 equipment slots with their own ATB Bars. The only thing inherent to Lighting are some special skills otherwise everything from weapons to "armor" to magic and physical attack and defense skills can be freely customized with those slots, you got free reign to make the most garbage and most op setups imaginable.

Another difference is that you dont level, there are no XP Points. You get stat increases from finishing quests. Those can be done more or less anytime in any order you want.  There are the big main ones you have to finish within the time limit to at least not get a game over (Quest chains with a boss and big expensive Final Fantasy cutscene at the end), side quests with either abit of story and background lore attached to em (not all available right away, dependant on which day youre on and somesuch), and plain old dime a dozen Fetch/kill quests from message boards (mostly more unlock the farther youre into the game).

Following the "No XP", how enemies come into play is abit different too. They drop stuff and money like in any other FF but the most important resource from them is probably replenishing your special magic points. Whats so important about the special magic points? One of the special magic abilities is a limited timestop youll have to rely on if you want to get more than the basic minimum of quests done. At the start you fight monsters to get by - In the later stages of the game youre basically a vampire harvesting them to fuel your time juice addiction. Also Monsters can go extinct - the last of its kind will be a supermook dropping good stuff but that also means you risk having places with nothing to feast on if you kill everything indiscriminately.

Think it also got abit of flak for Lighting being kinda sullen all the time. I dont mind - it fits the character and setting and its not like FF has always had the bestest Protagonists ever (Heyo Squall). Maybe id care more if i had played the other two games where they got all their development and backstories, my fault i guess.

In closing, i like this game alot but it might not be for everyone. Maybe if its on sale give it a try :o

The game is simply failed potential that also somehow manages to ruin everything that makes RPG gameplay fun while adding everything that makes MMOs boring and repetitive as hell. For starters, the combat system is fun, fast paced, rewards proper timing and strategy and the time limit mechanics are interesting and well implemented.

Sadly the game fails to take advantage of this entirely by reducing 80% of the content to boring fetch quests, most of which either don't involve combat at all (find item X in the field, talk to person Y) or require you to farm X amount of item MMO style, almost none of those involve fighting unique enemies or optional bosses. Even worse, instead of leveling up, you get stat bonuses only from those quests so you get punished for not doing them, so "just don't do them if you don't like them" is not really an option.

Rewards from combat are only recharging your EP (resource used to stop time, teleport, etc.), gil (which is mostly useless outside of new game+, you get way more than you need and barely ever upgrade your equipment) and skills of a certain level, which is determined by how far in the game you are. However, the game has a mechanic that allows for complete extermination of a monster species, meaning that if you do too much combat early on, you screw yourself out of some higher level skills late in the game. In other words, actually beating up monsters outside of getting quest items or new game+(if you can tolerate the game twice) is mostly a waste of time.

The remaining 20% of the game are 5 main quests, 1 of those is also nothing but a fetch quest series and 4 with a boss at the end. 2 of those have an extremely linear dungeon after doing fetch quests to access the dungeon, 1 that's basically an open room with a boss inside after a series of more fetch quests and one that actually has a complex layout and could be considered well designed.

In other words, avoid this game like the plague if you like boss battles or any sort of dungeon exploring - there are only 9 bosses in the whole game, 2 of them are regular enemies fought later on by the dozens, 4 quest bosses, the final boss and 2 superbosses. The rest of the game is spent running around giving items to NPCs or slaughtering weak monsters for quest items to give to NPCs. Pretty much a complete waste of a great combat system, as the game gives you barely any interesting enemies to fight.

There is also a new game+ options and a hard mode, the issue here is that you can't play hard mode without new game+, which means carrying over almost everything from the previous playthrough to the point where the vast majority of Hard is easier than a 1st playthrough of Normal, which kind of ruins the point of having a Hard mode. Gave up on the game at that point, would honestly rather drink a bottle of drain cleaner than suffer through the game again.

Go ahead and buy this if you like fetch quests, if you want a well designed quality RPG with content that isn't mostly filler, go look elsewhere.

33533037.review:
"Dear Lightning,

How's it going?  Good?  I hope so.  You might not know this, but I've been playing your trilogy for the past seven years if you can believe it.  Yeah, it sounds far-fetched, but I ended up becoming quite attached to this black sheep in a sea of white wool.  As for why, well, that's hard to say.  It could be that I was so enchanted by Hamauzu's themes that guided me down that long hallway, or perhaps it was the various interesting combat systems you had in place.  Ironically, though, and I suppose it's a bit embarrassing as well, but I've never beaten any of your games.  I have several dozen hours in XIII and LR, but for one reason or another I always stopped when I was getting close.

Then Square announced that your games were coming to PC, and with graphical enhancements even, and I was stoked.  And how could I not be?  While they weren't necessarily my favorite games in the series, they were essentially a second chance for me to beat these games that I put on hold back on consoles...

...but I don't think anyone was expecting the ports to be that bad.  Horrid, even.  Poor options menus, frame skipping (even on >recommended specs), crashing and bugs- XIII and XIII-2's ports were nothing short of abysmal and we really only have durante to thank for the fact that people are willing to give them a shot on PC today.  Then Lightning Returns came around.

LR's always been my favorite in the series, Light.  I'm a sucker for Action RPGs after all, and the garb/skill customization was fun as hell.  It was a lot of what I wanted out of ARPGs in a time when none were really willing to the distance, and even now it's pretty easy for me to get sucked back into this game whenever I reinstall and boot it up.  And even better, and shocking even, was that the port of this game blew the other two absolutely out of the water.  Support for Windowless Bordered, 60FPS, built-in options menu (still a bit cheap but leaps and bounds ahead of its predecessors)- it wasn't the perfect point, and the right conditions, such as populated areas or strong particle effects can slow down the game.

But Light, we gotta talk.  We have problems.  And those problems are you.

I liked you in XIII.  Somehow.  That game wasn't exactly written like Shakespeare but I liked it and I liked you.  And in this game, I...tolerated you.  Look, it's neat that your game wants to present these ideas of existentialism, how "good" is subjective and can be easily corroded and corrupted, and a fair amount of other subjects that it liked to preach- that it liked [i]you[/i] to preach, but it's done in the least interesting way possible.  Every loading screen is filled with monologs going on about what happened and the nature of why it happened, every happening creates a drawn out ponderance, and while normally I'd just be able to ignore it, this is how the game is supposed to make us bond with you.  You, the one consistent character throughout this entire game outside of Hope, who I can only assume was turned back into a child to fulfill some fan clamoring...somewhere.  There's also Lumina.  She's a thing.

This might all seem a little harsh and the fact that I'm recommending your game even still probably seems insane, as it should, because a lot of the value that this game tries to create in regards to the viewer is emotional.  Largely, it's meant to build on everything that's happened over the course of the last two games and really bring things to a head for the characters found here.  And it doesn't really work.  Admittedly, people who actually were fans of the first two games will find some investment here, moreso if they liked the characters.  But the problem comes with the fact that you're more of an observer than anything else.   Most scenes play out with you gasping as if you...display emotion?  And your performance overall is rather one-note.  This makes these "emotional moments" fall flat because there's no build-up, no climax.  And this really carries over into the side quests, too, despite a fair number of their premises being particularly alright.  Each quest felt like I was doing it because it was there and I gained benefits from it rather than wanting to do it to see the story proceed, even if I was listening to all the dialogue.

That said, the gameplay's pretty great.  Props to the developers for somehow managing to retool the systems that were in place in the predecessors and turning it into a competent, if a little unique, Action RPG that I'd recommend any day.  For someone like me who's always looking for variety in a genre that has no right to be the same, this certainly scratches an itch.  Being able to create your own character builds and the control you're given with which to do so offers enough option that it can be surprisingly engaging, even on replays.

For instance, back on console I generally went for 3 builds that covered all the bases while doing as much damage as possible: one for magic, one for physical damage, and one that was a mix of the two.  When I came to PC I decided to play a bit more with the efficiency game, making a build for each elemental weakness.  What made this fun, though, was that they weren't all the same with simply different elements.  My fire build had an emphasis on dealing as much ranged magic as possible, meanwhile my wind build was evasive and only used ranged magic as a means to chain into my dodges, but otherwise it was focused on using wind-based physical attacks.  Because even though the game could most certainly be wider than it is, the amount of freedom that's here is a hell of a lot of fun to play around with.

Another ball in your court, I actually liked the world here, too.  Some areas were just plain comfy to be in, the scale of others was quite massive and just fun to explore.  While the stories told in these locations weren't always the most interesting, the world and the gameplay made them fun to do, regardless.  And while some may begrudge the time limit, for me it just made it feel as if there was always something to do.  I had zero problems with it myself, I never really felt particularly rushed and finished with all the story content several days ahead of time simply because the timer isn't particularly strict.  And more than that, there are a lot of fun small things here.  Like how, if left unattended, monsters can kill animals/people, and in some cases, people can kill monsters.  And how you can slide on sand (oh I had a field day with that).  And the amount of life that in the more populated parts of the world- but even if you weren't in the city or at a settlement it never really feels lonely because people are always out and about.

It's just a good time.  I've very select things to say about the story but as a fan of XIII up to this point, despite their being disappointing for the most part, I was nonetheless all the way through.  But there's enough here even if I didn't like the other two games that I could still play this and recommend it to most people.  It's a bizarre mix of FFXIII and Majora's Mask but it works better than any sane combination of these two games should.  But it does, Light, and you've got a good product here.  People should buy this, even at full price it's cheap (and a hell of a lot cheaper than it was at launch), but they should get it on sale if they're undecided since it gets pretty low.

Oh, and while you're at it, please tell Square to stop shoving you into every goddamn product.  You're cool and all but I'm pretty sure this counts as abuse.

Anyway, see ya in Dissidia."

So, where should I start?

I absolutely LOVE this game. This is one of my favorite games ever, and though people seem to point out certain mechanics as awful, it's still an opinion and all people don't like the same thing. But as all reviews this is my opinion on this game.

To start of, the fighting mechanics in this game are interesting, they have basically thrown together hack and slash with some kind of turn based fighting. Many different monsters to fight and items to obtain. Some monsters are more vulnerable to different elements, for example ice is extremely vulnerable to fire and so on. Each enemy has it's own weakness and it's always fun to experiment. Slay all monsters of one species to exterminate those kind of monsters.

Then the overall level design is okay, I mean it's outdated graphics from today but if you don't have any big of an issue with graphics then it shouldn't even matter. The cities are pretty and it's fun running around on open fields and mountains.

The quests in this game may be a little confusing, though if you make sure to stay in touch with the dialogue then it shouldn't be problem really. There aren't an endless amount of quest, and the explanation will com later.

Story was really good. I haven't felt like following the story and lore of a game before, not on this level anyways. People may think of it as boring, and you and if you're going to play this one you should play XIII and XIII-2 first. If you care about the story, that is.

Now over to the mechanic most people seem to dislike. The timer. Yes, you have a timer to complete the game on, and in most cases I don't have a problem with that. It just makes that game a little more challenging. Complete quests to increase the timer, thus giving you more time to do everything. That's why there aren't millions of side quests, they give you a considerable amount of quests to be able to complete the game in time. As simple as that. This is why people vote it negative, and so I'm going to say DON'T buy the game if you have problems with timers and such. As it will probably stress you out most of the time.

The difficulty of the game, can be increased or decreased depending on how good you are at games. It can be very easy sometimes, and then dramatically get a lot more difficult. See for yourself.

Technical difficulties? I don't understand what people are talking about when they say stuttering and such. I didn't have any problem with this game. I don't remember if I played on 30 or 60 fps, but people are seriously angry that they have to play on 30 fps. Like what? It is a port from ps3 what did you expect? Anyways if you have trouble looking on a screen with 30 fps then don't play it. Recommendation: play with a controller. Since it is a port from console don't expect it to work well with keyboard and mouse!

Anything else? Oh yeah! The soundtrack in this game... it's nothing like you will ever come across again! It's amazing! It could be worth buying the soundtrack from a game like this. Seriously, The soundtrack is really good.

There you have my own personal opinion on this game. As you may have noticed, I love this game and always will. You can put hours in this game and that makes it a longer lasting experience. Have fun with it if you consider buying it!

La banda sonora resume temas de los dos anteriores juegos y añade otros nuevos bastante variados. No es top y ni se puede comparar con nobuo pero, es pasable con algun tema interesante sin mucho mas que decir.

En resumen, el juego para mi hace aguas porque tiene puntos muy peculiares que para algunos les puedes parecer un acierto y para otros una contra, como en mi caso. Se nota que lo sacaron para ganarse una pelas extras mientras hacian tiempo para trabajar con el FFXV. El juego se hace muy pesado y la mayoria del tiempo es completar secundarias como un loco con una historia donde no hay mas que contar. Eso si, por lo menos el ending es interesante y bastante largo.

The final entry in the 13 saga and all I can really say is, "I'm glad it's over."

Depending on the game mechanics you prefer and whether or not you like dressing a woman up, Lightning Returns is arguably the best in the 13 series-- take heed however: This is saying very little as 13 itself has very few redeeming qualities aside from the graphics and 13-2 is only marginally better. 

Try as I might I cannot connect with any character this series has presented me with; I just don't care what happens to them or why. The sad part is that buried beneath the trivialities that this series presents you with is actually reasonably decent lore, but it's never /really/ presented to you in the narrative of the game itself. It's largely hidden away in menu documentation.

Combat in this game feels like a chore. I have never been excited by an encounter nor felt rewarded for overcoming it. The most common reaction being, "Oh, this guy again." It feels as though the only reason it exists at all is because without it there would be no gameplay at all-- just a series of mundane [and often times idiotic] collect-x and kill-y quests. Most of the people you end up 'saving'-- ironically via your actions rather than theirs, you could not possibly care less about and their processes of redemption are dubious at best.

I keep tying to force my way through this game on the PC, but every time I sit down and play it for an hour or two I realize I have more entertaining things to do... like mow the lawn.

To me the series, including this entry, will always serve as an example of what not to do: turning reasonable story and lore into the most mundane experience possible by focusing on style at the heavy expense of substance.

As with all reviews, take this one with a grain of salt-- you might find that you really enjoy this game and the series, but to me, for the money, there is an almost endless supply of better games in the genre.

31387090.review:
Lightning returns se siente como un final digno para la subsaga XIII de final fantasy, se cierran todas las historias de los personajes principales. Jugablemente es el más experimental y diferente de los tres, aunque algunas de las mecánicas nuevas no funcionan del todo bien, aun así, como conjunto el juego es bastante solido. Si ya jugaste los anteriores y te gustaron, es casi obligatorio que juegues la conclusión.

Es un requisito hablar del port como primer punto si se analiza un juego japonés, en este caso con mayor razón, porque tanto el xiii y xiii-2 tenían ports que dejaban mucho que desear,  lightning returns sin embargo, tiene un port decente, en un principio pensaba que el juego no disponía de opciones gráficas, grande fue mi sorpresa al notar que se encontraban en la parte alta de la ventana, como si de un emulador se tratase, fuera de la presentación algo cutre, las opciones graficas esta vez son bastante amplias, y el port en si funciona excelente, no se libra de bajones en momentos específicos, pero en términos generales, en esta ocasión el port no es para nada un punto negativo.

Mecánicamente es el juego que más se aleja de las anteriores entregas de la sugsaga XIII, ahora tenemos un mundo abierto a nuestra disposición, dividido en 4 áreas, con día y noche, y un reloj que nos estará indicando siempre la hora en la que nos encontramos, y es sobre el tiempo que gira le mecánica principal del juego, tendremos inicialmente 5 días para completar las quest principales (tiempo del juego), pero que podremos ampliar haciendo misiones secundarias, que nos dan los NPC que nos encontraremos regados por el mapa, algunos solo aparecerán en horas específicas, las cuales tienen en varios casos una historia interesante de seguir, pero que se limitan a ser misiones de ve y tráeme, por contraparte las quest principales son pocas, pero están mucho más elaboradas. En combate esta ocasión solo usaremos a lightning, aunque podremos cambiar durante las peleas entre tres trajes que tengamos equipados, hay varias decenas de trajes a desbloquear, incluidos los de los DLC, se incluyeron todos en la versión de PC excepto el de aerith, cosa que no entiendo, ya que el personaje es de su autoría, no hay excusa de licencia, cada uno de estos trajes es completamente personalizable, desde el arma, escudo, y las 4 habilidades, la única diferencia entre los trajes es, aparte del aspecto, algunas pasivas especiales, y 1 o 2 habilidades ligadas. Hablando del combate, ahora es más parecido a un hack n slash que a un jrpg tradicional, ya no tienes que elegir la acción que quieras realizar desde una lista, sino que se ejecuta al tiempo que presiones el botón al que esté ligada la habilidad, el uso de estas gasta una barra de estamina, cada uno de los tres trajes que llevamos equipados tiene una barra propia, lo cual hace que tengamos que estar alternando entre trajes para que se recargue la barra del traje que acabamos de utilizar, tendremos habilidades ofensivas, tanto físicas como mágicas y las guardias, que sirven para mitigar el daño enemigo, o en caso de hacerlo con un timing perfecto aturdirlos. En general estos cambios pueden llegar a sentirse intimidantes al inicio, sobre todo el límite de tiempo, puede llegar a agobiarte, pero si haces una planificación mínima de lo que vas a hacer durante los días y haces varias secundarias, al final te sobraran días, una vez te adaptas a las mecánicas nuevas, el juego se vuelve muy divertido. 

La historia se desarrolla 500 años después del final del xiii-2, la gente desde ese entonces dejo de envejecer, aunque si pueden morir de enfermedades o accidentes, algo así como una inmortalidad a medias, y ya no nacen nuevos seres humanos, aparte de eso el caos empezó a consumir el mundo poco a poco, llevándolo a su inminente final, Lightning es despertada de su sueño de cristal por el Dios de la luz, bhunivelze, quien la envía como su redentor al mundo, días antes de que este llegue a su final, para que salve el mayor número de almas posibles, para transportarlas a un nuevo mundo que el mismo creara. La inmortalidad es un tema que siempre me ha llamado la atención, y si bien no está tocado de manera profunda en este juego, sí que hay cosas interesantes que ver, como lo cansadas que están de vivir muchas personas, o Yusnaan una ciudad que vive de fiesta todo el tiempo esperando el fin del mundo, como si de una celebración se tratase. Regresan los personajes principales de las entregas previas y se le da un cierre a la historia de cada uno de ellos, casi no se deja ningún cabo suelto, se siente como un final bonito de ver, y un gran cierre para esta aventura que se extendió a lo largo de tres juegos.

Graficamente es un poco inconsistente, los escenarios son sencillos en cuanto a detalles, pero tienen vistas que son hermosas, los modelados de los personajes principales siguen igual de impresionantes que en el primer título, pero el de los secundarios deja bastante que desear, y en esta ocasión es más evidente, porque interactúas bastante con ellos. El Ost por otra parte es magnífico como cabe esperar de cualquier final fantasy, regresan muchas canciones de los dos juegos previos, pero se agregan suficientes novedades como para sentirlo fresco.

Para terminar, empecé esta trilogía con muy pocas expectativas, dado el odio de los fans de la franquicia, y si bien no son juegos perfectos, al terminar de ver la escena post créditos de Lightning returns, el unico sentimiento que me quedo fue de satisfacción, disfrute mucho de las más de 140 horas que me dieron los tres títulos de la subsaga XIII de Final Fantasy, y para mí con eso es suficiente para recomendarlos.

31218811.review:
TL;DR: A criminally underrated game (due to much hatred for the FF 13 series) that feels fun, fluid and like a breath of fresh air in the stale genre of RPGS and JRPGs, with only few flaws in it's foundation.

[b] (Light (lol) spoilers ahead) [/b]

Let me first say that this might be a pretty long review. I am a huge fan of the FF 13 series - that is a statement that many people would already gut me for, seeing how saying that you like the 13 series is equal to commiting treason. I never found a reason to dislike it though - but this is a review for the third installment in that series, not an autobiography about my (maybe bad?) taste in video games.

After the events of 13-2, Lightning awakes out of her crystal slumber and finds out that the world succumbed to chaos. She is then tasked by god to save the remaining souls of the world, so that he may build a new world where all the souls she saved are reborn. From then on, Lightning plays the role of the savior, saving souls and people for the sole reason of guiding them to a new world before the current one dies after the 13th day - and the ultimate hope of God keeping his promise, the resurrection of Lightnings sister Serah in return for her work.

I like the story - it keeps you on your toes, has a few twists and turns and, if you played the old FF 13 games, follows old and working conventions. The side quests of the game are very interesting, in my opinion, as most of them have their own lesson to teach you about life, love and the inevitability of death. Time is important, and how you use it even more so - the game runs on a clock which makes you plan your every move ahead of time.

From then on, you run around in 4 open areas, following main quests, meeting old and well-known characters, fulfilling plenty of side quests to save the souls of the inhabitants of the world and battle monsters.

The battle system of FF 13-3: LR is a pretty unique one. You can switch between 3 garbs (think, classes) in battle, slinging spells and attacking the enemy head-on in an active battle system. Before the battle, you create schematas, consisting of a garb, a weapon, a shield, two accessories and 4 spells/attacks, between which you can then change in battle, depending on your needs.

I wish I could review all elements of the game in depth; since my review can't be THAT long, however, I will list my personal pros and cons of this game here and then drop a quick conclusion and rating.

[b] Pro: [/b]
- The battle System feels fun and fluid. You constantly guard from enemy attacks and attack when you have an opening
- Over 80 different garbs with different attributes and basic spells ensure there is a battle style (or three!) for everyone
- Every enemy has different behaviours, stagger requirements (essentially starting a phase where the enemy can't attack and you deal increased damage) and attacks
- The game offers the right amount of challenge
- Beautiful music all throughout the game
- The time mechanic, while not liked by many, actually makes the game so much better. It is lenient - you will have enough time to do everything in the game as long as you aren't too lazy - but keeps you on your toes and makes you plan ahead, which I personally loved
- Interesting story, though if you haven't liked the story of the two previous games, chances are this won't change, but it's unconventional for sure

[b] Con: [/b]

- The improvement system for weapons and shields is restricted to New Game +, something I don't really understand. Until then, improving your equipment is not possible.
- While many of the garbs look and sound cool, not all of them are equally effective and many of them are downright useless and will never be used by anyone. Some garbs are just objectively better than many others
- Some of the fights require certain stagger strategies; while that is not bad as far as tactics go, it is sometimes unclear why exactly you can't stagger an enemy, even if the enemy menu tells you what you have to do. Some fights rely on staggering too much, which can be annoying (but also makes it a bit more tactical)
- There aren't many enemy varieties in the game - unlike FF 13 which had tons of different enemy models, there are only a handful found in this game, some even recolored; though the models are still very detailed and a joy to look at
- While the voice acting of the main characters is fine as usual (in my opinion), the many side characters can't offer the same level of consistency - they are often just bad or average

- If you haven't played the previous two games, chances are you will miss a lot of references and can't connect to the characters as well
