30933971.review:
[b]Overview[/b]
Lightning Returns is a mixed bag for me. I really like some of the game's’ mechanics. I dig the combat and the timed nature of the game, that forces you to think about what quests to do in what order. The combat is fun, and discovering good builds and combination was imo the best part of the game. However, there are many problems with this game, and I can’t honestly tell if I love or hate it after 120+ hours. I can say I thoroughly enjoyed many hours, and endured some through sheer stubbornness. I’ve only seriously played FF4, FF8 and FF10, so my knowledge about the series as a whole is limited. I played a bit of FF13-1 and FF13-2 but I didn’t at all like their mechanics. Lightning Returns (LR) has better mechanics than both, and I can recommend the game based on that alone, as long as you have low expectations elsewhere. I picked it up because I knew it had majora’s Mask mechanics, which was neat. PC ports are also cheaper than on console! 

[b]Slightly Passive-Aggressive Rant about Open World and LR[/b]
FF to me means a story well told with a casual fun approach to turn-based combat. LR partially succeeds by merging turn based combat with timed “world time”. I like this idea since it adds urgency to the plot. Speaking of plot,  the story is really poor in its execution, and suffers from its attempt at being open world. As "The Savior", Lightning must save souls by helping people in need, as  sh*tty MMO quests. In the Witcher 3, most of the enjoyment I had was the fun I had was side quests, because the dialog entertaining and (sometimes) had real impact on the main story. Additionally, Gerald provides a service not easily substituted. Lightning, Demigod by trade,  does mundane tasks I’m supposed to believe  literally saves soul from the dying world. Imagine someone doing for you such a favor, that your soul leaves your physical body in salvation because I found your f*cking doll that went missing? Also you go to hell when if it’s the wrong one btw.  This idea does not work well with the majority of the side quests, and many of them could easily have been left out. It is not clear how many side quests are required to not fail on the final day, but the game makes it very clear immediately that you must do  as many side quests as possible. I ended up completing most of them, and they were not worth it. 

[b]Story[/b]
Honestly, I skipped all cutscenes that didn’t revolve around the main plot. After the first few hours I realized that the background story pretty much is that people are biologically immortal, and therefore bored. Since the world is nearing its end, you’d think people be panicking, and grow continually more unstable as the plot escalates. It would even make sense as the final installment in the FF13 trilogy.  However, the world is open and casual in its mood which just doesn’t fit the urgency it so desperately tries to instill. LR would work as entry in the series where you discover much grander plot at the end, opening for sequels. Ironically, I think FF13-1 with that counter would work better as the series’ conclusion.  

This is that one time, where having more grit and sorrow would be useful infuse some humanity into the vacant lot that is my feelings for whatever this game calls a plot. The main story is very short, so while I had little enjoyment, it also didn’t waste much of my time. I wish the LR was more linear and had more playable characters in the party. I didn’t care for any of the characters in the story, because they are so poorly written. I think this is a SE problem rather than LR specifically though. I do appreciate that much of the dialog were voice acted.


[b]Gameplay[/b]
The combat is simple and fun, and is where the game shines. 4 abilities can be mapped at once per costume. Lightning can use 3 costumes per battle you can freely switch between. Each costume comes with at least one ability, and some minor stat bonuses. The costumes are class variations that can be collected or bought at in-game stores. The fanservice is pretty obvious, and it doesn’t make much sense that changing to a different bra somehow makes you more tanky and less proficient with weapons. It would be so much simpler if you could switch between 6-8 classes with, where each class has a unique ability. Instead I have to go through minor class variations that only differs slightly.  It's made so you think there is more content than there actually is, and unnecessary since you already have great control over what abilities to use. That said, the best part of the game is making a setup that works for a hard boss, and succeeding with winning combos. This applies to abilities that can be found as monster drops and leveled up my a merchant. He merges your abilities together. While cool in theory, an xp meter would be so much better, as it doesn’t fill your inventory with HUNDREDS of those.

 I just went from A to B for the otherwise fun combat and light platforming. As an Jak trilogy player I’m used to platforming, and while it did spice up LR’s gameplay, the platforming elements lacked depth and variety, and was only once or twice the fun of the level.  Besides  missing more unique effects on found equipment, the actual gameplay is rather good, I’m just way to p*ssed off about everything else!

[b]UI[/b]
Speaking of p*ssed of, the worst part of LR is how much time you need to spend in the damn menus! About a half the time is spent in menus for the following reasons: 
1) Useful stuff, like planning a route that completes the most side quests, changing gear, and setting abilities. 
2) You’re stuck in poorly thought-out upgrading loop for abilities that you cannot perform in a batch!
3) Pause to activate the temporary time freeze. 

While no. 1) works fine, the overly animated menus take a long time to load, even on a SSD, but I can manage it. No. 3) is really annoying since the time freeze is so short, and I wonder why they didn’t increase the cost and the time so you spend less time in the menus or gave me a shortcut, because it really breaks the flow. While you don't have to freeze time to make it to the end, you do feel incentivized to not waste EP that you gain from battles. This is a lesser issue on higher difficulties.  No. 2) is the worst. It can take a long time to fully level-up an ability, since it can only be done one step at a time, and each step requires enough clicks that I question why I bother with the game when I have to do so. Go watch a video that shows how this is done, I don’t want to bother you with it. 

[b]Misc[/b]
I could go on about the other less important mechanics and features, but they’re honestly not that interesting. Completing battles give you EP which is used for spells (time freeze, escape battle, teleport to map  etc.). There is also a Day/Night cycle influence what quests are active, but it’s more annoying than the immersion is worth. The world in LR is really big, and I wish there were more teleport spots, because lots of traveling on foot/chocobo is needed that also takes time. Lastly, I liked the soundtrack, but I did find it to loop too often.

[b]Conclusion[/b]
The end of the world in a finite time as a hard failure state is a nice excuse to force tension, but only if you have a reason  to give a f*ck about the story or the characters, which I don’t, because the characters and plot are boring, predicable and monologuing.  Additionally, LR has an annoying tendency to to force you pause the game to do mundane tasks that I’d wish weren’t to important for my progression to skip.
I like the combat, and the occasional platforming had its moments.

All in all, I’d recommend the game on the basis that if you aren’t bothered by menus, and can play a game solely for its mechanics, you might still have a good time. The story isn’t worth the effort, just skip the cutscenes unrelated to the main story which is also rather short compared to the time spent doing sidequests, which is most of the content.

The combat mechanics are interesting and an improvement over the previous games for the most part. The story is basic and predictable for anyone who played the previous two installments in the FFXIII trilogy, but reads more like a DLC than a full title. I have three main complaints about the gameplay:

1. New Game + (loading the post-credits autosave of a playthrough) is required to unlock equipment upgrading. Hard mode is required in addition to that for tiers 4, 5, and ★ of abilities as well as fully upgrading your stuff.

2. Garb-locked, non-upgradeable abilities mean that late game you're likely either burning an ability slot for a useful passive (Equilibrium+) or selecting a sub-par or nonexistent passive to avoid wasting an ability slot (Stone and Sand). I don't like the design of 90% of them either, but I wasn't a fan of costume design in the other titles either so no surprises there.

3. Time only serves as a speed bump to quest completion. Many people only exist for 4 hours every day, and some must be talked to on up to 4 separate days. The game doesn't tell you when these people are available unless it's for a main quest, and none have an in-game reason to withhold their dialogue for several days.

Overall, it's a decently fun 20 hour game stretched to a questionable 30 hours for a perfect single run and ridiculous hundreds of hours for the completionist (Easy->Normal->Hard->Hard->Hard etc. until all equipment and abilities are fully upgraded). Like many sequels, the reviews improve as the series wears on and loses the less committed fans, but don't let that fool you into thinking this is a good game.

30247579.review:
TLDR  I would recommend it especially as the game (trilogy) seems to go on sale often enough to warrant playing through them for 3 different gaming experiences that are loosely connected together by its characters.  Just remember you should approach this game for the fun/experience rather than the storyline so try your best to do a completely blind play through and ignore that RPG inclination to grind out and play "perfectly" using a strategy guide.

Gameplay is the game's strongest point and yet it doesn't get as much attention among the critics harping on the downsides of the game.  The overworld isn't a hallway like the first game's first half and feels more like an actual world than the disjointed mess accessed through a hub that was the second game.  As you get to the later part of the game you unlock connections to the areas and see how the world fits together.  Enemies run around the overworld, who can mostly be avoided by jumping or sprinting past them.  You can also use your weapon to smack them for a sizable chunk of their hp before the battle even begins but being ambushed unaware will result in you receiving a penalty instead when entering the battle.  Overall it's easy to constantly fight if you need or choose to avoid battles if you don't (except in very few cases or a few enemies types) so I didn't get that RNG frustration from replaying older FF titles.

Let's talk briefly about the "doomsday clock" that people refuse to wrap their head around and immediately toss the game aside.  The Eradia system is the center of the resource management in this game, if you've played other action RPG games like Risen, Witcher or even Dark Souls, then you know how that plays in to the depth.  The battle system doesn't reward any experience for character level ups instead it gives you items/abilities, gil and Eradia points (EP) which you use to freeze the clock. You'll learn quickly that the tougher encounters give more EP and you're hit with a learning curve in either grinding out weaklings until extinct or suck it up and learn the tougher enemies without taking damage (as recovery items are limited) while balancing the tradeoffs of using powerful Eradia abilities in battle. This would be Final Fantasy's take on pushing the Action-RPG aspects in Turnbased combat to its limit with lots of reactions and swapping around.  After the steep learning curve even with its abundance of tutorials will require some practice to get used to and if you're playing on normal or Hard mode (NG+ only), reaction time and keeping track of the enemies' animations play a huge role to success.  Keeping track of where to restock EP and recovery items properly setting up for each battle where even common large enemies feel like minibosses to hunt down EP while staying alert to battle mechanics feels rewarding.  

If you're looking for a relatively less taxing experience easy mode is there that gives you passive HP regen and tons of EP that you can help finish every side quest and misc quest without the resource management needed to wander around aimlessly.  Remember that no matter what you do - even if you squander all your time away and ignoring Chronofreeze and the clock, you still retain all items, stat increases, gil and starting over from the beginning of the clock.  You can skip all the cinematic and avoid most battles if you don't need them so it's not frustrating rushing through areas you'll be overleveled for by avoiding all the trash enemies and getting extra gil for later. If you're a completionist then you'll be doing a Hard playthrough afterwards where it unlocks an item upgrade/crafting system and more into the spell leveling system and unlocks more items for the added difficulty.  Having many or all the sidequests complete gives you a sizable boost in stats and more equipment so it helps in reaching the different stagger conditions and launching and floating strategies which aren't explained much outside of experimentation.

The Controls on the PC Steam version is keyboard only as there are no options for using your mouse for moving the camera so you will have to getting used to using both hands on the keyboard for gameplay even after remapping (I would actually recommend a controller with two analog sticks for sure though).  Unfortunately this meant the camera would create some frustrating experiences in a "Gary" designed level based around platforming over time duration floating tiles where you can fall back to the beginning of the dungeon while being slowly poisoned by the dungeon and dealing with hard to avoid fire mages in tight corridors (Yes, I hate the Temple of the Goddess as the culmination of the bad things in this game).

The voice acting is passable (though cringey inducing at times) but there is enough there if you ignore the campy use of Japanese humor and culture.  Lightning Returns is a more than a bit ham-fisted with its religious subtext and the whole Jesus resurrection and Moses leading his people across the Red Sea but I did find myself interested enough in the returning cast to drive on through the narrative even if some events would make me scoff in passing.  The sidequests range from pretty good to extremely pointless drivel with very little inbetween.  The main story arcs don't have any great twists or surprises  which might seem like a negative to others but it was mildly satisfying moving through the light drama without feeling like the rug is being pulled out from beneath you.  It fails to meet expectations if you're here for the story but at least they tried to tie all the loose ends together.

The ending quickly devolves into a slew of anime tropes - just think Gundam, meets Power Rangers, meets the Dragonball Z yet the very final twist was satisfying for me at least because the uncharacteristic vibe from Lightning.  It didn't feel a need to explain the new game plus mechanic outside of one nod of dialogue which is totally fine with me because reasons I stated above in the gameplay section.  It's not exceptional in anyway and much of it is to justify the gameplay and missions involved but it's a step up from the mess that 2nd game was for sure.

The  cinematics live up to the beautiful FMVs reputations and the flashy elaborate choreography is nice to look at especially at the end.  Toriyama takes a page from his X-2 book and invests a lot into his costumes or garbs in this game with Lightning being clad in some ridiculous outfits.  Unfortunately everything else from character models, area textures and battle animations are just recycled from the previous two games.  This means some costumes don't fit Lightning's head model at all.  Not to mention adornments that seem to be floating around her body when she is the only controllable character in this game simply because they wanted to use these adornments on a variety of other NPCs to help their looks.  This could be considered fine in cutting costs for the game in reusing the perfectly workable models but with porting a few but creating even fewer new enemies, this creates a very limited set of new enemies that are just reskinned into 2~3 different versions and boss monsters become common enemies to add to only 35 or so variety of enemies.  The tacted on feel doesn't stop there as you see the same attack animations for a large variety of skills even if they have different effects.  The entire "last ones" quest and even their rewards are just the assets with their texture stripped so they appear weirdly purple/pink rather than bothering to reskin them or giving them an aura of some sort.  Music is all recycled from the previous two games as well - which might be nostalgic for some but I found myself getting all too familiar of the very limited music and sfx variety as well.  I would say the overall visuals and sounds are below average but still passable

29967265.review:
Don't mind the time, I played this game up to the final boss on my brother's computer because my computer's too weak to run it.

Let me start by saying that before I played this game, I knew next to nothing about the Final Fantasy XIII trilogy's story and gameplay. I bought this game hoping to play a good action JRPG, since buying Tales of Symphonia wasn't enough. After hearing that this game had a more real-time approach to the series' turn-based combat, I jumped in.

Lightning Returns: Final Fantasy XIII is a JRPG that defies as many genre conventions as it possibly can, featuring non-linear exploration, a singular protagonist as opposed to a team of six or more, and a mission-based structure akin to a Western RPG. I enjoyed this free reign over where I could go and what I could do, even if it was all under a time limit. In fact, I do actually like the time limit because it gives the game a sense of urgency, adding stakes to the whole 'saving people's souls' thing.

The weakest part of Lightning Returns, in my opinion, is the story. I don't have to know anything about the previous games to know that this story is just stupid. The dialogue is convoluted and forced at times, some of the characters make some odd choices over the course of the story, and the story overall lacks a clear sense of focus. I do think Lightning as a protagonist is compelling, if a bit wish-fulfilling. From the very first cutscene, it's pretty clear what kind of story this is supposed to be, and I can't fault it too much if the writers stopped giving a crap halfway through. 'Tis a shame, though. :/

Lightning Returns as a game, however, is better than I expected. Exploration and mission-based structure aside, the battle system is akin to an infusion of the Tales series and Valkyrie Profile in some respects. Being able to select moves and pressing a single button to execute them sounds simplistic, but the game rewards you for thinking about when to strike instead of mashing buttons all the time. Granted, 90% of my battles consisted of a specific pattern (mash a button until ATB is gone, switch schemata, rinse and repeat), which made most encounters predictably easy, but there are monsters that require you to think a bit. Staggering enemies is a little finicky when you don't know exactly how to do it, especially since no one enemy gets staggered by the same thing.

The schemata system is also compelling, not just in how you can optimize your stats but also customize Lightning's apparel. A wide variety of clothing ranging from elegant to skimpy and weapons ranging from swords to spears gives Lightning various stat boosts and abilities. Some are good, some are not so good. If you plan on beating the final boss, you need to figure out what group of schemata works best for you. Lightning can have up to three Schemata at a time, which is pretty much essential to have if you plan on beating any of the bosses in the game. Personally, I made it through most of the game having one schemata for brute force, one for magic and one that balanced the two yet focused on defense more than attack.

The graphics are top-notch, as expected of Square Enix. The few CG cutscenes in the game are quite well-done, although the in-game engine is not too bad either. Every major character and town has a unique look and feel to it, and although the NPCs get a little samey every now and then, that's to be expected. The music ranges from ambient to bombastic, providing a wide variety of tunes both original and recurring in the series. I didn't really expect the music to be this good, but considering I liked a good deal of XIII-2's soundtrack, it makes sense. My favorite tune in this game is the epic title screen theme (and occasional battle theme), Lightning Returns. It makes a big deal out of her appearing from nowhere after hundreds of years in crystal sleep, doesn't it? :D

Speaking as a casual fan of Final Fantasy, if you have any interest in this kind of game at all, give it a shot. It's definitely different from the classic FFs, but it's certainly an enjoyable game. If you've never played any part of the FFXIII games, I'd say it's okay to start here. The game provides a bit of backstory and a glossary of characters and locations in case you don't know what's going on, but there will be some disconnect since it still kind of expects you to know who these characters are in order for some scenes to connect emotionally with the player. It's still a compelling game if you can look past that, and I give it my full recommendation.

Maybe I should go buy FFXIII after this...

I'll begin by saying I did not complete Lightning Returns and am basing this review only on what I experienced. I had to stop because the story just became too full of itself for me. There are other issues that include the insane amount of fetch quests, the possibly unintended encouragement of massive amounts of saving & loading, and more. The game does have some good parts to it, but they weren’t enough to keep me motivated to push through to the end.

This game has the worst Final Fantasy story I’ve ever experienced. It comes down to the sub-par writing. They tried very hard to have a grand and epic tale only to utterly fail in keeping me invested in what was happening in the story. The situation is dire and Lightning has only 13 days to save as many souls as she can so that she can guide them into the new world before the old dies. She’s able to do all of this because she made a deal to become the chosen savior of Bhunivelze, also known as God, in order to bring back Serah, her dead sister.

The story then becomes a pretentious melodrama that made me roll my eyes and sigh often. Over time, I just grew sick of everything. I couldn’t bring myself to care about the characters anymore due to the awful storytelling. Almost everyone has been tragically suffering for hundreds of years, you’re fighting against fate, the power of love can open doors and save souls inexplicably, Lightning somehow inspires everyone with her eloquence, and frequent conversations take place about God with Hope. It felt like a strange, alternate take on Christianity where Lightning is Jesus and the Chaos that’s killing the world represents Revelations. It could have worked if they just toned down the overdramatic delivery. On the other hand, the regular side-quests had relatively okay writing.

You can find side-quests by talking to people or interacting with the Canvas of Prayers. While the former can sometimes have some writing and voice acting to back it up, mechanically, they’re mostly uninteresting and forgettable fetch quests. You’re going to be collecting X number of ingredients or items, usually with vague instructions or hints because you’re expected to meander around aimlessly. Rarely will you have quest markers to help you out with these boring activities, making them frustrating too. It doesn’t help when time is a precious and limited resource.

You have only 13 days to save as many souls as you can and the in-game timer reflects that and gives the player a sense of urgency. It also serves as a great annoyance. I think it’s completely manageable since the game eventually gives you Chronostasis which allows you to stop the clock for a short amount of time. You do have to spend EP to keep casting it from the menu and more EP can be gained by killing monsters. I think it hurts the pacing of the game since I had to keep on casting it repeatedly when I was exploring or questing. I don’t know why they went with this timer mechanic when they let you stop it. It’s just there to inconvenience you with areas that open and close depending on time of day and the pressure it puts on you in general. I’m not too keen on time management in a game that enjoys being vague.

The timer and the “Normal” difficulty lead to plenty of loading screens since wasted moves or failed battles can lead to a gargantuan loss of time. Being forced to escape from a failed battle means a loss of 1 hour (out of 24) and the game isn’t afraid to throw overwhelming enemies at you from the very beginning. It’s good that the saving and loading process is fairly quick since I would make saves before many encounters depending on health or if I fought it before. I’d also make one before warping to a town at the start of a new day. At least once, I ended up in a town where the quest givers weren’t present yet which meant I couldn’t turn them in, wasting valuable in-game time and real life time (ohoho).

The outfits and costumes are probably the biggest draw of the game. They make zero sense when thinking about the narrative unless Lightning dressed as Cloud is canon now. I enjoyed them for the aesthetics. They also give you access to different abilities. There’s a humongous collection of different outfits, weapons, shields, and head ornaments to wear (it helps that all the DLC items are unlocked from the start). They all make their way into the cutscenes too so you can have some really weird moments depending on what Lightning is wearing. I guess the game isn’t that serious when the main story isn’t involved.
 
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=858375182

I wasn’t too wild about the combat in this game. It’s completely functional, but I couldn’t perfect guard for the life of me. It’s also not the most entertaining type of combat. You just keep track of weaknesses, hit them with attacks until they stagger, and then deal big damage to kill them. You’d think outfit switching during battle would add much more strategy to the game, but they just allow you to fire off more attacks or tank more attacks depending on your Schemata (the classes you make) arrangement. I’d be fonder of it if I could reliably find abilities, but you have to acquire them through treasure spheres or monster drops. Don’t expect to find any in shops or in a skill tree (there isn’t one). I really went into this game wanting to like it.

The FFXIII series i've always seen as a beautiful mess, one that has glimmers of something beautiful from the masterful audio/visual design and inspired story fragments, buried under a web of gameplay issues, bad narrative melodrama and production issues.  The previous entry in the series actually managed to resolve most of these issues and is a legimitely great game in it's own right, but despite the really interesting and unique design choices in this final installment, it felt like it finally collapsed under the weight of a lacking production budget and some recurring issues that you could only see a glimpse of previously.

The time system although an interesting quirk, left me exhausted and unable to stop and smell the flowers and doesn't serve any interesting purpose, the main story is split down the middle between sorta good and utterly terrible, and even the one consistently positive thing you could describe about the game series - the audio/visual experience - has gotten the sledgehammer.  Music is poorly coordinated throughout, ruining the experience of hearing what is the best soundtrack in the series, and there's a lot of embarassingly rough level designs and re-use of textures and models that really belonged in the N64 era, ruining what crafted visual design and planning there clearly was before their level design interns got their hands on it.  This series if nothing else captured atmosphere and mood really well, and it's now just an infrequent visitor.

If you're still reading (congrats) and think, "I don't care, what about the gameplay?" or are someone that really likes JRPGs generally, then the combat is well designed and consistently enjoyable and although nearly all of the side-quests are of a "MMO mince meat" quality, it has content.  You'll probably like it.

The final entry of the series however took what little I liked from the series when this should have been a great send-off.  I've always found the RPG genre intimidating and hostile, too much focused on melodrama and grinding over consistent writing and careful pacing, and the brilliantly orchestrated audio/visual experience and unique time-based combat of the first game helped draw me in.  That however is mostly gone in what feels like a cruel parallel to the game's over-arching narrative, and it makes me truly sad to have witnessed the conclusion like this when it could have been so much more.

As an intro to this review, I will give my experience with the trio of FF13 games. I have played the first 2 twice. Once on xbox, and once on PC. I have completed Lightning Returns on PC only. I personally liked all of them, from story to gameplay. While the previous games in the 13 series have had preformance issues on PC, and the games themselves were very divisive in their gameplay and story, Lightning Returns changes everything. Combat is completely different and the overall experience is so much better.

[b]Preformance[/b]
The pervious games had quite a few preformance problems on PC. Terrible frame rates, small resolutions (which was fixed later), and even game breaking bugs. I myself was a victim of one of those bugs, as well as fps issues, but was able to fix and play them both. On the flip side, I am happy to say that Lightning Returns was not plagued by any of these problems. I installed the game and went right to playing it, with absolutely no problems at all. The game can run at 60 FPS, and though it did dip below that sometimes, it was mostly stable. You also have a decent number of options to improve your own preformance by clicking on the options menu at the top left of the screen. Unfortunately, you can't access that menu with a controller, but that, along with the acual quit button (as opposed to the main menu button) are the only things you will need a mouse for if you wish to use a controller.

[b]Combat[/b]
Combat from the first two games was very simple, and was mostly just controlling which classes your 3 fightning charaters were at any given time. Switching between these constantly was very important, but otherwise, the only thing you had to do was choose the auto-battle function and let the game choose the abilites to use.

In Lightning Returns, the system is completely different. There are now things known as "Schemata", or outfits with 4 abilities, 2 accessories, and an optional adornment for each. You get to choose every single one of these for youself, and there is a large pool to choose from. 

During battle, you now control everything. You have access to 3 Schemata to switch between, which are all very important because each Schemata has its own ATB guage, which is basically a stamina bar. These fill up much more quickly when the Schemata is not being used, so it is important to switch between them often. Guarding has also been introduced, which is very important. During combat, you will need to guard in order to drastically reduce damage taken. Timing your guard perfectly will negate almost all damage, while simply guarding without proper timing will reduce damage by around half. If you are worried about timing, don't be! I'm pretty bad at timing stuff like this, but there were only a few places where I struggled. If you are still worried, you can play on easy, which allows you to regenerate health for free between combat.

[b]Other Gameplay[/b]
There is now a clock in game, which is very important. You have 13 days to complete your ultimate goal, and if you don't make it in time, you will lose the game. If you do fail, you start a new game, keeping all of your old items, excluding quest items. This mechanic scared me a lot at first. I was sure that I would mess something up because I wasn't going by a guide. My fear, however, was misplaced. By the time i was ready for the end of the game, I still had around 4 or 5 days left, with little left to do. The most important thing to remember is to use the chronostasis ability. This freezes time, but also consumes EP. You start with 5 maximum EP, but gain more throughout the game. Chronostasis costs 1 each use, but you can gain EP through combat very easily, so you can do so much more during a single day in game than you otherwise would. The time limit is not something that you have to be scared of. Just explore, use chronostasis, and don't avoid combat. Also, at the beginning of the game you start with less than 13 days left. Through quests (main and side), you gain additional days, as well as stats and money.

Something else of note is that the game is now open world. You can now do whatever you want, with the only exception being time. Some NPCs will only be out at certain times, and some areas will only be open at certain times. This can sometimes be annoying, but there is almost always something else to do in the meantime, so just come back later if something isn't accessible.

[b]Story (Spoiler Free)[/b]
In Lightning Returns, you have one controllable character, who has been in both previous games: Lightning. She is now also known as "The Savior", and has been chosen by God to serve him during the world's final 13 days. Along with her, God also chose Hope, another returning character. He will help Lightning from "The Arc", which is a place created by God and unaffected by time. You will meet many different characters throughout the game, some you may recognize if you have played the previous games, while others will be completely new. If you are new to the series, or don't remember everything from the previous 2 games, then don't worry. The cutscenes alone do a decent job of filling you in, but you will also have a datalog with plenty of information to read through, should you wish to know more.

[b]Conclusion[/b]
In conclusion, I personally believe this game was great. As you can see, I spent a bit more than 90 hours playing it and I enjoyed every minute. There were 0 technical issues, the graphics were beautiful, and I really enjoyed the new and much more interactive combat. The Schemata were also a very nice addition, as they allowed a lot more variety, both in combat as well as for Lightning's appearance. The story was emotional, but action packed. It was also mysterious, but consistant. By the end of it all, I nearly cried, as the final cutscene just wrapped everything up so much more nicely than I could have imaged. This game is a great pick up and if you are looking for a great story with good combat, then you have found it.

Lightning Returns is about the constant struggle for hope in a world lost and locked in despair before the final stroke hits 13.  It focuses on a central character that has been prominent in Final Fantasy XIII for the last six years, Claire Farron or more commonly referred to as Lightning, Cloud's distant second cousin (I kid, I kid).  It's time that she puts her foot down and save her sister and the people, for this world, or the next.  Nothing will stand in her way.

Graphics: Not bad, basically around XIV graphics regularly.  Funny note though, they basically spent all their CGI budget on the beginning and end of the game. I happen to like it.  15 minutes of beautiful CGI is a rewarding end for some I'd think.

Gameplay: Good, final chapter of the class / stagger system.  It takes a little getting used to but it gets rewarding for the most part later on.  The structure of the quests is debatable.  A few main quests here, bunch of menial side quests there, all under that pressing timeline.  Especially when you don't know what will help give you more time. I think it is the uncertainty that can increase that sense of pressure (the game nearly tells you as much). +Game also is almost worth doing even with a full time job.

Voice Acting: Always good, I would shake their hands if I ever recognized them.

Conclusion: A solid end to an up and down series that seems to take you everywhere and while some patches are rough, you are glad you could be a part of the ride.  

Now, for my crazy analysis of the story...

The Plot...
   The game starts with the premise that there is no reason to save the world but only the people who seek salvation in it.  You assume the role as savior, the chosen one by celestial powers only known to be God by everyone that sleeps below the clouds.  And by the looks of it, with the end of the world coming, you have some of the common tropes.  You have people who desperately seek a sense of security, purpose, and salvation through faith in the same celestial being.  You have other people who seek to protect themselves and the things they care about.  Lastly, you have the people who are lost in all of it.  The irony is that most of time you seek to liberate people from their dispair so that they may find hope.  It becomes their salvation.  It becomes a consistent theme throughout the game in all shapes and sizes.  The powers to be that could help have long surrended their efforts to the inevitability of the nearing end.  
   
Throughout the game you task is to save as many people as you can.  Your friends and enemies are the most important souls for you to save.  It's nice to see the familiar faces once more.  I was always a fan of Lightning, but to see Fang was a great pleasure (maybe it was that strong femine touch or that austrailian accent, who knows?).  Snow isn't have bad, he and Hope are like wines, awful if inbibed too soon, palatable if taken with age. Even Caius makes a return, what an ass he still is.  Even death can't seem to shake the stick loose that seemed to be shoved so far up there.  But still, like the undeniable prick we all seem to come across once in our paths, Caius reveals the same undeniable necessities that we all need and a singular truth that we need to recognize.  Good, bad, or strange, we all have a choice, and more importantly, a part to play in this story.  
   
Another great scene in the story is Lightnings interaction with Noel Kriss (my one standing objection to the writing of this series, they seem to take these random objects or famous figures and reapply them to their characters, like codenames maybe...Hope, Snow, Fang, Lightning(was a code name), oddly the more stable characters generally have realistic names, anyway, interaction with Noel...).  Lightning decides to play along with the role of being an evil harbenger of death which shows a depth of character and manipulation I haven't seen before with Lightning.  It was very enticing to see her play the role of the villian to fulfill Noel's perception of destiny.  Throughout this game, Lightning has become incredibly perceptive if not wise in some ways.  Which leads me to the one new character, Lumina.  She is the thorny prick that you can never seem to find but you know you sat on.  But that is also her undeniable charm.  She keeps you guessing to the very end.  
   
Fast forward through all the minor quests (they offer insights into Lightnings thoughts but overall, there isn't much personal growth except for the few main quests there are).  Final boss (yep, once you are done with the five or so main quests, its the final boss), 

God, no biggy.  

   As Lightning has said and implied (a little 'spark' of glee for me please) over the course of the game, she has been fighting fate for a long time, and she has been getting good at it. She sees through Gods plan and decides humanity should be accepted as a whole for all of its pros and cons.  The new world should be for everyone free from God.  She will take on the roll of death to give people the chance to live.  So, she kills God. To be fair, it was God's failure to empathize but his equal need to be close to human kind that drove him to eventually try to control humanity.  He was an engineer at heart who wanted to understand what love was but since he couldn't he decided to remove it from everyone else, metaphorical downfall.  
   
    Love conquers all, yadi ya. But it has a point, one that should resonate with us on some level.  It is through our love for others, our passions, our willingness to coexist, that we contribute and build a future and vision that only we can dream alone.  
    
    Back to the story...God is slain. Everyone comes back together, loose ends from 1&2 are wrapped up here as well (it was nice to see actually, considering how depressing XIII-2 was).  Everyone goes towards the light and decides to be reincarnated in the new world, including Lightning.  Caius and the infinite Yuels remain except for the one that loved Noel.  They would watch over the Chaos that doomed the world in the first place, which, let's be fair, they created.  But even so, they did it with effortless humility.  The cycle of life is finally restored.  And the new world is filled with life. 

Extra Ending:
Lightning among us?
The new world is awfully similar to the one I take for granted and more than I care to admit (not to mention avoid mostly by playing these games).  Lightning leaving a train in a rural area ready to face the peacful new world with unbridled optimism (her face is adorable) is both joyful and sorrowful (at least for me). It joyful because she can finally be happy, and sorrowful because our time with her is at an end.  The life of the tragically mundane and stable has finally ended our drama on the grand stage.

With that being said, I wonder, her new life is just beginning. Part of me likes to think the possibility exists that Lightning can start a new adventure with this new life.  Hell, why not?  I would like to see what life throws at her next.

25537029.review:
This final entry to the Final Fantasy XIII trilogy can be summarized in one phrase: The combat system. It is the ONLY reason to play the game. In fact it’s so good that I spent over 450 hours to understand it thoroughly. However, the game fails miserably on almost everything else especially on the game design and story.

EXCELLENT AMALGAMATION OF ACTION AND RPG: The addition of the timing mechanic officially turns this FF title into an action RPG. However it plays very differently from run of the mill action RPGs because Lightning Returns had evolved from turn based strategy. And strategy is what most action RPGs lack.

Besides limited equipment slots, popular action RPGs such as the Elder Scrolls and Diablo series have no restrictions on unlocked skills, thus leading to ridiculously overpowered characters by end game. This game however, allow only four skills you can use at a time in battle, forcing you to think hard about the most effective setup against each foe. So the most powerful enemies are challenging even if you are maxed out.

I absolutely loved the addition of a timing mechanic because it rewards your investment into mastering this skill. Once you get this down, fighting enemies even on hard difficulty becomes a breeze with the right strategy. If blocks are timed correctly, damage can be reduced or even negated completely. A well timed attack also increases damage. It usually doubles the damage, but some equipment can triple or even quintuple that.

Combat is equally demanding on both your reflexes as well as your brain. I have never seen such an elegant blending of both strategy and action in any game. Even though I was beyond disappointed with almost everything else in the game, this ONE aspect gives me hope for the future of the franchise.

COMBAT IS REALLY NOT TOO DIFFICULT: A vast majority of the complaints is nothing more than a “too difficult” and therefore it’s bad assertion. This complaint certainly has its merit, but it’s really a poor game design issue.

With the right setup and a basic level of competency on timing blocks and attacks, most enemies are not difficult to defeat, even on hard difficulty. From mid game onwards, it can get really frustrating if you don’t learn how to setup your equipment.

Unfortunately, neither the in-game tutorials nor gameplay scenarios lead you to explore the depth of the thousands of possible customizations on your garbs, equipment and abilities that this game has to offer. Reading a guide to understand combat is almost inevitable.

THE DESPICABLE END OF WORLD TIMER: This is by far the biggest complaint everywhere. After several playthroughs, I realized that there is way more than enough time to finish the game and it’s really not a big deal. But a new player on their first playthrough will NOT know this. So there is no excuse for the game designers to implement such a silly mechanic.

The clock just ends up forcing the player to only focus on completing quests and objectives because he is constantly worried about wasting time. It certainly made me feel like my boss was relentlessly watching me. I thought games are supposed to be relaxing and not feel like going to work.

NORMAL DIFFICULTY IS TOO HARD: The “normal” difficulty is way too hard for a casual gamer. The learning curve climbs way too fast following the combat tutorials in the beginning of the game. It gets frustrating very quickly. My recommendation for a casual gamer is to use the easy setting for the first playthrough. The game designers really should have the current “normal” difficulty set hard while “easy" should be set to normal. Then they should create an even easier difficulty level below that and a nightmare difficulty above hard. This simple design decision alone would have made the game a lot more accessible to casual players.

UNCONVENTIONALY POOR LEVELING MECHANIC: Only completing quests will “level” your character. This leveling mechanic together with the end of world timer gives the player tremendous pressure to focus only on quests and to avoid combat and exploration. It’s another poor design decision. It is so ironic that the game encourages you to avoid using such a well designed combat system.

REQURING TWO PLAYTHROUGHS TO EXPERIENCE THE COMPLETE GAME IS ABSURD: You have to complete the game at least once before weapons can be upgraded and abilities be leveled beyond three. What casual gamer will play a game twice? Every FF title has allowed the player to unlock everything within a single playthrough without requiring a restart. Yet another ridiculous design decision.

LIGHTNING HAS ZERO CHARACTER DEVELOPMENT THROUGHOUT THE ENTIRE TRILOGY: This is THE colossal failure of the entire FFXIII series. There is no central character to hold the story together. It’s no surprise so many players find Lightning un-relatable. That’s just simply because Lightning doesn’t have any character.

There is a meager sampling of scenes that would qualify as character “development” in the first installment of the trilogy. Hope and Lightning briefly traveled together and bonded. She told him she wanted to forget about the past by changing her name from Claire to Lightning. So that’s the reason why she is so cold and distant from other people. That was it. No more information was revealed as to why she made the name change and what she struggled with. These details are necessary for us to connect with Lightning.

The incessant focus on saving and protecting her younger sister, Serah could have worked had it served as a conduit to develop Lightning’s story. Like many reviewers have already pointed out, the whole trilogy never goes beyond superficial statements from Lightning (and also Snow) about how she needs to be saved and protected. The writers need to illustrate the relationship between the two sisters. Show us bonding moments in the past between Serah and Lightning. Make us care about Serah as much as Lightning does. The same could be said for Snow. Furthermore, the writers could have really used the conflict between Snow and Lightning to add more depth to their characters. The plot contains so many opportunities to develop the main characters. But they really failed to capitalize on it. All that melodrama between the main characters will not work if we don’t care about them.

LIGHTNING RETURNS IS A MESSY HODGEPODGE OF DISJOINT STORIES: Each of the five main quests have little to do with the main plotline. They really made me feel that I am just playing a longer side quest. If the game allows skipping to the final quest, you will not miss anything story-wise.

The random philosophical ramblings from Lightning at the end of most quests come across as nothing more than platitudes. These monologues need to be interconnected and build up to a central theme or relate to the main characters for them to be meaningful. After wasting two games with no character development, it is too late for that here. Just focus on plot, tie up the loose ends and get it over with.

THE MUSIC SAVES THE QUESTS FROM BEING A CHORE TO SLUG THROUGH: A lot of these dramatic pieces made this disaster of a story tolerable. The music has stopped me on many occasions from pressing the skip button on the dialogue scenes.

Some of my favorite pieces includes Lightning’s theme that are used throughout the more serious moments in the story. The Ark’s saintly hymn fit me right into my savior role for humanity. Many of the other pieces that included a chorus truly immersed me into my divine undertaking during the final missions.

I care about Final Fantasy a lot. No other game franchise can tell a story better than the early installments released during the previous two decades. Few stories in any medium can match the epic journey of Final Fantasy VII that many of us still revere a dozen or so years later. I want to see the franchise return to its former glory.

This is probably the best game in this trilogy of games. Absolutely tons of content, great combat, satisfying story, and replayability after you finish the first playthrough.

First, the combat. In the other two, the combat is sort of automated for you, and you don't have any control over your own characters movement which can be frustrating when you watch them walk right into a massive attack. In this game, though, you have full movement over Lightning. You can dodge attacks sometimes by moving around. It really helps in a lot of areas. 

The combat in general has way more control over what you can do, and what actions you want to perform in the Schemata system. In the other two, you choose between 5 different Paradigms that you set up, and the AI sorta takes over from there (At least with your two party members). In this one, you set up 3 different Schematas and chose 4 different moves for each, and they each have their own ATB bars letting you switch on the fly to block attacks or switch to melee/magic when the enemy staggers much more fluently than the other two.

This game also introduced a new clock system. If you're a completionist like myself, you may not be that thrilled. [spoiler]You only get 13 days[/spoiler], and it can feel very overwhelming trying to complete all the side quests, Canvas of Prayers and monster extinctions within the allotted time. I played about 4 hours before restarting and following a guide just because I wasn't sure I was going to be able to complete everything in time (That was before I decided I was going to give it another playthrough on Hard). You can freeze time, almost as much as you would like, as long as you keep killing monsters. So it isn't all that bad.

You may have also guessed that, yes, the framerate is all over the place in this game like the others. I can maintain 60 fps throughout the open zones, like the Dead Dunes or the Wildlands, but the two Cities I get constant frame drops. Something I got use to over time, but it is just as bad as FF13-2.

The last thing to mention is the story. It is a satisfying ending to the trilogy, and I wasn't at all disappointed with the story or how it ended. I've noticed that a lot of games nowadays just kinda end, and don't really give the closure that I was looking for. This game does not have that problem. It gives the right amount of closure as well as keeping it open ended enough [spoiler](Not a sequel bait ending)[/spoiler]

It does sort of start off weird, I was wondering what the fuck was even happening at the beginning and why [spoiler]all these characters from the other games were still alive[/spoiler], but they slowly explained it over the course of the game.

Overall, a pretty great game that receives a lot of flack just because it's in the 13 trilogy, even though the games in it are pretty good. Worth buying.

Despite its linearness, I played through Final Fantasy XIII willingly. The end of it had all the trappings of weirdo cataclysmic killing of gods and universe unravelling and implausible battles, but the story revealed itself in an engaging way, and the characters were interesting and lovable.

Playing through XIII-2 was less pleasurable. A very interesting character that you wanted to know better in XIII is one of two main protagonists. Alas, with only two characters to follow, it got old. There was little to do in battles, once you had a set-up that worked reasonably well you just mashed a button. Worse, however, was a Chrono Trigger-like wandering through time, messing with cause and effect, but without the multitude of characters' stories being intertwined in an engaging plot. Worst of all, if you did manage to tough it out to the end of the main game, you were rewarded with a most displeasing ending where the end-of-the-world scenario you were trying to avoid all game winds up happening anyway. There's a ton of end-game content that becomes unlocked, but I just couldn't care long enough anymore to bother.

Into that bleak and aimless scenario starts Lightning Returns. Because two characters was deemed to be too many, we've now been reduced to just one, and it's another bloody fashion show - the exact reason I never managed to finish FF X-2, despite having loved FF X. 

Furthermore, and worst of all, they have set up a system where you are punished for completing objectives by having a time limit on the game. Yes, time acually ticks away as you progress through the game, and if the timer's up, then you've lost. Yep, all that gameplay down the tube and you have to start over again from the beginning. I'm sorry, when I pick up a mainstream RPG I want to take my time and explore every nook and cranny as I make my way through the game. Here, they attempt to force you to run through the game as fast as possible, to see as little as you can as it goes by. 

It all hinges on Replay Value. Replay Value should be based on how much fun the game was to play the first time. Here and in XIII-2, it seems they are trying to force you to replay the game. "Didn't like how it ended? Here, try playing it all over again and see if you like it better this time. Still no? Start again from the beginning and make 'different choices' this time." Starting over is not just a core mechanic, it's at the center of the plot. For me, this just tells me I'm wasting my time. 

If they want a game to be played and replayed, it has to be interesting. My Skyrim has 1,000 hours in it. FF X probably has around 350.

In the case of XIII-2, I had seen enough the first play through, and all that extra DLC unlocked at the end was left unplayed. For Lightning Returns, it's been just 3.8 hours so far. I may get a Game Over, I may actually get through to the "end" of the game, but I may quit before seeing either ending. Right from the start, I'm told that what I'm going to do doesn't matter because existence is going to end, and I'm having a hard time caring. 

I may yet change this review, but so far, not so good. The company that brought us FF Tactics, FF VI and VII and X has lost its way.

Update (10 hours): Though a veteran of all things Final Fantasy, I just cannot understand or like this game. After writing the above review, I chose to start over on Easy - which I never do in this series. I also downloaded a few DLC freebies in game. The idea was that by playing in Easy, I could enjoy the story and the game, and not feel like I was just getting kicked in the shins the whole time.

It worked for a while. Then, I progressed in the story to a point where I go into a graveyard near the end of Day 2. Suddenly, and without explanation, the monsters went from pushovers to "What just happened?" Most of the time, I have no idea how I wind up dead.

A few theories: First, I like strategy games (which this series used to be about). I take my time, plan my moves, and dominate the enemy. From what I can tell, this is far more of a game about timing moves - a game style I tend to stay away from. Even worse, you could call this more of a brawler-type game, a style of game I simply can't stand. 

Attacks can be blocked, if you get the timing right. However, the screen is usually so cluttered with effects that I usually have no idea what's going on. Additionally, wIth the Stagger system as it has devolved, you are being continually being pushed to full offense, and so even if you see an attack coming, it's too late and you can't get your shield up in time.

At this point, I think I'm going to save myself the bother and read a synopsis of the story online. For the premium price tag that these FF games take, I feel as though I wasted my money on this one.

25197806.review:
Sorry if this review is not formatted well, because I haven't written many reviews. ( I think this is my second in the years I've been on Steam) but I felt it had to be written because of the bad rep Final Fantasy 13 has had. I think it's an incredible series and many would agree the ending to Lightning Returns is probably one of the better game endings out there in terms of wrapping things up. 

After playing 6 of the main Final Fantasies I was sure nothing could top Final Fantasy 7. Final Fantasy 13 alone wouldn't top it but the combination of the trilogy was the first time I actually had to think about it. I can't give a definitive answer but that could be nostalgia. 
Battle System
    Final Fantasy 13 gives a better more controlled real time action battle system over their previous games. It's not perfect for several reasons imo. It's not really made to hop around like a mad person spamming attacks (in fact you'll probably die fairly quickly if you do). I actually wanted to do this since I prefer to enjoy the story and other elements. You do have to pay attention, the Cloud outfit with its raw power can only get you so far (I'd say like a 1/4-1/3 of the game). Anyway, you can eventually equip a dodge,block,heal and even jump if you want. There are one or two difficulty spikes which are crazy hard and mostly requires you to choose a different path and return later. Also I was surprised to find out there's actually a full on crafting system but it doesn't unlock until after you beat the game. I had no idea. Anyway, technique is much more important that your weapons. At higher difficulties, those improved weapons will be detrimental.

Graphics
    I've always found Final Fantasy 13 series to be beautiful to look at it and Lightning Returns is no exception. I own the game on both PS3 and PC and I eagerly awaited the pc version when I was 2/3 done with the PS3 version just so I could enjoy 60FPS and I have to say the game delivered. It wasn't perfect at first but after some light patching it is now as far as I know. It runs great on my Laptop with a GeForce 860m (almost max) and of course no problems on my Desktop with a Core i5 and GeForce 980. I never encountered any graphical glitches and I'll say it again, I think the character models are beautiful to look at. The world is not the biggest but PC version does have enhanced textures. I'd say it looks like a smooth PS4 game.
Sound/Music
    All Dialog is voiced and well at that. Lightning’s dialog is my favorite part of Lightning Returns. She has really insightful monologs and character conversations. I love how she's not naive she may even be border line cynical sometimes but she has a reason to help people so she goes through with it. All the music especially the main FF13 theme, the battle and boss themes are all pretty damm good. I didn't like it at first but it grew on me big time. 
Story
    The game wraps up the Final Fantasy 13 series incredibly. I'm going to sound crazy fanboyish but it definitely has one of the best ending's I've ever seen in a video game. It's definitely my most favorite Final Fantasy ending by far past the others. It's not even just the main story, the people you help feel like you're actually helping people. It's not always about fetching something for someone (there are grind quests like that too but as rewarding). I was moved a few times hearing some of the NPC's back stories, I couldn't believe they put this effort and so much emotion into side stories. Some are short and some long quest lines. it's kinda crazy because there are some really interesting ones that don't really pop up anywhere, you just have to stumble on them by being curious of your surroundings. Like I mentioned earlier Lightning may be slightly cynical and because of that, the game for the most part is not campy expect some slightly dark stories, death and even questions of morality. It's a very immersive atmosphere and the game feeling very open world helps this. Anyway, every character you can imagine makes an appearance of some kind and the story definitely goes full circle with everyone’s choices over the years. Like I said before, I couldn't think of many games that would wrap up plot points so well.

-Additional notes
I play the game exclusively with an Xbox 360 controller. I played mostly on my desktop. I own all three games on the ps3 and the first and last on PC. You'll want to spend some time setting up your outfits with their abilities and MAKE SURE you switch outfits at intervals during battles, even short ones. You do spend most of the game fighting on your own which sucks as a FF game but there are places in which you can have a consistent partner. One can even be powered up a lot if you put the work into it and it will reveal some familiar backstory. The game has metaphorical and literal references to God and Noah's ark.

Dead Rising Presents: Final Fantasy XIII

Seriously; it's Dead Rising. This game has a timer, just as in Dead Rising, whereby you have to complete the main quests before it runs out. Just as in Dead Rising this game has side quests that are optional and can also be completed within the time frame the game allots you. UNLIKE Dead Rising completing side quests EXTENDS the timer and is integral to the plot. Furthermore you can FREEZE time with an ability that uses EP points (gained from battle). So it's Dead Rising but, generally, easier. Don't let anyone tell you the timer is too harsh; hell if you go ''game the SH1T out of the system'' mode like me you can complete everything in the 4 of the 13 days you are given, so it provides plenty of wiggle room. Granted some sidequests are only open after doing others, and those others might require multiple days past 4, whereas others are opened up in later days. But generally speaking the large ''bulk'' of them can be completed in roughly 4 days (along with mainline quests). The quests afterwards I did without even stopping time since very few 'new ones' showed up.

The devs thought side quests needed even more of an incentive to go through, so they threw JRPG grinding out the window and decided to innovate. See....there's no actual grinding in LR. It's a JRPG but without any experience gained from battle; there's no point behind them other than drops and money. It's almost an anti-JRPG in that sense. 

Instead, quest completion itself boosts your stats. 

Quest completed 
rewards: 
+10 strength, +6 magic. 

It's actually one of the more ingenious things this game has come up with and it's really impressive. Rather than grind for an upcoming battle you can go complete story content and plotlines. Granted, these sidequests don't have the branching paths and long, thought out storylines of Fallout sidequests, but it's still impressive how they used it as a replacement for a JRPG element that gets criticized. For it's part I thought the game did a good job of variety and giving each quest character and reason. There's one where a path branches and the reward changes depending on what you pick; more of that would've been great.

The story itself is better than the previous games, because it makes sense. All open-world games tend to have simpler plots, I feel, because you don't want to interrupt gameplay with constant cut-scenes and the linearity required to constantly interrupt play with story. So if you didn't know wtf was happening in XIII or XIII-2, don't worry. You don't have to. You get the sparknotes version here. 

Worth mentioning are garbs: costumes that affect stats and provide abilities as well as auto abilities. They tied cosmetics to customization and made it as important as weapon choice and shields. Nothing new but worth mentioning, as there are an assload of costumes in-game. ASSLOAD.

As for the battles themselves the ATB system is still here; battles are in real time but most people end up using their ATB gauge in one go and wait for it to refill. They allow you to move during battles which isn't that big a deal, until an ability you can equip comes up; ''ATB Recharge''. The way it works is you recharge ATB quickly for as long as you have ATB recharge pressed, but are vulnerable during and afterwards when you recover from the animation. So it makes positioning in battles actually matter and animations for moves something other than just an animation for a move until your turn is up. Otherwise the game still suffers from some of the constraints of typical RPG turn based battle mechanics in a real time system; waiting for gauge to recharge is really just a slight step up from turn based since you're STILL WAITING; more abilities like ATB recharge would've made it feel more ''real time'' but whatever. Take it or leave it, but it works. So meh.

Verdict? A fantastic end to the XIII series, which had a pathetic start. Love Lightning as a stoic protagonist; really liked how they changed up JRPG elements here, and the ingenuity makes me want to play XV if and when it comes to PC. It's sort of like Majora's Mask in how it did some really cool new things with established formulas, and I wanna see more of it. We finally got to open world, quest based, ingenuity in how levelling up and XP is alloted in FFXIII and it's fan-effin-tastic. I guess the only downside is that if you want to give more 'meaning' to the world and story you gotta play FFXIII lolololololol. And also try to make sense of  XIII-2's plotline lololololol. Even if you don't this game's just so damn good and creative in various aspects.

Oh, and the music is so good that I forgot to even mention it since lol it's expected from the XIII series at this point.

I was really hoping this game would make up for the disappointment I experienced with XIII-2. There's not a lot Square could have done to rectify the ridiculous convoluted story (90hrs into the trilogy, and I'm still not confident I could explain it to someone if I had to), but I think they have done the best they could to make it reasonably motivating. Games of this length have to be motivating to keep the player interested, and that's where XIII-2 fell down, and where Lightning Returns ultimately picks it back up. Part of this is due to the fact that the game is completely open-world, more so than any other FF game I've played (possibly due to the complaints the previous two XIII games got for being 'corridor simulators'). Literally all of the explorable world is accessable right from the word go, but you quickly realise that there is a logical order to the locations you should visit.
The combat system is reminiscent of XIII, but rather than customising paradigms across the party, Lightning herself is able to switch roles on the fly and perform different actions. There is seemingly endless customisation options for these roles using the vast array of outfits which can be purchased from stores, found in containers or won from battles.
The game looks fantastic at higher resolutions, in fact much better than I was expecting from what is essentially a port of a PS3 game. SE clearly put some effort into making great visual improvements, and it's just a shame the same effort wasn't put in to optimisation. At launch, this game ran pretty terribly. After a number of patches, the game runs acceptably, but was still prone to pretty serious dips in framerate for seemingly no reason.
In conclusion, if, like me, you enjoyed the previous XIII games but were slightly put off by one thing or another, then I'd definitely suggest picking up Lightning Returns, as it makes an effort to correct most of the complaints the previous two games suffered, and it does it very well. It's probably not worth picking up if you havn't played at least the first XIII game, as it may not make a lot of sense - not that it does even if you have played it!

24356417.review:
I give up. I actually liked FFXIII and was wanting to play this trilogy to its conclusion, but after my time with Lightning Returns: FFXIII (LR), I just have no desire to keep going, and as best I can tell, I'm about halfway through the game. I'm pretty unskilled at games, but it wasn't the difficulty that got me. No, no...I was doing just fine with that, and I was getting the combat system.

The concept of this game is philosophically awesome: all humans on the world have stopped aging, so no one dies from growing old; only other means like disease/murder. This means everyone who was alive 500 years ago still looks the same, including children, and some shadowy crap that spews out monsters is seeping everywhere, with the last areas of the world poised to be destroyed within one to two weeks (depending on how many major quests, etc. you complete). That has some fantastic philosophical and psychological implications. Knowing this and being a fan of FFXIII, why in the world didn't I like this game?

Well, before that, let's start with one thing I really did like without any negatives whatsoever: Lumina. (don't look her up as her appearance might be kind of a spoiler if you haven't finished FFXIII-2.). She's a young girl who seems to be able to control this chaos stuff that's apparently destroying the world. She helps some people, hinders others, and seems to be making Lightning think and question her cause in good ways while taunting her playfully and occasionally summoning big monsters for her to fight for reasons unknown.

She's a wild card, with an appearance that raises some serious questions about who or what she is, and why she looks like that. She's doesn't come off as creeper eye candy and her voice was enjoyable; not that high-pitched, annoying standard fare you sometimes from from young female characters in JRPGs. She intrigued me and quite frankly, I have no interest whatsoever about the rest of this game, other than as it pertains to her.

What didn't I enjoy? Virtually everything else either turned me off completely or had a glaring flaw that other FF games (including FFXIII or FFXIII-2) did better. Since I was just talking about Lumina, let's talk about the story. Get ready for some awkward Biblical terminologies getting liberally thrown about. Lighning is the "Savior." She calls herself this, as do other characters, and she serves a being she and others call "God." However, that's not its name or a translation of its name; rather, its name is "Bhunivelze," and there are three other "gods" that are apparently lower level managers to the "God" in this game.

Your mission is to save souls so that when the world ends, those people will be created anew and live again in a new world Bhunivelze will create. How do we save souls? Well, you make depressed people have hope again by doing fetch quests and their souls pop of their chests and into Lightning's, and boom, tiny max stat increase for you (a lot more from major bosses you beat up). Let me repeat that: person is sad, bring them something they want or beat them up, now they have hope again and you get their soul. This is the plot of the game. Hope communicates with you over some sort of radio channel, and isn't very interesting or funny, and Lightning is -less- emotional than in FFXIII and FFXIII-2. LESS emotional. She's even less likable in this game than before, and they even talk about it! Her having no emotions is a plot point which I still haven't seen resolved yet.

Well, except anyone who has ever played a JRPG already knows that something will go wrong with the deity. Either everything with it happens off-screen and it's just a badly written plot device, OR it ends up being fake or evil and you have to kill it. JRPGS love having you kill deities because it's upping the ante...much in a way that some Hollywood movie sequels end up being set in space because they keep upping the ante in each sequel and can't come up with anything more "impressive" than going into space.

But I digress. The game's religious terminologies are just a poor excuse for one of the aforementioned inevitable outcomes with a deity in a JRPG while simultaneously trying to justify fetch quests. I was terribly bored with the three major maps I explored in the game. As best I can tell, there are 4 or 5, and two of them are cities with slightly different design and color pallets. Were you aching for cities/towns with real NPCs that have relevance and shops in FFXIII? Well, you got your wish...they exist here. That's all, though. I found them terribly uninteresting, as with almost every side quest I did. I just kept hoping for more cutscenes to take me away from these dull towns and all the running around through them for so long. They're pretty big and just eat up your time (real world time, not just the game's Time system) instead of presenting entertaining content.

Speaking of the Time system, you game over in approximately 8 hours or so from starting, while the clock is going. You can freeze time with a spell outside combat as long as you keep fighting monsters to get your resources back to cast the spell again and again, but if you run out of time, you save your game and start over from the beginning of the first major quests with all your gear and stats in tact, and can do the quests over again for 50% of the stat gain rewards from the first playthrough. You can do this infinitely, I hear. 

I never restarted, though before I bought the game, I read the reviews and thought this sounded really fun! Other people were griping about this, but I foolishly didn't listen, thinking it'd be awesome to zip through the main quests again while really powerful and still getting more stat boosts in the process. However, having actually played the game, it would bore me terribly to play through even the main quests again. Everything is just bland and uninteresting! The game feels like busy work everywhere except in combat, which I'll discuss now.

Looking at screenshots, one might assume this is a third person action game. Not quite. It's more like FFX-2's Dressphere system and FFV's Job system, but with ONE character and you can only bring 3 outfits. Each outfit gives you different stat boosts and has four slots for equipping attacks/spells, but almost every outfit (Garb) has 1-2 locked-in commands, meaning you can only assign 2-3 commands  (hence the FFV reference). And no, I don't mean "Black Magic" is a command so you can choose between a myriad of spells like you could in FFV. If you want Fire, Ice, Lightning, and Aero, it would take all four slots on one of your 3 garbs you can take into battle to equip it. The same goes for all of the debuff spells like Deprotect and Deshell. Also, you need to be able to block or dodge, or bosses will destroy you, and that takes another command slot! 

A few non-slotted abilities are available like Curaga, but for the most part, you can only have between 6 and 12 slotted commands in battle, and you don't have a team like you do in other FF games. That means this is one of the most limiting FF games ever made in terms of number of abilities that can be used in a single battle. In LR, it's just too few, and I'm one of those people who thinks other FF games have too many. Other than the blocking, I prefer the combat system in virtually every other FF game made to LR's combat. Oh, and you don't level up or gain stats at all from combat, except against bosses. That sounds refreshing, but I hated it. =/

Lastly, the music is simply forgettable for me. I like the first two games' music in this trilogy and remember several songs from each, but I draw a blank here just trying to remember one song from LR.

I don't have much else to say about how uninteresting, bland, and unenjoyable my time was with this game. I cannot recommend it to fans -or- haters of FFXIII.
