24151767.review:
Personally I give the game a 9.5
Professionally I give the game an 8.5

You can take my final verdict or you can read on to discover how I came to it.

This game has a lot of options on how you want to progress through the story and how you want to play. It is only in the very beginning chapter where you are restricted on your choices. This isn't limiting, but rather freeing, as it educates you on how to manage your time wisely without feeling impaired. 

[b]The Time Limit:[/b] I want to address something I've seen said a lot; “The game doesn't have options or any freedom because of the time limit.” 

[u]My answer is the time limit is more of incentive than it is an actual limit.[/u] Yes, there is a limited amount of times you can hand in or complete a quest but that is only a problem if you neglect to pay attention to your progression in the game. [u]It is IMPORTANT to take the time to explore and soak in the environment if you have any intentions of coming close to 100%.[/u] 

To date I have 132 hours of gameplay. I finished my first play-through with a time played of 131 hours. I would say 50 of those hours were from sitting in menus, reading datalogs, fighting monsters and testing. All points where the clock is not ticking. 80 of those hours were from actual time spent running around exploring with the clock active. The time translation is about [u]two real-life seconds is 1 in-game min.[/u] How did I do this then? Simple; I used my time wisely when it mattered and I used the ability that allows you to stop the clock. I did everything in this game besides kill the super side-boss and I did it without a manual. I took my time to seek out and find all the quests and did not rush.[u]This is the first Final Fantasy title I have EVER played[/u]. Although I am by no means new to RPGs, anyone who is a fan of the series is more than capable if they allow themselves the chance to learn how to play. 

[b]Gameplay[/b]

[b][u]Combat and Gearing[/u][/b]

LR:FFXIII offers the standard turn-based three-party class-orientated combat system that every RPG does but in an refreshing different package with one playable character. You have “ATB bars” which translates to turn-per-minute or simply how often you get to do things. The more ATB recharge you have, more times you get to do things. 

You have three different schema in combat (specs/characters) all played by one character on-screen. It is “real time” in that you can't stand idle but with the strategy of turn-based. Which is a nice and refreshing. A spec is reflected in actual outfits that house up to four abilities. They often have an ability locked to it already. Some of them are very strong abilities, others get weaker as the game continues. The point is that you really have three abilities to customized into anything you want. 

The customization of the character was very fun and rewarding as I spent hours just thinking of how I wanted to play. 

I found as I learned the enemies I was rewarded greatly for my efforts. I would swap out abilities for ones better suited in the specific area I was in. When exploring I kept a generic jane-of-trades ability load-out so I never got caught facing something I was ill-equip to handle. [u]Despite the swapping of abilities/weapons I never felt like I was being forced to play a specific way but rather rewarded for being prepared.[/u] My mage was always a mage, my tank a tank and my melee a melee.

I did like that high damage / rank does not translate to it being the best. Secondary stats are important and not neglected making combat and gearing about more than just finding the hardest hitting weapon. 

[b][u]Story Progression / Character / Ending[/u][/b]

The world of story is rich and luscious. I found myself interested and engaged. I spent time reading the information provided in the datalog out of pure interest in learning more rather than feeling confused. I never found myself lost because I didn't play the prequels. All I had to do is pop into the datalog and read up on it. Quick read, detailed, coherent, enjoyable. No complaints. 

Questing was well done, all-be it confusing at first. As I learned how the title played and handled questing it became second nature. That said, there is a learning curve, but it goes away as you progress. Best advice I can give is talking to people will solve almost every quest problem.

There are complaints about it being grindy. I didn't find this to be the case. [u]The fetch quests are a staple of RPGs. Go play a different game if you hate them, you are doing it wrong.[/u] Every RPG is go to location A and do B or collect C. This game is no exception. I thought it was well done. Many of the fetch quests were completed as you progressed through the main story or moved around. Some of them yielded awesome rewards. Others were stat buffs that seemed trivial until facing some of the harder monsters. It adds up at the end. So don't disregard the quest simply because the reward seems to low.  

[u]My standards of story uniqueness are rather high in that it must make sense but my standards for characters are far higher.[/u] Lets be real here, if it makes sense and you follow what is happening then there is a really good chance you've seen the story before. All-be it in a different package, but good vs evil is not unique. [u]What makes a story inviting and new is characters.[/u]

[u]I want to address that Lightning is wonderful female protagonist.[/u] Something we just don't see enough of in any media. She is stoic, confident, and real about the world she is a part of. She is intuitive and capable of evolving. She is also caring and compassionate. Subtle changes that do not happen too soon or too late are a part of her depth. The world and herself do not ignore what makes her-her. If you take the time to stop and appreciate the development of Lightning's personality you will find a great deal of enjoyment. 

[u]Sadly the development spent on Lightning is not spent on other characters.[/u] It really makes me sad to see this.  They feel like they are almost “just there.” The voice acting and lines they deliver are very real, and I was convinced of their importance. They aren't bad or poorly done characters but the fine-detail polish just isn't apparent. 

I did find the ending to be restricted due to the characters found in the prequels. [u]The spotlight shifted, perhaps, to far away from Lightning in the final moments of engagement making the player's contribution to the story feel a little lacking.[/u] It makes sense, but it could have been done in a more satisfying way.  

[b][u]Final Thoughts[/u][/b]

I truly love this game. I just wish more people could take the time to let go of their expectations of a title and rather hold their standards of fun firmly in mind. We vote with our wallet and we should never accept anything less than what we pay for. 

If you found this title less than what you paid for I challenge you to go back. Ask yourself if you took the time to set aside your expectations? Did you focus on the bad as an excuse to not attempt to have fun? If you can't find fun in a game, that is okay. Give yourself a chance to though. There are a lot of amazing games out there that have some technical quirks that take a little bit of tinkering to get rid of. That is something you may run into because this game is a port. Read-up and give it more than a few minutes to figure out. [u]I hold by my stance that [i]Lightning Returns: FFXIII[/i] has excellent quality fun inside but it isn't accessible to everyone because of the seemingly daunting clock.[/u]

Sincerely,
Vel

Let me put it this way, it's Lightning and the final chapter of her incredible, perfect story, if you don't like Lightning, you're not a true gamer.

Granted, you probably won't understand much of what is going on unless you've played the previous two games, and I'd highly reccomend playing both anyway, if not for the gameplay, then for the sake of the detailed, emotion-tugging storyline itself.

Onto LR though, the gameplay, compared to the other two, is definitely better, and is definitely one of the best PC ports of what was a console-only game I've seen, there's so much more options and customization, so many outfits you can put Lightning in, like gorgeous dresses or awesome armor (And unless you have a -good- reason for making her wear some of the more..revealing sets, get out, right now.) the varied stats and certain skills that come with each piece of gear makes you have a more tactical approach to the game, it isn't just about rushing in and smashing things to pieces, no, you'll die very quickly attempting that.

Graphics are..well, the game is sort of old now, they aren't going to be shiny and amazing, but the PC version does have advanced settings that make it superior to the console versions, and gosh the game can be pretty at times, especially in the Wildlands or Dead Dunes areas, I always did love open, grassy areas with wildlife in it, and the game isn't at all demanding, even a weak PC could likely run this game, simply because of how well optimized this game is.

Some people say that Lightning is bland and has no emotion, and that she (or her voice actor) are completely bland and generally garbage, sadly, these people didn't pay attention to the story at all, clearly, as it is outright said Lightning's emotions have been "sapped" from her, which is why, in most scenes, she always has the same tone of voice and expression, but in the later stages of the game, her emotions return to her, and she returns to her old, incredible self, and near the end of the game, she says one of the most awesome lines you'd ever hear in your lifetime.

There is a time limit, yes, but you're given more then enough to finish most, if not all, main and side quests in the game, which even adds some replayability as you can come back and do the stuff you missed out on in the first playthrough, some quests are fun, others a challenge, and a couple have even made me laugh a few times, a lot of them even have a story to tell, too.

There's really no reason to -not- buy this game, to be honest, Lightning is here, she's beautiful, conflicted, and complicated, and being her awesome self in general, as always. Pretty much the greatest heroine that the gaming industry has ever given us, full stop.

Do bring a controller of some kind though, the PC controls are a bit awkward, and that's pretty much the -only- downside to this game, the controls, everything else is perfection

Lightning Returns: Final Fantasy XIII es el fin de un ciclo en la saga Final Fantasy, un ciclo que para muchos ha sido pésimo, pues juzgan la Fabula Nova Cristalys por el primer título y se olvidan de los otros dos, que son verdaderos juegazos, y sin duda este es el mejor de los tres.

Gráficamente es identico a los anteriores, lo cual es bueno, ya que los gráficos están bastante bien; en tema de optimización y opciones gráficas está muy por encima de los otros dos, permitiendo por primera vez jugar a 60 frames y escoger unas pocas opciones gráficas, aunque siguen siendo muy pocas opciones para lo que nos tienen acostumbrados a los jugadores de PC. La banda sonora tambien es la misma que en los dos juegos anteriores, una banda sonora a la altura de la saga Final Fantasy, sin llegar a ser la mejor ni por asomo.

Y es en la jugabilidad donde este juego se desmarca totalmente de los anteriores, pues, a pesar de que el diseño de niveles sigue siendo mediocre, esta entrega nos presenta un sistema de combate totalmente nuevo y mucho más entretenido que el anterior, aportando ese punto de dinamismo que sin duda Square Enix ha estado buscando desde Final Fantasy XIII. Además, mientras en la primera entrega se nos presentaba un escenario totalmente lineal, y en la segunda varios escenarios semi-abiertos por los que teniamos que ir pasando, esta tercera entrega nos ofrece un mundo enorme con cuatro zonas totalmente conectadas entre si y nos permite elegir el orden en el que las completaremos, destrozando todo tipo de linealidad y ofreciendo una enorme cantidad de misiones secundarias. Finalmente hay que hablar del sistema de arquetipos, un sistema mucho más personalizable que el de los roles de las entregas anteriores, un gran acierto. A pesar de esto, hay un gran fallo en la jugabilidad, y es que al abolir cualquier sistema de niveles, hay pocos alicientes a enfrentarte a los enemigos que aparecen en el mapa.

La historia es la continuación directa de la segunda entrega, con el estilo profundo de esta, aunque se echa de menos un villano tan visible y carismatico como fue Caius en FFXIII-2, se puede perdonar ya que la historia está a la altura, y ofrece un final épico como pocos. Lightning Returns: Final Fantasy XIII es el ejemplo de buen capitulo final, donde se mejora la gran mayoría de los aspectos de los juegos de la saga y se cierra la historia de forma magistral, sin dejar cabos sueltos y de forma épica. 23920771.review:
The FF XIII series is probably the most polarizing of all FF games. If you hated XIII, just stop. Don't try to convince yourself that  you'll like the other two. Otherwise...

Lightning Returns is in many ways the best of the three games. The story is nonsensical, but that's largely true for all three games. What LR is, however, is a swansong. Kind of like how they make up a story for Dissidia, so they can have all these various FF characters fighting each other, the story for LR is basically an excuse for you-as Lightning-to have one last reunion with your party members from the first game, and go off into the sunset. 

Mechanically, the combat is the best of the three games. It's also the most difficult, though that comes with the caveat that the game will throw all levels of difficulty at you in the same area. The end boss...well, if you have no sense of timing, you're going to be in for a world of hurt, as it comes in 4 iterations, and the last iteration is a test to see if you can figure out how to stagger it. I consider myself a fairly good gamer, and it took me 3 hours to figure out exactly when in its rotation you could actually stagger it (and, once staggered, it dies in a matter of seconds). After which, I browsed the internet, and let's just say there's a lot of misinformation out there on that boss.

The elephant in the room. Time limits. Assuming you do most of the side quests, you're going to have 14 in-game days to finish the game. I finished the main quest and majority of side quests in the first 4 days. So...yes, the time limits seem ornerous, but if you're willing to kill everything you see and constantly freeze time, it'll be fine. Once you're able to kill the types of mobs that give you 1 EP or more easily (EP is what you use to freeze time, among other things), then you are essentially able to keep time frozen as long as you want-other than when the story forces you to advance. 18 hours to complete the main story + majority of side quests. 31 total hours to complete the game (those last sidequests (consisting of running through each map every day to see if a new quest was available)/exploring/figuring out how to beat the final form of the boss took up almost half the game). 

There's a lot of sidequests. Do them, as they tell bits of story (and improve your stats). 

I'll be honest. If this game had a party, and about 10 more zones, and a sensible story...it'd probably have been the best FF game ever made. They had the framework for a great game, and we can only hope that they aren't completely reinventing the wheel with open world when FF 15 is released. 

Putting aside the main story, a lot of the writing in the side quests, random npc voices, etc...were great. It was almost as if I was in FF XIV, except it was voiced. Lots of the same type of humor as well. 

Ultimately, if you didn't despise XIII, then play this game. This is basically the type of game XIII should have been (but, with a full party and lots more zones). If you did despise XIII, don't torture yourself into thinking you might enjoy any of the other two games.

If you just played FFXIII or FFXIII-2 and you like the style and you're expecting this to be mostly the same, read this now!

First, I think this is a fantastic game, expecially for a port from consoles. The frames are fine, the game is well optimized, and it's exactly like the console version.

That being said, this game is very different to FFXIII or FFXIII-2.

Now, if you did play the first two, or any other Final Fantasy game (aside from FFXI or FFXIV,) you're probably familiar with its turn based combat, and if you're coming from FFXIII or FFXIII-2, you're also familiar with the Paradigm Shifts. LIGHTNING RETURNS has a whole new take on the combat system. You can move around your enemies, although your attacks are based on your gauge, ie, how many attacks you can pull off in one go, it's not turn based. You can start going all out in attacks against the enemy, then right before they hit, you can sneak in a guard and significantly reduce the damage taken. Then go back to your onslaught, or in the middle of your melee/physical attacks, throw in some magic, all while moving around.

Paradigm shifts, I'm not going to explain too much about them because if you played FFXIII or FFXIII-2, then you're already familiar with the concept. Essentially, you can still do paradigm shifts in this, and each time you do, your gauge is pretty much filled back up so you can go back to attacking/guarding, so you don't have to wait for it to fill up each time. This just helps cut down the waiting time between attacks and makes everything feel a little more real-time.

I personally bought this game to finish my FFXIII collection (the other two games are on a different account, don't bother looking for them on this account,) and I was kinda surprised when I saw all the changes in this compared to the others, but I learned it, got into it, and it's just fantastic. The story just follows our epic trilogy and brings us to the conclusion, nothing really shocking there, but damn it's a good story. The music is still just as good as any other Final Fantasy game.

All in all, I'm really enjoying the game, and although was a little surprised with the new mechanics, I'm thouroughly enjoying it.

GAMEPLAY: 8/10
VIDEO: 9/10
AUDIO: 10/10
OVERALL: 9/10

TL;DR, buy it, it's a good game, but it's a little different than the other FFXIII games.

Please keep in mind that I have not played a single Final Fantasy game, let alone the first XIII games. This is coming from a newcomer to the series.

From what I have played so far, it's pretty nice. The battle system isn't the best in the world, especially compared to what I've seen in the upcoming FF15, but it's good enough to keep me engaged. Anyone that has played Legend of Zelda Majora's Mask will be very familiar with the timer system in this game, as it is pretty much exactly Majora's Mask in that regard; you have a limited amount of time to complete as many side quests as possible, as well as completing main quests to extend the world's time limit. Despite the battle system not being the best I've seen, the ability to change between different movesets via the costumes you unlock is pretty cool, not to mention that the various costumes do provide some of their own effects, making them more than just eye candy. I enjoyed this game. My main motivation for and why I even played it was to get some closure on 13-2's ending and Serah and Lightning. I approached it with the mindset of completing it as quickly as possible to see the story, but I found myself enjoying it more the farther I got.

So first, things I liked. I loved the environments. Such an improvement from 13-2 in terms of size and utility. There was much more to see and do in the world that felt a lot more expansive. I liked how there were a greater variety of NPCs you could interact with (whether as vendors, quest givers, or just random people) It also looked a lot nicer than 13-2, particularly the Wildlands and the Dead Dunes. Side quests are a MASSIVE improvement over 13-2's. I'm not talking about the side AREAS in 13-2 like the Vile Peaks or the extra Oerbas that had a side story (they were well done and we SO needed more of those), I'm talking about those meaningless fetch quests with pretty much zero interaction and take up the 80% of the side quest datalog. In LR, there are more side quests, and a good portion of them have interesting stories and actually feature our protagonist INTERACTING with the quest givers. Not perfect, but a major improvement. I actually liked how this game took a bit more of a personal tone with the protagonist, really delving into Lightning as a person and character. I wish 13-2 treated Serah in the same way. Maybe because this series is pretty much just about Lightning :/. 

Moving onto things I didn't like: 

The time system. It's awfully frustrating and inconveniencing. How I have to wait for a specific time to access some area or a particular quest. There are some quest givers that only appear during certain times of the day and some parts of any main or side quest can only be done at certain times of the day. And once you're finished your quest and go to turn it in? Oh sorry, the NPCs aren't there anymore and you have to wait till the next day... It's annoying, especially when you have a THIRTEEN DAY TIME LIMIT. You have to painfully wait for some quests to progress because of the time while having a constant reminder of the short amount of time you have left. It's stupid. I know there should be enough time to complete most of the side quests, but it's stressful to have to worry about what time of the day I can do what while being reminded that time is running out. I understand how the time limit imposes a sense of urgency that's more realistic, but it could have been far less annoying and restrictive. Maybe I just want to take my time, enjoy the environments and explore as much as I can.

The combat. I liked having a real time battle system (it's what I'm used to), I liked being able to time my attacks, my dodges, and my guards. It made fighting more immersive. But what I liked even more was the more strategic-based combat system in 13-2. I liked the paradigm system where I was able to choose my strategy, assign roles to party members. Every move felt like it had some thought and planning put into it. I usually like real time combat, but for some reason, it felt off in this game. Nothing bad about it, it's just a personal preference, I guess.

The story for the most part felt rather incoherent and messy. There wasn't some underlying path Lightning was treading on to reach her goal. Her journey felt all over the place. There wasn't anything significant tying each chapter of her goal to save Serah. It felt like she was just visiting the areas to do busywork, taking part in the irrelevant lives of others. Yes, she was working to save the souls of her close friends, but it wasn't tied to her ultimate goal. It feels like the work she's doing throughout those thirteen days didn't advance any part of the overarcing plot: to save Serah. The final encounter did not have enough buildup from the plot at all, which made it feel rather incohesive with the rest of the story. I still enjoyed Lightning's reunion with her friends throughout her story, however, especially the Snow part (one of the sections where you could really feel the connection to the plot). Sections like that maintain the game's continuity from its predecessors.

The villain was a disappointment. He wasn't much of a character. He basically had no presence in the whole game until the very end. He had zero development and didn't feel like a threat at any point in the game, because he was missing for like 95% of the game. You couldn't really feel his influence on the story at all, it's like he came out of nowhere and conviently makes an appearance to take the physical form as a target who the good guys need to unleash their weapons at. 

This brings me to my biggest complaint: how the characters were handled. My ultimate motivation for playing this game is to get some closure on what was left behind in FF13-2. Mostly on the characters. For the most part, the characters were handled well throughout the story. It was how they wre concluded that left me really disappointed. Serah, the person that Lightning starts this whole journey for, the centerpiece behind her motivations, and the person who was the main drive for her actions and story, is basically non-existant in the game. And what little there is of her takes form mostly in a fake Serah they created. I thought this was a neat concept (especially how this fake developed to harbor feelings for Lightning) but WHY NOT use what little characterization and development time there was on the REAL character? You know, the one Lightning talks about for the WHOLE GAME. But the biggerst letdown was how the journey for Serah concluded. There is basically no satisfactory closure on her relationship with Lightning. What did Serah want to say to Lightning after being revived? Did she forgive Light for her death in 13-2 (we should all know the answer but I would've liked to hear it from her)? Did she and Light have anything to say to each other after 500 years that showed the power of their will to be together again? Did she have any words about how she felt about everything that happened and being together with Light again? Did she even acknowledge Snow? Her fiance??? Nope, it ends just like that. She utters maybe three lines (that weren't all that memorable) before the game ends. Lightning has spent THREE WHOLE GAMES trying to get her back, even defeated a god. Then it's like she came back and it doesn't even matter at all. I mention Serah, and not so much the other characters, because I really felt like Lightning and Serah were the two most important characters in the trilogy (on how every game has been about them trying to be together), with everyone else a whole level below in terms of significance. If that is to be the centerpeice of your trilogy, it better be well developed and concluded, which I felt that it was not. Not only that, closure on the other characters were scarce too. It's like how everyone is leaving behind their old lives and homes, and no one cares. This game needed better, more satisfying closure on the characters than that last cutscene. It's supposed to be a happy ending, which is good, but there's no reason that a happy ending like this can't be more satisfying.

Overall a decent game that I enjoyed my time with, despite frustrating things, mostly because of the return of characters I grew into, even though in some cases they may have been inconsistent or lacking. The gameplay held its own well enough for me, though on a mechanical standpoint, this game really doesn't have much going for it, as there isn't anything all that special about it. The game is mostly carried by the characters built from the two precious games, and their stories. If you like the character or generally like Final Fantasy or JRPG style characters, then this may be your thing. If you don't care about the characters or the story beyond 13-2, I would say this isn't worth the time.

22920992.review:
This has been a really weird trilogy. The first game was rather bland in total. It had some nice character development, but the story and gameplay just fell flat for me. So then I tried the "sequel" which was really just a completely different game that happened to use the same characters. Honestly nothing from the first game really mattered for the second. Combat felt a bit better, since it focused on two characters instead of two parties worth that you had to juggle back and forth if you wanted even growth (hint to developers: if your cast is bigger than your party, share exp with all of them, not just the active party). Asside from being completely unrelated to the first one, the story was pretty good, though the ending was obvious sequel bait.

And that brings us to this one. Which I feel is the worst of the lot. First of all the time mechanic and open world feel like terrible ideas. I know they got a lot of flak for how linear the first game was, but trying to follow a story in an open world game is always a pain. I go over here and find something out and then go over there and pretend I've never heard it before because they didn't know which I'd do first. The timer had me initially worried about running out of time, so I stopped time as often as possible, which resulted in me finishing ALL of the main stories by day 4 (out of 13). So I relaxed a bit more and did the side quests... and got them all done by day 8. So the Savior slept through the last 5 days. Needless to say, between those two elements pacing was killed, cremated, and thrown to the winds.

Combat was pretty meh at first, but the tougher enemies just annoyed me. They weren't so much hard as tedious as hell. There were a couple enemies I got halfway through and just reloaded a save to ignore them. Your selection for combat is also rather limiting and there's no way to adjust in combat for the various enemies you'll face. Where the last game gave you access to all the spells in a set that you had (if still forcing you to have certain Paradigms) this game limits you to 12 abilities spread over 3 outfits, each with one or two locked in abilities. (Another developer hint: don't do this crap. Allow players to be flexible in combat, not force them to reload and change the loadout because they didn't bring a fire spell or something.) And then there was the timing elements which were just annoying. It didn't feel like things were telegraphed all that well either for your attacks or your enemies (such as for attacks that seemed to move the camera off to some other part of the field entirely or come from off screen). Overall, I just avoided it near the end.

And finally there's the story itself, we've got another disconnect where it's 500 years past the last game (which had a good deal of jumping around by itself) and we start off at odds with a number of our past friends. It felt like the game was deliberately trying to make Lightning a boring character, despite most of her actions in the field not really fitting with that persona. Certain parts of the plot are dragged out between various days but are forced to wait for the last day for final resolution... which makes very little sense honestly. I could tell stuff was happening but for the most part I had either no investment or no clue.

Overall I can't recommend this game.

TL;DR: La idea es buena, pero la aplicación no tanto; la historia va dando tumbos pareciendo casi inconexta, y el sistema de combate es demasiado cuadriculado. Si solo quieres disfrutarlo, juega en Fácil. No te lo tomes como un insulto, sino como una forma de ¡NO PERDER EL TIEMPO!

Por no hablar de que los traductores a español se tomaron una buena cantidad de licencias con las traducciones (el Altísimo en un universo politeísta no encaja demasiado...).

Pros:
+ Sistema de tiempo que aunque es agobiante al principio, lo cierto es que se puede aprovechar en gran medida.
+ Un sistema de combate distinto a los anteriores FFXIII.
+ Misiones variadas
+ Enorme customización del personaje en cuanto a estereotipo (ropa, arma, accesorios, forma de combatir...)
+ Gran dificultad para los usuarios más exigentes.

Contras:
- Pocas misiones si eres un jugador experimentado al que le acaban sobrando la mitad de los "días".
- El combate es muy complejo/enrevesado/restrictivo para los usuarios menos exigentes.
- Los tiempos a veces son arbitrarios, aunque al menos puedes conseguir los objetos ANTES de las misiones (a veces).
- Farmear habilidades es necesario y el sistema de mejora de las mismas es demasiado confuso/aleatorio hasta que buscas guías.
- Necesidad de pasarte el juego al menos una vez para acceder a aspectos casi NECESARIOS del juego (entre otras, una misión que no puedes terminar hasta que empiezas el juego nuevo)
- Algunos monstruos, bosses necesitan que exploitees el sistema de combate para poder pasártelos (Aero+ e Inmunidad Física/Mágica)
- El sistema de aturdimento es ESTÚPIDO.
- El sistema de aturdimento está mal traducido y explicado.
- Me he pasado el juego y hasta el boss final no acabé de comprender el sistema de aturdimiento, siendo necesario buscar en guías.
- La técnica más importante para aturdir está restringida debido a otros usos importantes (Tiempo bala) que no puedes usar, ya que el juego en determinados momentos te EXIGE que aturdas al rival.


Si habéis llegado hasta aquí, comprenderéis que mi mayor problema con el juego está en el sistema de aturdimiento.

El sistema es relativamente sencillo, buscas la debilidad del rival (un elemento por lo general) y spameas un hechizo de ese elemento hasta que se aturde y se queda aturdido unos segundos.

Hasta ahí bien, el problema viene de que tu personaje está limitado a 12 habilidades exclusivamente (algunas de las cuales las fuerza el traje que lleves puesto). ¿Por qué esto es un problema? Pues porque si un enemigo es débil a un elemento que no tienes equipado, te jodes.

Te jodes, a secas, puedes huir del combate, pero pierdes una hora, y si quieres volver a intentarlo tienes que entrar en un menú poco intuitivo y bastante engorroso para cambiar tus configuraciones, habiendo podido dejar algunas predefinidas (GRACIAS).

Y ahora viene el segundo problema, las habilidades son objetos equipables que por si fuera poco, en tu primera partida van a hacer una basura de daño (15-60% de tu ataque base, que puede ser 400; para acabar con monstruos con 30k de vida). Un engorro.

Pero el juego viene y te da una buena noticia: "las habilidades se pueden mejorar para que sean más efectivas". Noticia que por cierto, te da en cuanto matas a un "Último" y pillas objetos especiales y difíciles de conseguir; causándote además, que no vuelvas a poder conseguir las habilidades que dropea ese enemigo (y no se pueden comprar), puesto que al matar a un Último de una raza, no vuelve a aparecer NUNCA más hasta que no empiezas un new game+.

En definitiva, el juego se convierte en un come horas de farmeo, que además te bloquea el farmeo, y aunque original, limita un sistema "en tiempo real" de forma que lo convierte casi en un piedra papel tijera lagarto spock dejándote solo usar piedra o tijera, debido a la forma estúpida de limitar un juego tipo final fantasy en lo que por lo general, lo mejor es la gran lista de opciones a mano.

22734505.review:
I downright hated this game at first, then started to like it, got right to the end, and then gave up.

As you might expect, "Lightning Returns" IS a Final Fantasy entry. The artwork is killer, the gameplay mechanics come across quickly while having major depth, the story team really found their groove with wrapping up the mythos, and everything is polished to a mirror-shine - it's all top shelf craft.

There's nothing to have a problem with there.

...and the game is a HUGE improvement over its predecessors. The environments are expansive and free-roaming from the beginning, and the emotional core is handled far better. Yes, it really is a bunch of fetch quests, yet it all manages to contextualize itself in a motivating way. Not everything is directly tied in with the main plot, of course, but everything does manage to feed into the main plot. The "just a bunch of random stuff going on" problem is NOT in play here, which is a welcome upgrade from "XIII-2."

So, why did I hate the game at first?

The theme of the game is time, and the race against it. This is already a bit of a precarious thing when it comes to a Final Fantasy title, where the "Take Your Time" trope has been essentially baked-in since the 8-bit era. The experience of racing the clock gets downright VICIOUS in "Lightning Returns," because of how everything seems to pile on.

To start, battle is a tough business in the early game, and battle is still central to getting anything done. Fighting is also clearly tied to the central "time" theme, with getting the rhythm of the encounter exactly right being very important. The thing is, getting the rhythm exactly right is extremely difficult. The window for getting a "perfect guard" (where you take no damage) is very small, and the enemies hit hard. The window for getting enhanced attacks is even smaller - so small that I gave up on it almost immediately. (To be fair, it doesn't seem that enhanced attacks are really core to successful gameplay.)

Further adding to the difficulty of battle is the way resource management works. You start out with a very limited stack of carryable restoration items, and a similarly shallow pool of EP. Your EP is sort of your "safety net," because you can cast curative magic from it. Where things get hairy is that EP is also your pool for attacking powerfully, and for all practical purposes, you can NOT restore EP with your item inventory. (There are ethers in the game, but they are as rare as megalixirs were in other titles.) You restore EP by winning battles, but winning battles can be quite pyrrhic: A difficult encounter can burn through all your items and all your EP, leaving you with nothing in reserve for the next face-off.

You have to fight to progress, but fighting is actually pretty dangerous.

If you get into a really tight spot, you can escape from a battle and get your used items back, but escape costs some of your limited time.

All this creates a nasty ball of frustration, especially at the beginning of the game. You don't really have a handle on how long things are going to take to do, so you don't know if you're taking too long to do them, There's no indication of exactly how much is required to extend the world's time, and the go-where-you-want nature of the game means that you can waste precious hours in finding out that you're just not ready for a major encounter. (The only way to find out is the hard way.) If you're like me, you end up being very tense about everything that doesn't go well, because running out of time means starting over. From the beginning of the game. (!)

As a motivator and tension builder, it's incredibly effective. It can also be not very fun.

The good news is that things get a lot better as Lightning strengthens. As that happens, and you get some wins, the tension begins to ease. That's when you can really start to appreciate just how tightly woven the whole thing is. I might even go so far as to call the game a masterpiece of interlocking mechanics.

A pretty darn difficult masterpiece, but still.

When you do "find the groove," you'll have many hours of enjoyable questing in the world. You'll even get good at the time-management aspects.

So, why did I give up at the very end (literally, at the final stage of the final battle)?

"Lightning Returns" ended up doing what the other games in the "Fabula Nova Crystallis" series did: The end boss is essentially a puzzle that is not solved in ways that have worked for the rest of the game. If you try to solve the puzzle the wrong way, you encounter a near-vertical difficulty spike. You can have progressed diligently through the whole of the quest, finding a setup that works for you, and then "bang," the setup stops working.

This title, much of the time, has your character on a solitary journey. To give Lightning the necessary versatility to survive, she's equipped with "schemata," or battle setups that allow her to switch "jobs" instantly. The thing is that it's easy to start leaning heavily on say, physical attacks. It's a bread-and-butter configuration that actually can end up being very effective - right up until the tail-tail-tail-end of the game.

I finally survived the other stages of the final encounter, and suddenly noticed that my attacks were doing almost no damage...on an opponent with over a million HP! I went back, tried switching things up, couldn't repeat my previous success, tried again, got beaten into the ground, and finally said:

"Forget it. I could win the stupid game if I was willing to have a three-day fight with this thing. I'm going to find the ending on YouTube."

Other people have, of course, legitimately seen the quest through to the actual end, but I was done. I play games to enjoy myself, not to be frustrated by trying every combination of character configurations.

Like I said earlier, though, this game is really well made. It seems to be the perfect capstone to the series, even if I really disliked parts of it. If you've played the others in the series, be sure to play this. I don't think you'll be disappointed, but you may grind your teeth a lot...

I put off playing this game since I had originally played the first two games on the xbox.  By the time LR had been released I didn't think it looked very fun.  I really only wanted the story since this was the finale.  I built a good computer and found out that FF 13 was coming to steam.  So I replayed them on steam while waiting for the next one.  I never played LR until it came out on steam.  

The story is split up from the start.  You get to pick where you want to start in terms of the story.  There are 4 different areas with 5 main storylines and a bunch of side quests.  Completing those main and side quest will reward you with base stats.  So you'll get stronger the more quests you complete.  The game is large so there is quite a bit of running around involved.

Unlike the other two games this game is on a timer.  12 in game days which in my first playthrough was way more than enough to get through the entire main story and almost all side quests.  So don't be stressed about the timer.  Also if you don't happen to make the timer there is the option to new game plus.  You'll keep all the stats and non key items you've earned.

I was very confused at first and frustrated trying to learn how exactly you are supposed to stagger enemies.  Not being able to see their stagger gauge unlike the previous games and just increasing the stagger gauge in general.  It took a while but once you learn the game is very fun.  It's basically the same as the previous games except increasing the gauge is different for every enemy.  Enemies stagger in levels, so basically after staggering an enemy once their condition changes.  They might be aplied debuffs such as deprotect or become vulnerable to certain debuffs and elements.  Some will stagger with a single perfect shield and some have to be staggered 4 times before you can even deal significant damage to them.

Other than that the game can be challenging at times and pretty technical.  It requires a lot of learning to deal with enemies and their attacks.  Perfect shielding and retaliating correctly to stagger them is a lot harder in this game than it sounds.  Especially if you're still learning the basics.  Just stick to it and it'll be a fun game.

22288054.review:
I’ll be honest with you. I bought Lightning Returns primarily for the dress up, and my expectations weren’t high. While I wasn’t a fan of FF XIII, and even less of a fan of it’s confused, malformed sequel, you couldn’t fault either game for their excellent selection of high quality, glossy lipped and slightly dead eyed Japanese dolls. The producers of Lightning Returns seem to have realised this and baked it into the marketing campaign with all the subtlety of a cruise missile aimed at a nunnery.

What will come as something of a surprise to many then is that the game is not the car crash disaster it by all rights should have been, though it is heavily flawed. Lightning Returns is a good example of why steam needs a middle ground rating – I can’t honestly give it a thumbs up, not without serious caveats but dismissing it entirely is every bit as unjust.

The core conceit in particular is both original and compelling – God is going to end the world in seven days in order to create a new one, being evidently based on the bored bi-polar sociopath of the Old Testament. You as the hero can do nothing to stop this – all you can do is save as many souls of those in this world as you can, so that they may be reborn in the next. There’s a further wrinkle to this - no-one has been born in 500 years, but equally no-one can die of old age. However, people may still be killed by other traditional means such as disease, misadventure or good fashioned suicide. This sets up a nihilistic Children of Men-esque world covered in a thick malaise of apathy, offset by a tense race against time as you do what you can to save what little hope is left.

This being based on the characters and premises of FF XIII, this potential is of course completely squandered. The story is borderline incomprehensible at best, a train wreck with no survivors at worst. Set 1000 years after the first game, Lightning is awoken from cryosleep by God and has agreed to be the world’s soul collecting saviour with the hook that her sister Serah is reborn in the next world. But she’s also had her emotions removed, the reasons of which are never adequately explained, so why she should be moved by this emotional plea is unclear. Removing your main character’s personality as well as driving motivation doesn’t sound like a recipe for entertaining drama without a careful writer at the helm. Sadly the writing is roughly on par with the last two games – which is to say it’s crushingly, wincingly awful. All of the characters you either loathe or barely remember make their melodramatic, floppy haired return, and chew their way through dialogue so purple it would make Anne Rice blush.

Word of advice – set the language to Japanese. All credit to the English voice actors, they do the best they can with the material they’re served but this is hot, George Lucus tier garbage and not understanding the words being spoken adds a comforting, brain shielding barrier between player and script. Your comlink companion Hope (also thankfully de-emotioned) never shuts the fuck up either, and in English his repeated dialogue goes from irritating to excruciating very quickly indeed.

So it’s down to the mechanics to save the whole show, and I personally found the game quite compelling in spite of its shortcomings. The impact of the time limit on this game can not be overstated. Make no mistake, this is an absolute core part of the game that cannot be ignored in any way, shape or form. You have six in game days to finish the whole thing, with an hour of game time being roughly equal to a real-world minute. You have a limited supply of EP (I forget what it actually is, so I’m going to assume it refers to Lightning’s collection of Emerson Lake & Palmer records) that can be used to stop time for about three real world minutes – EP is regained slowly, typically by killing baddies. Time management is absolutely crucial, and it is a massive barrier to relaxed exploration. If this sounds like a deal breaker to you, I would not recommend this game regardless of how much you want to see Lightning in her knickers.

In terms of freedom, Lightning Returns finally gets the balance right after the hand holding corridor of FFXIII and the borderline cryptic non-linearity of the sequel. There are four large areas, each containing their own main quest as well as a series of side quests that can be tackled in any order, though enemies do get tougher in the larger, more open sections. The side quests are of particular import – Lightning does not level up by fighting monsters (the lazy cow) and instead gains flat bonuses by completing these quests. They’re of a variable quality – there is a literal “find my dog” quest, but there are some nice multi-tiered interwoven quests that don’t inhale dong in there as well. The time limit alongside a general lack of waypoints can make this aspect of the game quite frustrating, and I feel that they should have made these more optional – you will have to complete a sizable number if you want to have hope of beating the bosses or even some of the tougher basic enemies.

A word of warning - The game is surprisingly difficult, and demands you learn its mechanics quickly. You will need to learn how to block quickly, or you will die, frequently and unceremoniously to even the lowliest of enemies. You will not be able to muddle through things on the default difficulty –Every loss results in a loss of a precious hour from the in game clock. The first boss in particular is a wake up call, and they only get harder from there – seriously consider starting on easy if action games are not your forte, though it should be noted that if you do so your future descendants will feel your gaming shame.

The battle system is fantastic once you get the hang of it though. This is by far the most action orientated of any of the FF games, with nary a menu to be seen. You control only Lightning this time, but she can switch between three different costumes at will – when one is in use, the ATB gauges of the others will recharge faster. While each costume has different abilities and stats, you’re largely free to customise their active abilities as you wish. There’s a bewildering number of costumes and accessories available, and those wanting skimpy bikinis might want to temper their expectations- while those exist, they’re vastly outnumbered by the range of much more tasteful outfits. This is probably for the best, as Lightning is built like a 15 year old boy with two oranges in a bra – her bottom is Isaac Clarke levels of flat. Flatter than Master Chief. Flatter than Sigourney Weaver in Alien. I’m not some kind of badonkadonk zealot, but this is heartbreaking stuff.

Lightning Returns is easily my favorite Final Fantasy XIII game.  Given my opinion of the other two games that's not saying all that much, but I genuinely like this one.

The battle system is the best thing to happen to a Final Fantasy game in years, it's a fantastic hybrid between direct character control and picking commands from a menu and it's something I've never seen before.  It's possible it was ripped from some MMO I don't know about, but it was very fresh concept to me and it took me by surprise how much I'm digging it.  The battle system alone is enough to put this game ahead of the other games in the series for me.

I also really like the character customization system.  I wasn't sure how I'd feel about basic abilities like attack and guard being limited, equipable items, but it works.  The garb (aka dress) system also works because, whether we admit it or not, we all like playing dress up with our virtual action figures (they're totally not dolls! :) - whether it's putting spiked pauldrons on a barbarian or a highly impractical "armor" on Lightning.

Beyond the combat systems, I like the general structure of the game too, even though it's exceptionally basic.  Sadly none of the quests are all that compelling by themselves, they're still all Fedex and monster hunts, but I like the regulated nature of having a bunch of quests and gradually working through them.  It keeps me going in Bethesda RPGs where most quests are similarly hollow and mechanical in nature, and it kept me going here.

The time limit did worry me quite a bit.  Basically you have a limited about of time to accomplish a particular number of tasks in game, and if you fail to do so, you get a bad end and have to restart.  The notion that I could play the game for 20+ hours only to get a bad ending and have to start over seemed ridiculous.  However, it turns out it's a complete nonissue. I decided to play the game on easy because I was so worried about that and I ended up completing all main quests and like 90% of the side quests by the game's half way point without looking at a guide once.

The story is the one area I'm pretty disappointed with the game.  The plot is nonsense, but that's no different than the other FFXIII games...or Final Fantasy games in general for that matter.  However, in other FF games you at least get some degree of enjoyable spectacle in how the story is presented - big set piece moments and scenes.  Apart from the always cool opening cinematic, I've only come across one other scene that I thought was cool.  Other than that, the game doesn't even get its anime drama-on properly.  All the series main characters have like 2- 5 minute cameos at best, during which they try to cram in entire emotional arcs and it comes as especially absurd how quickly characters change from one viewpoint to another and resolve their conflict.

So the story is a wash like the other games and the spectacle that was the saving grace of the original FFXIII isn't there, but I like playing the damn thing more than any other game in the series.  It goes without saying that you shouldn't bother playing this unless you suffered through the other FFXIII games, but if you do, you might just find is a nice way to finally be done with that chapter in FF history.

The best game of the Final Fantasy 13 trilogy! This conclusion to the trilogy has better, more fast-paced gameplay, more clothing, more accessories, and more lore than the first two games. Speaking of lore, the main quests and sidequests are a joy to do because they give you more insight into the world, and quite a few of them provide comic relief!

The name of the game in Lightning Returns is the Stagger gauge. Many enemies will be difficult (or impossible) to defeat unless staggered. Character development will quickly focus on builds (called "schemata") designed to stagger enemies and keep them that way.

I strongly recommend starting the game in Easy mode, as in Normal mode you cannot regenerate HP and enemies are far more difficult to kill.

This game features a monster genocide option. If you kill enough of a certain species, you will permanently remove that monster from the game. This option makes it easier to explore areas, but I found the emptiness... disturbing.

Do not worry about managing your time in this game, because it features New Game Plus. You will not only be able to finish the quests you couldn't, but do over every quest in the game if you so desire. This will allow you to reach apocalyptic levels of might as a one-woman army. Of course, you can use New Game Plus just to run around and take in the view!

If you have never played any game from the Final Fantasy 13 trilogy, I strongly recommend Lightning Returns. Like the leading lady herself, this game stands on its own with its gorgeous graphics, beautiful music and rich story.

If I have anything good to say about it, it's that Square Enix finally produced a rather good port of their in-house made game. Other than that, you will like this game only in case you: a) like Lightning as a model (not as a character) b) like what they done to the combat c) like fetch quests in MMOs.

If not, this game is an incredible dissapointment and probably the worst part of the XIII trilogy. The premise and ideas are absolutely fantastic - the world is ending, events of XIII and XIII-2 just postponed/lessened the impact of what the main antagonists were trying to do, but they essentially got what they wanted. People lived for 500 years stuck at the age they were when the ending of XIII-2 happened, no new people are being born. All that is left is that Lightning, as a Savior, saves the chosen souls to be reborn in the new world, where people can live, die and be born again. Sounds amazing, doesn't it? Sadly, the actual events to follow up on this are just horribly dumb.

Instead of a brilliant dark but hopeful ending to the trilogy we get stupidly boring retread on the previously done stories. Story has flashes of brilliance in terms of ideas, but never seems to understand what to do with them. Cutscenes are horribly and sometimes amateurishly directed, dialogues (often monologues) are boring and often poitnless. mini-stories in side-quests are sometimes interesting, but tied to most boring fetch quests you can imagine with most intriguing and involved quests in the entire game being the very first one you get. Things often just happen, get dropped, kinda picked up by the end, but there's no unifying feel to any of it. Everything is just *there*.

Same goes for the combat/RPG systems. Yes it is more involved and action-y than other XIII games, but it's still boring and often pointless. It's no Vagrant Story of Parasite Eve II. Also some features that could make first playthrough fights at least a bit less pointless are locked away until NG+ and some stay locked unless NG+ is played on Hard. Because reasons.

It's a game with a great premise that fails in devlivering on it. That has features and mechanics that have been used in much better and more fun games. That has an unsatisfying story, that could bring an interesting end to the trilogy, but instead goes for a "Lightning wet-fantasy fanfic" feel, that often reminds of Metroid: Other M in terms of how boring, self-indulgent, repetitive and stupid it is. ATB Bars are basically Mana Pools where Lightning uses an ability and that amount of ATB is taken from the ATB Bar. (Note that ATB is NOT shared between your Schemas and will regenerate when not in use.)
Combat Highly Revolves around how well the player can perfectly Block and Attack. 
Staggering is the main way to do damage, Staggering has different conditions depending on the enemy and there are many different ways you can stagger a single enemy. 
The player may choose whatever goes into the schema and is completely up to the player on which they would like to use. While on the topic of Schemas I would like to address a complaint that some players have about the Schema Setups.
Some players may feel forced to use a certain garb for a locked ability [spoiler] Soldier of Peace with Artemis's Arrow [/spoiler] Choosing to use a garb for the reward of easing the play is the PLAYER'S choice and not the games. I personally beat the game using garbs that Lightning wore in the previous games; which are given to the player for free in the Rewards Barter Shop (Only on the PC Port, On console you must have to have a save file from FXIII for 1 and FXIII-2 for another).
One of the aspects of the game are the Time Limit, You are given 6 Days to start but by progressing through the story you are given more. (PROTIP: DO NOT LOOK AT THE ACHIEVEMENTS OR YOU WILL GET SPOILED VERY HARD ;-;) Now roughly 2.5 seconds in Real Life are equivalent to 1 Minute in Lightning Returns clock. So 1 Hour of Lightning Returns time is equivalent to 2 minutes and 30 seconds of Real Life. That being said a Full Day in Lightning Returns is about 1 Real Life Hour. The clock is stopped during cutscenes, fights, and interaction with NPC's. Do not feel rushed, Square Enix knows that the time limit may be stressful and they incoporated abilities to help Lightning get through the quests without running out of time. 
Lightning is also given Eradia, which can be found in the bottom left corner indicated by a glowing orange number with orange bars. Eradia has many uses which are given to the player throughout the game. Eradia is lost when using an Eradia Powered ability and is gained by killing enemies. Certain enemies such as, Niblets, will not grant as much Eradia (roughly .02 Eradia gain) than slaying a Zaltys ( 1 Eradia gain). So killing big monsters will grant more Eradia to let Lightning use the Eradia spells.
Now the world is dying and it's all because of the Chaos. Chaos can be seen as a black aura with many tiles. If Lightning chooses to go to this area enemy encounters are alot harder. The enemy is given certain buffs while in the Chaos but if it leaves the chaos it becomes a regular enemy again. Fighting inside chaos may prove a challenge but if Lightning does win a battle inside the Chaos she is rewarded with: Bonus Eradia, Bonus Gil, and a higher chance of good drops.
Unlike the regular experience system in other FInal Fantasy games, Lightning Returns doesn't give you an experience system. Instead Lightning gets stronger through finishing: Main Quests, Side Quests, and Canvas of Prayer Quests (The Board found by Chocolina). While it may annoy some people having to grind quests to get stronger, it is optional. I was so engrossed in the story that after day 7 I slept all the way through the last day to see the ending.
Now we all play Final Fantasy Titles expecting story. Lightning Returns gives us story, some may not like it some may, Personally I enjoyed it. The story may be rushed at times but isn't that how it's suppoused to be? The world ends in 13 days and you can't dally or you fail your mission. The ending is something very special and if you hate Lightning as a character from FXIII and FXIII-2 for her attitude I would say you HAVE to play Lightning Returns. I personally loved Lightning as the main character throughout the series, being cold, violent, and mean made her seem like the biggest ***** alive but if that's the reason you don't want to play Lightning Returns you are doing yourself an injustice. The ending is something VERY SPECIAL while many seem to hate it I loved it (Even though I could barely see the screen through all my tears). It's something unique to say the least, I had always had an emotional connection with Lightning and the character progression of Lightning in this game parody'd (Related too well) to me, May have just caused a more emotional effect (I literally was blind in tears) 
Now Square Enix forces you to start with either Normal or Easy, Both do NOT offer the full experience and the player must play again on HARD, which is awarded after completing the game. You basically have to play through the whole game again to get the full experience. May be annoying for some people I found it fun going through the tougher bosses for round 2.
The PC Port of FXIII Lightning Returns, as said in other reviews is undoubtedly the BEST PC PORT for the FXIII Series and is great. I ran FXIII Lightning Returns on 1920 x 1080 60 FPS (Ocassionally dipped down to 40) on a NVIDIA GTX 960M (Comparable to the GTX 750TI for Desktop Users) I5-6300HQ 2.3GHz with 8 GB of RAM
FXIII Gets alot of hate and alot of negative reviews for different reasons and people always have differing opinions. If you did play FXIII and FXIII-2 you MUST play this one. If you want to start with Lightning Returns I would highly oppose it, and URGE you to play through FXIII and FXIII-2 to get the story and get the most from FXIII Lightning Returns.

[h1][u]tl;dr[/u][/h1]
+ decent gameplay; almost action game-esque
+ collecting different outfits, weapons and shields
+ quasi open world 
+ interesting side stories
+ a girl asked me to find her green doll. I brought her a red doll. She started laughing hysterically and went insane. The game told me her soul was now lost forever.

- main story is completely inane
- pointless and annoying time limit 
- framerate is still terrible

I'm really torn on this one.

On the one hand the gameplay is pretty decent and I would definitely lie if I said I didn't have fun with this game. Finding and changing between different costumes (surprisingly few of them are metal bikinis!) and weapon/ shield/ ability sets really motivated me to continue playing and exploring. Battles still mostly revolve around the stagger system which has a lot more depth this time around. More often than not you won't be able to dish out any meaningful damage on your opponents until you finally stagger them. However the conditions to do so vary from enemy to enemy. Sometimes you have to attack using a specific element, or use only physical or magical attacks respectively, other times you have to wait for them to attack you in a particular manner (like wait till they raise their weapon and stand on one leg) and then block/ dodge and counterattack or knock them over during the wind up. Part of me wishes they would have turned this into a proper action game (like Devil May Cry) or an action-RPG (like the Tales of series) because it certainly feels like those at times if it weren't for the lack of direct control. But, in the end, it's still fine the way it is. 
The only thing I didn't like gameplaywise was the timelimit. In fact I absolutely hate the whole idea. It doesn't even make sense from a storytelling perspective. Because apparently ever since what happened in XIII-2 the world itself has been slowly dying over the span of hundreds of years. But only in the last 13 days God decides to bring back Lightning to collect some souls for him. Like, he really couldn't have done that a little bit sooner...?
And now from a gameplay perspective, why would you ever design an open world RPG that more often than not asks you to run from one side of the map the other, and then limit the time you're allowed to explore all these areas? Even moreso when it's constantly shoved in our faces (Really. Hope never ever shuts up and reminds you - I think - every ingame hour which is about three minutes in real time that you're supposed to 'hurry up!').
Now, what most people will tell you, though, is that the time limit hardly even matters. And that's completely true. But, you know what? That ultimately makes it even worse, in my opinion. Because when the game constantly prompts you to speedrun through the game, you're most likely going to hurry from plot marker to plot marker and NPC to NPC to finish as many story and side quests as you can before you "run out of time". But in doing so you inevitably run out of things to do about halfway through the game, which means you now actually have to purposely waste time until you reach the final day to trigger the final story quest. That's just bad game design and so unnecessary as it really doesn't add anything to the gameplay or the story.

Then again, the story...
What a pile of crap, honestly. What the hell were they thinking? It almost reaches fan fiction levels of disconnectivity. None of this has anything to do with the original XIII, yet for some barely explained reasons the entire main cast of XIII still plays a major part in LR's story, although they mostly just look like them and act completely differently. It really feels like this was supposed to be an entirely different game which had the FF XIII theme slapped on top of it.
The dialogue is pretty damn cringe worthy as well. Mainly because Lightning is probably the biggest edgelord in Final Fantasy history, surpassing even Squall, Sephiroth and Paine. I mean, come on, she can no longer FEEL anything!? She forgot how to be happy or sad? Why.............................................
This ties right into the ending which a GameFAQs user perfectly describes as "the most unbearably hammy, cheesy cheese filled cheese videogame ending I have ever witnessed in my 20+ years of gaming". It's a textbook happy ending if I've ever seen one, yet it doesn't explain jack sh*t, because apparently you'll have to read like 3 extra books to even understand half of the stuff that happened in this and the previous games. I think I'll pass...

Apart from the main story, the sidequests are kinda good though, I'll admit that. Maybe also a bit corny every now and then (Thank you Lightning, for showing me the mistakes of my past, so I can redeem myself!) but there are definitely some interesting side stories. You meet a lot of different characters and personalities, who will sometimes go out of their way to tell you their entire life story (another thing that kind of goes against the whole idea of hurrying up), but at least they actually have something meaningful to say. Some of the sidequests build upon each other in a way that you have to finish one person's quest and learn about their past in order to realize that this is the exact kind of person who can help with another character's problem. The game rarely points you directly to your destination and you kind of have to look for the relevant quest items or NPC yourself (while the time limit ticks down...).

All in all a solid experience. Out of the three XIII games it's the one with the best gameplay in my opinion, but also the weakest story.

As for the PC port. I personally didn't see any improvement over XIII-2 whatsoever. The graphic options are there, like on paper. But what does that even mean when I choose between 'standard' and 'advanced' color correction. I played around a little bit with all the different options, but excluding resolutions I didn't notice any difference. The framerate is still terrible, because it costantly jumps between 60 and 30 fps lock every time it loads a set of NPCs. But at least you can permanently lock it to 30 fps now (Yay...?). Battles ran at a perfect 60 frames per second for me (which was the same experience I had with XIII-2).

21996003.review:
[h1] Square Enix's most underrated game that every RPG buff should experience [/h1]

Let me start by saying that I dropped FFXIII halfway and couldn't even stomach pass the first area of FFXIII-2. Confusing plot, mundane gameplay, annoying characters; the list goes on endlessly. I'm a massive Final Fantasy fan (played all the numbered entries, some spinoffs and currently clocking 1000 hours on FFXIV) but FFXIII and its sequel is a steaming pile of disappointment. When Lightning Returns went on sale, I still had doubts that the trilogy could get me interested. One hesitant purchase later, I was pleasantly surprised that all my earlier worries were for naught. Not only is Lightning Returns a great comeback to quality Final Fantasy, but it's also one of the most exceptional RPGs to come out in a while. And just so I can make this clear before continuing my review: [b] you don’t have to play or like the first two games to appreciate Lightning Returns, although they may help in your enjoyment of the game. [/b]

The plot picks up centuries after the second game’s ending. After being crystallized for hundreds of years, Lightning awakens to find that the entire world is ending in 13 days. Numerous monsters rise from sinister zones called Chaos, most of the world has been engulfed in darkness and the remaining traces of civilization left can be found in the Dead Dunes, The Wildlands and the cities of Luxerion and Yusnaan. The worst realization for Lightning, however, is her sister Serah being held captive by the god of light, Bhunivelze. The god then made a deal to Lightning: she would become his servant for the final 13 days in return for her sister's freedom.

I have not finished both prequels, but I can assure you that the game does a good enough job in explaining its branching storyline. Some terms and characters are foreign at first for new players, but it's nothing a few hours of playing the game can fix. The story is also easier to follow and not distracting unlike in the past two games. Also two giant thumbs up for wrapping up the story in one of the most epic finale in the series!

Speaking of characters, Lightning Returns takes a step forward for the supporting characters and a massive leap for our titular heroine. If you couldn't stand any of the characters in the prequels, you'll be glad to hear that this game made their presence actually bearable. All returning characters except Lightning receive limited screen time, but their personality this time around is fleshed out through individual story arcs. With an impending apocalypse in sight, it’s not really surprising that many of the upbeat characters took a turn for the worst. Lightning herself is no longer the constantly broody genderbent Cloud from the first game, but a strong woman who is constantly seeking out her true self while looking out for her sister. From her rich interactions with the other characters and NPCs, I realize that she could be snarky, cynical, hilarious and even (gasp) feminine. She yearns to help others while always putting her mission first. I couldn't help but notice that the characterization of Lightning here just screams Geralt from The Witcher 3.

I would like to thank Square Enix for heavily revamping the combat system and making the battles actually enjoyable. Still remember the clunky mix of turn-based and real-time combat of the prequels? In Lightning Returns, the battles feel like a fresh hybrid of FFX and Crisis Core. You can unleash different attacks real-time using the four button inputs while keeping an eye on the ATB bar. If your ATB bar runs out, you'll be unable to take action for a period of time. Timing your attacks, managing your bar, exploiting the enemy's weaknesses and switching between garbs (which I'll get to in a sec) form the combat mechanics of Lightning Returns. There's even a dose of Dark Souls thrown in where timing your blocks become essential to survive against tougher foes and bosses. Unlike other Final Fantasy games, Lightning Returns will reward players who can master strategic combat instead of those who can grind the longest or obtain the best equipment. This is further backed up by the lack of EXP system in the game.

Wait, did I hear that right? No EXP, so no levels? That's absolutely correct. The term "experience points" and "levels" is nonexistent in Lightning Returns. The only way to boost Lightning's stats is by completing main story missions and side quests. Instead of getting EXP, killing monsters will net you new skills, rare weapon drops and EP for your counter. The EP counter is sort of like your SP bar in traditional RPGs for using utility skills. The only reason you will want to grind mobs is to farm skills and build up your EP counter for very situational moments. Strong skills are essential to create the ultimate Lightning, but fear not since the drop rate in this game is abnormally high.

In exchange for controlling Lightning the entire game, our heroine can equip different armors called "garbs" to fulfill the role of an entire party. Think back to the different roles like Commando and Ravager in the prequels except it involves Lightning switching garbs mid-battle instead. Each garb has their own ATB bar so timing your switches is essential since they can only refill their bar while on standby mode. For even more customization, the garbs can be modified heavily with skills that drop from monsters. The maximum number of garbs you can wield per battle is three, and there are over 80 different garbs you can buy and find. Not to mention all the garbs have pretty sweet designs!

A major complaint I've seen by most critics and players is the clock system. Every three seconds in the real world equals a minute in Lightning Returns. Right out of the tutorial level, you are given only 13 in-game days to complete numerous tasks before the world ends. Fail to do so and Lightning might not be strong enough to fight through the final day. Here's a confession: this feature was actually the main turnoff that almost made me pass the game. Even I thought the developers were on meds when they decided to make a time-restricted RPG. Guess what? By the 9th day, I was able to complete virtually every side quest and story arc! This includes me wandering around aimlessly, backtracking a lot because I felt like I skipped a treasure chest and even falling asleep once (which, by the way, causes the game to pause automatically to not waste precious time). My total playtime was already a good 40ish hours by then. The clock system may sound restrictive, but the time available is actually much, MUCH, longer than you think. For those who played the game and still think that time is too short, be aware that a skill to temporarily stop time is forever at your disposal for only a measly 1 EP. The only minor annoyance with this feature is that some quests can only be taken and turned in at specific times. The same goes for the accessibility of several areas in the world.

All in all, I consider Lightning Returns as a reminder to why I love the series so much. It's the second game I ever cared to Platinum to date, so take that as you will.

Definitely a strong [b] 9/10 [/b]
