21881014.review:
I'd open this review with a spoiler warning, but if you've read the store-page, then you already know what happened. Gran Pulse was invited to a picnic, but was given nothing but shit sandwiches. All that's left of the world now is Nova Chrysalia, four continents inhabited by humans who have lost their "time". Children never grow up, adults never grow old, and the seniors... they just keep being old. For 500 years the last remnants of humanity have endured, but it's all coming to a close. The world is ending in 13 days, and no I'm not talking in JRPG days. The clock is ticking, and only a Goddess can save everyone's souls. Lightning has returned to settle this mess once and for all.

As with the previous game (FF13-2), Lightning Returns is a major departure from the first entry, yet it carries over many of the sub-systems and combat-design. It's a decidedly different adventure, with its emphasis on open-world exploration, and stat-building tied almost entirely to quests, but the elements of familiarity keep everything somewhat grounded. The battle-system still revolves around the number 3. Lightning can equip three schematas aka outfits. Each set of clothes has different stats or abilities tied to them. These schemata are customized further with abilities you acquire from monsters or treasure. 

Battles are entirely real-time, and you're given far more agency than previous FF titles. By switching between the three schemata, you'll account for every possible situation. You can even deflect large amounts of damage with a perfectly-timed block. Unlike a number of JRPGs, high stats tend to take a back-seat to planning, strategies, and reflexes. Lightning also has access to a handful of EP skills. These powerful abilities can really turn the tide. All in all, the battle-system in this game is excellent. It really feels like the culmination of all of the ideas Square-Enix has implemented throughout the FF series. 

The rest of the game is more interesting in concept than execution. As with most open-world games, there are a lot of side-quests. These side-quests usually involve fetching items, or finding people to converse with. This means you'll be spending a ton of time just running around. The in-game timer isn't too much of a worry, especially on the easy setting, because you can just spam chronostasis to stop the clock. However, your real-world time is going to be rather dull and annoying. I won't lie, I used a guide to locate all of the quest-giving NPCs. There was no way I was going to run circles around every continent just to find people. 

It's too bad really, because there is a subtle cleverness to NPC interactions in this game. As with previous FF-13 games, most of the NPCs don't really have anything to say, aside from sharing their opinion on Lightning's current outfit. What is this? [i]Skyrim[/i]? Maybe the guards will ask Lightning to conjure them up a nice warm bed next. Anyway, almost all of the interesting NPCs have ??? marks over their head. This is what catches the player's curiousity. Sometimes these NPCs can't be talked to at first, so the player will think: "Hmm... I'll have to keep them in mind in the future." When using a guide, all of the mystery is lost, since you'll know where to go, when to arrive there, and how to go about accomplishing the task you're given.

While there's a heavy amount of combat in Lightning Returns, there are actually very few bosses. This is disappointing for a number of reasons. Due to the constant fighting, you'll figure out the strategy for every monster, and get lulled into a sense of complacency. Unfortunately, this means you'll be ill-prepared for the few major encounters, which are varied and immensely thrilling. In keeping with LR being a "send-off" for FF13, you'll face "Last Ones". Ever see that Jet Li movie [i]The One[/i]? Same concept. When a monster is hunted to near-extinction, the Last One gains the power of all the others that had died before it. Some of these Last Ones can be really tough, especially when fought near the very end of the game. The problem is that you either have to grind away, or face them all in a gauntlet. I tried to do a bit of both, and it led to boredom and then frustration, because I got my tail handed to me quite a few times.

I really like the idea of The Last One, it drives home the fact that this might be the last time you experience FF13. Unless, of course, you decide to play New Game+. I approve of any RPG that implements this system. Although, I think making equipment-upgrades NG+ only is a real head-scratcher. I believe that having weapon-upgrades available earlier would make the level of difficulty more fluid. More players would opt to choose the normal setting for a first play-through, if they had additional opportunities to strengthen Lightning. Also, while this game offers a lot of niceties to NG+ players, you still have to re-do almost every quest, especially if you're like me and didn't defeat a certain end-game super-boss. 

As for the story, well, I can't tell you how many times I got the urge to skip a cut-scene or three. It's not that the storyline is particularly bad, there's just not much to it. When there's organized religion in a JRPG, you already have an idea of how things are going to turn out. A lot of the time I felt like I was just going through the motions. Still, I have to say that Square-Enix really knocked it out of the park with the final portion of the game. Everything about the last hour or two is just perfect. To give an idea of how good it is, it not only lifted my opinion of LR, but also the other FF13 games. This is a trilogy that put its cast of characters as well as the players through a lot of crap, but its ending is so great, that I felt it was all worthwhile.

Surprisingly, this port is the best of the FF13 PC trilogy. Aside from that nasty online-only DRM that was quickly removed, I'm very pleased with how it turned out. Granted, the frame-rate chokes a little when moving around, but for me it's always been at or around 60 fps during battles, which is exceedingly important. I didn't run into any crashes or other major issues, and that's always nice. Actually, there might have been one crash, but I'm going to blame it on my PC, it was acting a little strange that day.

There's a lot to like about Lightning Returns. Aside from its many unique ideas, this game presents one of the most refreshing and fun battle-systems in franchise history. It carries over the familiarity of the previous FF13 titles, but with its own spin. Nova Chrysalia is an interesting world, and each continent has at least one or two cool aspects to it. While LR's ambitions are never quite matched by tight game-design, S-E still managed to craft something very special.

Five centuries after XIII-2 the world is going to be destroyed in thirteen days and it's up to Lightning to get the band back together ... in heaven.  While it might not be as dumb as it sounds to me, what I do know is the plot will be delivered almost exclusively through forced exposition that DOES. NOT. STOP.  You will hear conversation after conversation repeating the same exposition, often several times in a row!  Need a thing?  Don't need a thing?  Don't worry, your loyal resident Navi, Hope, will remind you every five minutes to get that thing, even if it so happens you can't get the thing, don't want to get the thing or are trying to find a different thing.

Honestly, this game has opened up a new genre for me that I dub the 'chore' game.  Lightning Returns is quite literally a series of expositional cut scenes intersped with fetch quests.  The chore is both literal, the never ending fetch quests, and metaphorical, as in this game is a chore to play.  Yet, as awful as that sounds, every character is in on this joke: even Lightning herself contually bemoans her fate before begrudgingly accepting these countless, thankless tasks.  It's not a good sign when the lead character's only motivation is to acquiesce because she has to, but tell me game, what's MY motivation.  Every quest, and I mean EVERY quest will work as follows: a person will tell you something they need, get that thing and take it to them.  This either completes the quest or leads you to the next person who needs something.  Yay.  This formula will not be deviated from.


While we could have a philosophical debate that nearly all games work this way, other games usually try to pad this out a bit with dialogue, minigames, crafting, inventory management.  Something!  In Lightning Returns you are either fetching an item or looking for a person to fetch for.  I would have been shocked if a SINGLE character you spoke with said, "I can help you, right this way!"  Spoiler alert: that will never happen, and neither will anything else.  So it's basically what it looks like, a cosplay fetch quest fantasy.  I'm not really sure what Square Enix was trying to create here but while I admit it might have some charm and appeal for some, personally I found it too limited to put up with for more than my recorded play time.

21739214.review:
All things considered this is a surprisingly nice game. It has some rough edges, but it's totally worth playing through. It's slightly difficult to recommend to anyone who's not already into JRPGs or familiar with Final Fantasy (which for all intents and purposes are rather 'Westernised' and not particularly 'hardcore' JRPGs anyway), but that kind of goes without saying. It's a niche genre game and a great one at that. I know people have been critical about the FFXIII games, but from the few hours I've spend on this game so far (about 11 hours) I'd generally disagree with most of the critique. It got me hooked fairly easily, despite a few flaws.

PROS:
-excellent voice acting, both in Japanese and English
-great sountrack 
-great combat system with surprising depth in strategy because of the Schemata you can customise and abilities you can upgrade.
-your clothing (garbs), weapons and items determine a large portion of the damage you do, health you have and so on, which makes for a very good combat system
-no XP level up nonsense grind here, although you can upgrade general stats from around half-way through the game
-defeating monsters actually requires skill and blocking / evading
-the game's difficulty is excellent and higher difficulties will really make this a tough challenge for experienced players, people new to JRPGs should probably start on Easy as to not get frustrated
-main quest missions are great and actually make you want to play on and on
-side quest missions are not too much of a grind or fetch quest IMHO
-locations are great, varied and generally just very interesting, something that can't be said about many recent games these days that suffer from open-world generic-ness and problematic recycling of content
-despite the somewhat lazy port, PERFORMANCE is excellent at all times, with combat being a joy at full HD resolution (or higher) @ 60 fps. I'd say it's required for a game like this, as you do have to respond rather quickly in combat
-graphics in general look great, even despite texture resolution not really being entirely current generation quality. It's hardly a problem in a game that looks like an anime anyway
-amazing cutscenes (that kind of make you wish the entire game looked like that, but lets not forget this is a PS3 port)

CONS:
-sidequests aren't entirely optional, you kind of need to gather as much souls, gil credits/weapons/garbs/etc as possible in order to stop 'time' and have acceptable stats to progress through the main quest. I'd say one to three side quests per zone (or chapter I suppose) seems to be the minimum. thankfully there's a variation in difficulty of said side quests.
-speaking of time, the game has a day and night cycle which includes a mandatory trip to a futuristic spin on 'Noah's Ark', which is actually kind of immersion breaking and annoying. They probably should have made that optional. Trainers do exist to mod the game and turn the timer off though, but I didn't really found that necessary. 
-story line is kind of a biblical affair with the player being 'the savior' in a fairly literal way, this might be off putting to some. Without spoiling too much, you've struck a deal with God and need to gather as many souls as possible within the  5 days left before an inevitable apocalypse. 
-the game could use a few more voice overs for the taunts or commentary of the player, there are only a few different lines and she uses them a lot. Same goes for voice over loops of announcers in some areas that keep telling you you're a wanted criminal. 

Some nitpicking:
-there's a downside to how some enemies have rather varied weaknesses, which means your most successful 'build of Schematas (which defines your attacks, blocks, evasions, magic attacks or heals or any kind of bonuses in combat) tends to be more of a generalised build, instead of specialising which results in far more powerful more interesting builds. I wouldn't say the game is ever unfair here, but don't be too surprised if you need to change your Schematas in order to beat specific types of enemies, which otherwise take forever to beat with your weaker attacks that happen to be the kind they aren't immune to. I suppose to many people this is a good thing, because it means the game requires some skill / stragey in building effective Schematas
-you'll see the same enemy types a lot, but with the combat being rather exciting it's a minor gripe. You'll also figure out how to deal with the strengths and weaknesses of each specific type fairly soon. Don't get me wrong, there are plenty of different enemies in total, but 10 hours in I've only seen less than a dozen so far
-keyboard control is rebindable which is great, but the default lay-out makes zero sense. You'll be using BackSpace, M, . and all kinds of keys across the keyboard to control the game; I've played thusfar on keyboard, but I'm sure using a Gamepad of some kind would work way better
-no mouse camera control /in-menu control as far as I can tell, but you'd best play this with a controller anyway
-don't be too surprised to find literal references to the PS3, because it's actually a fairly lazy port all around. 

I've got no doubt some people think this game is pushing it's whole 'savior story' a bit too much, which is kind of true, but there's plenty of great content to be found regardless with the new combat system being a big pro. I recommend the game, especially on a discount.

I held off on this game for a long time, in fact it was the first Final Fantasy game I decided I would not bother getting - and having been a fan of the series for almost my entire life that was a huge deal. The reason for this of course was the dreaded "timer".

Well, the game has been out a while, it was on sale for 8 Euro, I figured id keep an open mind and try it out! And I gotta say.. I misjudged it. Don't get me wrong, I still don't like the time management aspect as it stresses me out, it makes me rush more than i'd like in an RPG, some of the zones are pretty huge and i'd love to just go exploring for a while - but I can't because i'll game over if I do. Im a completionist and this game doesn't allow it. With that said I gotta say for what it is, the time aspect is well done - it's actually bareable even for someone who hates that sort of thing, the timer pauses in conversations, cutscenes, menu's - and when you chill at your base (ark) in between days, stopping to take a breather or tinkering with your gear/shopping is really not an issue which is great! The timer will only run when you are running around the map exploring and moving about.. It even pauses in combat, and the more combat you do the more "EP" you collect, which you can use to cast Chronostasis which freezes the timer for a while. You can also extend your total time by several days when you do certain quests, so in short.. You have plenty of time. I haven't finished the game at the time of writing this but I am quite confident that i'll be able to do most if not all things that I want too during my first playthrough with some management, and with the game being built around multiple playthroughs (like Type-0) anything I do miss i'll be able to check out the next time around, and there seems to be plenty of reasons to play through a second time.

Alright, im ranting on so i'll move away from the timer topic and get into the game itself. The story has been referred to as lighthearted but I think that's incorrect, it's not as deep as what you are used too from the main series of games, but was any spin-off sequal ever? Think X-2, yes it has a few more lighthearted moments and some obvious fan service, but the story do have a serious tone as well as it wraps up the series.
The performance of the game is great, it looks pretty and runs smoothly and I haven't run into any bugs or crashes. The only thing that I would complain on from a technical standpoint is the controls, they are really weird and you can't set everything as you want which makes it feel like an obvious console port, for an example your map button and one of your attack buttons shares a key, and similarly with the menu button and a second attack, etc. So if you want your map on M and your menu on say Tab or Esc like in a typical PC game, you would have to do combat with those two keys as well which is a pain in the ass and 20 houres in im still not used to the controls and I probably won't ever be, so i'd definetly recommend trying a controller if you have on since the game is obviously built for that! 
Lastly the gameplay itself, combat is suprisingly fun although some of the random monster encounters can be a bit annoying, either they will knock you to the ground all too often, or die too easily, when you to get around to a boss you are rewarded for strategy. You can play the game button mashing, but the game rewards you if you choose to play better, as an example - you can hold the block button to block things, but if you simply press block at the right moment you might knock back and stagger your enemy, and there's also tactical strategies as using vulnerabilities against enemies. 
You do not get to level up in the traditional way which im not sure if I like or not.. Instead you are rewarded with permanent stats for each quest you complete, another reason to replay the game, as you can increase in power endlessly (?). You also get quite alot of new equipments and you can equip multiple setups to switch between in batte, and you can upgrade your spells - and from what I hear your equipment too once you unlock hard mode, so despite not leveling up you still have plenty of ways to increase in power and you get quite a few ways to customize your Lightning the way you like her.

That should cover the basics so i'll just TLDR; The time management is annoying but ok, it sounds worse than it is - the game is not as serious as the previous two installments but doesn't screw around with it's story, don't go into it expecting another main series game, with an open mind though you should definetly have alot of fun and get a nice conclusion to the story.

And most of all - get ready to repeat these words regularly every time you play.. SHUT UP, HOPE.

Very fun, recommended.  I enjoyed this game so much that I completed 100% of the achievements just to ekk out every bit of game-play possible.

In this game you can upgrade your abilities (skills) and completely customize what schema you want to use.  I found that replicating what FF13/13-2 did worked out best for my gaming experience.  You can use three different groups; one as commander (melee), two as ravager (mage), and the third schema as sentinel (tank)/saboteur (debuffs) hybrid.    Following are my final set-ups that beat 99% of the game on normal mode, with the exception of a few switches to battle a couple of the final bosses.

[b]Garb Commander: Soldier of Peace[/b]
Weapon: Masamune
Shield: Blasphemy
Accessories: Tiger's Emblem, Dawn Gauntlets
Adornment: Killer Shades
Abilities: Shadownbind, Attack, Heavy Slash, Mediguard
Why use this Schema? Leveled up Heavy Slash turns Artemis's Pierce into a one turn killing machine.  Alternatively use Mediguard to life-up.

[b]Garb Ravager: Spira's Summoner[/b]
Weapon: Chaos's Revenge
Shield: Summoner's Shield
Accessories: Falcon Charm, Sniper's Gloves
Adornment: White Mage's Hat
Abilities: Elementa Lv. ★, Mediguard, Magnet, *
Why use this Schema? Elementa Lv. ★ will simply destroy 99% of the game. Alternatively use Mediguard to life-up.  Never found much else to use in the other two slots that was worth ATB Vs. Elementa, besides perhaps magnet and then something like fire or air depending on the enemy.

[b]Garb Sentinel/Saboteur: Guardian Corps[/b]
Weapon: Blazefire Saber
Shield: Noblesse Veronique
Accessories: Preta Hood, Runic Ring
Adornment: Black Mage's Hood
Abilities: Deshell, Deprotect, Imperil, Mediguard
Why use this Schema? Those accessories will make you immune to magic attacks.  This is my default garb, so when the battle starts you can cast Deshell and Imperil onto target then smash them with Elementa.  Cast Deprotect before hitting with Heavy Slash.  Mediguard for life-up.  Alternatively switch to Guard Glove & Ghostly Hood accessories when fighting heavy physical enemies.  Also switch Imperil with Poison for some bosses.

Since the PC version of Lightning returns gives you all DLC for free (turn on DLC in the options and buy them for free in the rewards screen) most of these garbs are already available to you... starting out I did use Cloud's SOLDIER 1st Class in place of the commander's Soldier of Peace garb (along with his weapon/shield.)  The Guardian Corps and Blazefire Saber are unlocked for free also if you have a FF13 save file.

Lightning Returns, starring everyone's favourite rose colored hair protagonist!
The world is submerged into chaos and it won't be long till the end of the world. It is up to our old pal Lightning to save the day (or is it days?)
Lightning, who slumbered for 500 years is awakened by the god of light Bhunivelze. The world isn't like she hoped it would be, the people are stuck in a world ruled by chaos, they do not age, but they are still able to die from diseases. Bhunivelze gives Lighning the task and power to save their souls so that they can be born again on a new world created by the almighty god of light. Lightning seeing her efforts were in vain sets foot again on a quest to save her sister Serah.
She soon meets her old partner Snow, who knows she's sent by god and isn't so willingy to hand over his soul and questions Lightning's beliefs. So, after a little fight Lightning retreats, while so she meets a mysterious young girl named Lumina who only she can see and hear, her role in this story very important and and she frequently shows up to help Lightning, in her own mischief ways and remind her what she's fighting for. Who Lumina really is, is something that you can find out pretty early if you use your wits. Lightning herself will stay dumbstruck till the end of the game and when she finally figures it out you get a relieved satisfactory feeling.
Lightning will meet many of her old friends on her journy to save the souls, some want to fight her, one just doesn't give one f*** and others welcome her with open arms! Lightning helps them get a hold of themselves by helping out with serious troubles, something they couldn't figure out on their own. Which brings me to something I noticed. There are quests that involve a children who lost their things, one lost her stuffed animal, another lost his ball. In both instances the belongings are literally 30 feet away from them and family disputes which could easily be solved by talking to each other, but instead it took a middle woman a.k.a. Lightning to go back and forth delivering messages. Wheter these people got realy lazy because of the chaos or if it was the developers who couldn't come up with better quests will be a question I don't know how to answer. 

So far, there aren't too many main quest, you can finnish these quite fast. The game revolves about a timed based kind of gameplay. The world as we know it will end in a couple of days and it is Lightning's task to save as many souls before they are lost forever. In order to save people's souls Lightning has to help these troubled people across the world, which usually  translate to fetch quests and defeat xx number of enemies or talk to a person. Completing these quests mostly end up in a follow up quests. Once you successfully complete a quest you will be awarded xp and unique items and the person's soul. At 6AM the day is over and you will return to "The Ark", here you will drop the souls into a gigantic flower named Yggdrasil, the more souls you put in the more it will grow and by giving many souls, you will be granted extra days. You will also find some useful items here and you can fight previously fought bosses for idk, better score? Oh, and there's Hope who you can talk to and replenish items. Anyways...

 As you explore huge fields and cities, finding people who are in need of your help, time keeps on ticking and boy does it tick fast! Like, two seconds in real life equals one minute on the clock. Now this can be countermeasured with a skill named chronostasis, this skill will cost the player 1 EP. EP which is from a special meter that fills up from defeating monsters, the stronger the monster, the faster you build up your EP meter. Chronostasis will only last about a minute, but recharging just one point of the EP meter will take quite some time and most of the time you use it, there won't be strong monsters around, so it makes this skill totally impractical. Personally, I think they did the whole time constraint thing better in FFXIII-2, since you could just travel through time via the Historia Crux, why the Ark doesn't work this way? Beats me. I am not sure what they were thinking. I wish time would only advance when you completed a quest or that the clock didn't tick so quickly. Fortunately I found an easy mod to stop the clock for good.
 
Which brings me to the combat. The combat in this game involves Lightning switching between three active roles which all have a matching costume (garb), hp and atb, that last one is very important, because it's the feul in a well oiled machine! The idea is to equip three garbs and balane them in a way that gives you the upper hand in battle. For instance, you come across enemies that are weak to ice, but strong to fire attacks. Each costume has four slots, usually they have one or two occupied slots, so you choose a garb that has the skills you need and fill up the rest of the slots with attack, defensive and debilitating skills, you then switch between switch between garbs during battle to attack relentlessly. Come across different enemies? No problem, you can save your setup to extra slots and equip a whole new garb + skills without overwriting your old setup. Defeating monsters reward you with skills that you can then equip and fight with. You can obtain unique garbs from shops and completing quests. A fun way to make up for just controlling one character throughout mostly of the game. If there is one garb I can recommend, the FFX Yuna garb is extremely powerfull, I used this garb till late end game.

There are a handful beautiful locations you visit, from a town with little restaurants and terraces, a field with windmills and in the distance a view of something that resembles a city of modern day skyscrapers, a forest so huge that it is easy to lose your bearings, to a desert where the most fun you can have there is sand surfing!
All the areas look really amazing and are rendered with a pretty smooth 60 fps, which is a nice job. The only time the fps drops is when passing through obvious load areas, which is a bit of a let down, but since you run right past it, it doesn't really hinder the experience.
The sounds in this game are alright,  in the huge city Yusnaan there are street artist who play memorable final fantasy songs on their instruments which is really cool and the background music is really nice, because there are different tracks that play depending on what time it is, so no happy joy joy festval music at 6am in the morning, just a nice mix of synths and piano and at night you will something jazzy. The voice acting is done beautiful, I actually prefer the english dub because I got so used to hear Ali Hillis's soothing voice. The japanese voice actress who sounds also great and fitting to the character is just missing that little bit of uniqueness. Although the voice cast sounds great, the sound editing crew did a poor job of making everything sound in place, so when you are located e.g. in a church, the voice acting will sound like they are in a studio talking through some really expensive equipment. No biggy.
The world feels alive, with people doing their thing like, doing the laundry, moving boxes around, run when they see you run, petting animals, walking in between you and the npc, pushing them 30 feet away from you, you know the usual thing. 
Graphics are quite good, but there are definitally moments where you will see some really low res textures and npcs and animals look like they were transferred from a PS2 game, but that didn't bother me very much.  
Ultimately, would I recommend this game? If you like to find out wha happen with Serah or if you just like Lightning and the fanservice, then yes, otherwise no. it's a fun game that you can play for a while and then pick it back up couple days later. this is not like other jrpgs where you have tons of interaction between the characters and just enjoy it so much that you forget about the time.

[b]At first I was weary about buying another Final Fantasy XIII title. But after playing through this game, I am so glad that I did.[/b]

Lightning Returns really feels like a Final Fantasy game. When I played XIII and XIII-2, they felt like okay games, but for Final Fantasy games, they really fell short in a lot of places. On the other hand, LR had the same feel as the old Final Fantasy games did. I could not stop playing, because I wanted to explore the world and literally do every side quest I could in the game. This is the kind of feeling that FFVI - FFX had for me, and I'm really pleased with how Square-Enix brought this exciting feeling back.

A few things that made this game so much more interesting than the others:[list]
[*]The opening sequence really drew me in and made me extremely interested in what this game was about. While the other two had slightly interesting beginnings, neither of them pulled it off quite as well as this one did.

[*]Another thing that made this game so strong was the interesting world. It was so open world that you could literally do any of the main quests in whatever order you wanted. I loved exploring the whole world, and how each area had its own unique culture.

[*]All of the NPCs had their own back stories and interesting reasons for doing what they were doing. This is one of the features that really made me want to do all of the side quests, without making them feel like "extra work" or generic "fetch quests," even if they were technically asking you to go get an item for them or slay a monster. There were even certain times of day that certain NPCs would be in specific areas. This made them seem so real. Like they were real people with real lives, and couldn't just be sitting in the same spot all day, because they had things to do.

[/list]At first the battle system was my main complaint, but after getting used to it, it turned out to be my favorite battle system in the XIII series. It requires so much strategy and isn't as simple as hitting "auto-battle" and sitting there, watching the battle play through. I love how it has elements of the ATB system from previous Final Fantasy titles, but it also brings in much more action elements to really make it feel like you are participating and controlling every move.

Another thing that turned me off at first was the time limit of the game. At first I was worried that I would be unable to do everything in the amount of time given, but as I played the game, it really wasn't a huge issue. I was able to complete all of the main five quests with at least three days left to finish up side quests. Using the combination of Chronostasis and Teleport really makes things fairly easy to complete in the time limit given. Also, being a project manager, this was really a lot of fun for me to manage my time and use every second efficiently. It got me excited to be able to write down what times certain quests could be completed, and when things had to be done by. This might be hard for people who don't enjoy time management as much as me, but honestly it's a really fun challenge that is added to the game.

One last thing that I would like to point out is the improvement from XIII-2, in regards to the PC Port. I didn't find too much wrong with this port, and it ran just like it would on a PS3, for the most part. No lag at all (I played on the lowest settings and it still looked beautiful). The only issues I had were that it would crash in the Jagd Woods in the Wildlands sporadically if I did not save every few minutes. Other than that, I never had any problems.
